chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Incarnation and Birth of Christ
chunks.latin: LIBER SECUNDUS. CAPUT PRIMUM De Incarnatione Christi, vel ejus Nativitate.
chunks.english: Book Two. Chapter One: The Incarnation and Birth of Christ.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Mor. lib. XXX, c. 25, n. 73.) Omnipotens Dominus noster Jesus Christus per majestatis potentiam omnia circumplectitur, et tamen per dispensationis gratiam intra uterum Virginis venit, sua dispensatione nos redimens, divinitate cuncta complectens, et humanitatem intra uterum sumens.
chunks.english: As Gregory writes in his thirtieth book of Moralia, our Lord Jesus Christ, the Almighty, encompasses all things through the power of his majesty. Yet through the grace of divine economy, he came into the womb of the Virgin. Through his own dispensation he redeems us, embracing all things by his divinity while taking on humanity within the womb.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 30, chapter 25, paragraph 73

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In quo utero incarnatus est, et clausus non est; quia et intra uterum fuit per infirmitatis substantiam, et extra mundum per potentiam majestatis.
chunks.english: In that womb he was incarnate, yet not confined. He was within the womb through the substance of weakness, and beyond the world through the power of his majesty.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ev., homil. 29, n. 10, 11.) Veniendo Christus ad redemptionem nostram quosdam, ut ita dixerim, saltus dedit, et necessarium nobis est ipsos ejus saltus agnoscere.
chunks.english: In his second book of Homilies on the Gospels, Gregory writes: When Christ came for our redemption, he made certain leaps, so to speak, and it is necessary for us to recognize these leaps of his.
chunks.notes: Citation to Homilies on the Gospels, book 2, homily 29, paragraphs 10-11

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: De coelo venit in uterum, de utero venit in praesepium, de praesepio venit in crucem, de cruce venit in sepulcrum, de sepulcro rediit in coelum.
chunks.english: From heaven he came to the womb, from the womb he came to the manger, from the manger he came to the cross, from the cross he came to the tomb, from the tomb he returned to heaven.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ecce ut nos post se currere faceret, quosdam pro nobis saltus manifestata per carnem Veritas dedit: Quia exsultavit ut gigas ad currendam viam suam (Psalm. XVIII, 6), ut nos ei ex corde diceremus: Trahe me post te, curremus in odorem unguentorum tuorum (Cant. I, 3).
chunks.english: Behold, to make us run after him, the Truth made manifest in the flesh made certain leaps for us. As the psalm says, he rejoiced like a giant to run his course, so that we might say to him from our hearts: Draw me after you, we will run to the fragrance of your ointments, as we read in the Song of Songs, chapter one, verse three.
chunks.notes: Citations to Psalm 18:6 and Song of Songs 1:3

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde oportet ut illuc sequamur corde ubi cum corpore ascendisse credimus.
chunks.english: Therefore we must follow with our hearts to where we believe he ascended with his body.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Mor. XXXIII, c. 1, n. 2.) Mons Domini Christus appellatus est, qui in Israelitico populo incarnari dignatus est; mons quippe est in vertice montium incarnatus Dominus, transcendens celsitudinem prophetarum.
chunks.english: In his thirty-third book of Moralia, Gregory writes: Christ is called the mountain of the Lord, he who deigned to be incarnate among the Israelite people. The incarnate Lord is indeed a mountain upon the peak of mountains, transcending the loftiness of the prophets.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 33, chapter 1, paragraph 2

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 1, n. 4.) Incarnatus Unigenitus Patris istis montibus, patriarchis scilicet atque prophetis, vel omnibus sanctis, aequalis non fuit, quia naturam, vitam vel merita omnium ex sua divinitate transcendit.
chunks.english: In his second book of Homilies on Ezekiel, Gregory writes: The incarnate Only-Begotten of the Father was not equal to these mountains, that is, the patriarchs, prophets, and all the saints, because from his divinity he transcends the nature, life, and merits of all.
chunks.notes: Citation to Homilies on Ezekiel, book 1, homily 8, paragraph 23; source citation appears inconsistent with content location

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ezech., homil. 8, n. 23.) Incarnatus Unigenitus Patris, per hoc quod homo factus est, infra angelos fuit, sicut de eo scriptum est: Minuisti eum paulo minus ab angelis (Psalm. VIII, 6).
chunks.english: In his first book of Homilies on Ezekiel, Gregory writes: The incarnate Only-Begotten of the Father, by the fact that he became man, was below the angels, as it is written of him: You made him a little lower than the angels, from Psalm eight, verse six.
chunks.notes: Citation to Homilies on Ezekiel, book 1, homily 8, paragraph 23 and Psalm 8:6

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Resurgens autem et ascendens in coelos, omnibus angelicis potestatibus praesidet; sicut de eo illic rursum scriptum est: Omnia subjecisti sub pedibus ejus (Ibid. 7); et sicut ipse ait: Data est mihi omnis potestas in coelo et in terra (Matth. XXVIII, 18).
chunks.english: But rising and ascending into heaven, he presides over all angelic powers, as it is written again of him in the same psalm: You have subjected all things under his feet. And as he himself says in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-eight, verse eighteen: All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me.
chunks.notes: Citations to Psalm 8:7 and Matthew 28:18

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dum Divinitas defectum nostrae carnis suscepit, humanum genus lumen quod amiserat recepit. Unde enim Deus humana patitur, inde homo ad divina sublevatur.
chunks.english: When the Divinity took upon itself the weakness of our flesh, the human race received back the light it had lost. For from that place where God suffers human things, from there humanity is raised up to divine things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Mediator Dei et hominum per humanitatis incarnationem habuit nasci, crescere, mori, resurgere, de loco ad locum venire.
chunks.english: The Mediator between God and humanity, through the incarnation of his humanity, was able to be born, to grow, to die, to rise, to come from place to place.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia ergo in divinitate mutabilitas non est, atque hoc ipsum mutari transire est, profecto iste transitus ex carne est, non ex divinitate.
chunks.english: Because therefore there is no changeability in divinity, and this very changing is passing away, surely this passing is from the flesh, not from divinity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Per divinitatem vero ei semper stare est, quia, ubique praesens, nec per motum venit, nec per motum recedit.
chunks.english: But through divinity, to stand is always his, because, being present everywhere, he neither comes by movement nor departs by movement.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ev., homil. 26, n. 2.) Deus Pater omnipotens Filium suum in hunc mundum misit, quia hunc pro redemptione generis humani incarnari instituit.
chunks.english: In his second book of Homilies on the Gospels, Gregory writes: God the Father Almighty sent his Son into this world, because he ordained him to be incarnate for the redemption of the human race.
chunks.notes: Citation to Homilies on the Gospels, book 2, homily 26, paragraph 2

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quem videlicet in mundum venire ad passionem voluit: sed tamen amavit Filium, quem ad passionem misit.
chunks.english: He willed him to come into the world for suffering, yet nevertheless he loved the Son whom he sent to suffering.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Electos vero apostolos Dominus non ad mundi gaudia, sed, sicut ipse est missus, ad passiones in mundum mittit.
chunks.english: But the Lord sends his chosen apostles not to the joys of the world, but, just as he himself was sent, to sufferings in the world.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia ergo et Filius amatur a Patre, et tamen ad passionem mittitur, ita et discipuli amantur a Domino, qui tamen ad passiones mittuntur in mundum.
chunks.english: Because therefore the Son is loved by the Father and yet is sent to suffering, so also the disciples are loved by the Lord, who nevertheless are sent to sufferings in the world.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Omnipotens Dominus, sicut ex nihilo bona facere potuit, ita, cum voluit, per incarnationis suae mysterium etiam perdita bona reparavit.
chunks.english: The Almighty Lord, just as he was able to make good things from nothing, so also, when he willed, through the mystery of his incarnation he restored even the good things that had been lost.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ev., homil. 2, n. 8.) Mediator Dei et hominum Christus Jesus, cum sit Dominus et Creator angelorum, suscepturus naturam nostram, quam condidit, in uterum Virginis venit.
chunks.english: In his first book of Homilies on the Gospels, Gregory writes: Christ Jesus, the Mediator between God and humanity, though he is Lord and Creator of the angels, came into the womb of the Virgin to take upon himself our nature which he had created.
chunks.notes: Citation to Homilies on the Gospels, book 1, homily 2, paragraph 8

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nasci tamen in hoc mundo per divites noluit, parentes pauperes elegit.
chunks.english: Yet he did not wish to be born in this world through the wealthy; he chose poor parents.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde et agnus qui pro illo offerretur defuit, columbarum pullos et par turturum ad sacrificium mater invenit (Luc. II, 24).
chunks.english: Therefore the lamb which would be offered for him was lacking, and his mother found young doves and a pair of turtledoves for the sacrifice, as we read in the Gospel of Luke, chapter two, verse twenty-four.
chunks.notes: Citation to Luke 2:24

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Mediator Dei atque hominum homo Christus Jesus non alter in humanitate, alter in divinitate est.
chunks.english: Christ Jesus, the human mediator between God and humanity, is not one person in his humanity and another in his divinity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Mor. XVIII, c. 52, n. 85.) Non purus homo conceptus atque editus, post meritum ut Deus esset accepit; sed nuntiante angelo, et adveniente Spiritu, mox Verbum in utero, mox intra uterum Verbum caro, et manente incommutabili essentia, quae Christo est cum Patre et cum Spiritu sancto coaeterna, assumpsit intra virginea viscera, ubi et impassibilis pati, et immortalis mori, et aeternus ante saecula temporalis fieri posset in fine saeculorum:
chunks.english: In his eighteenth book of Moralia, Gregory writes: He was not conceived and brought forth as a mere man, receiving divinity afterward as a reward. Rather, when the angel announced and the Spirit came, immediately the Word was in the womb; immediately within the womb the Word became flesh. And while the unchangeable essence remained, which is coeternal with the Father and with the Holy Spirit in Christ, he took upon himself within the virginal womb what would enable the impassible to suffer, the immortal to die, and the eternal one before the ages to become temporal at the end of the ages.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 18, chapter 52, paragraph 85

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: ut per ineffabile sacramentum conceptu sancto et partu inviolabili, secundum veritatem utriusque naturae, eadem Virgo et ancilla Domini esset et mater.
chunks.english: This was so that through an ineffable mystery, by holy conception and inviolate birth, according to the truth of each nature, the same Virgin might be both handmaid of the Lord and mother.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sic quippe Mariae ab Elisabeth dicitur: Unde hoc mihi, ut veniat mater Domini mei ad me (Luc. I, 43)? Et ipsa Virgo concipiens, dicit: Ecce ancilla Domini, fiat mihi secundum verbum tuum (Ibid. 38).
chunks.english: Thus indeed Elizabeth says to Mary: Why is this granted to me, that the mother of my Lord should come to me? As we read in the Gospel of Luke, chapter one, verse forty-three. And the Virgin herself, conceiving, says: Behold the handmaid of the Lord; let it be done to me according to your word, as we read in the same chapter, verse thirty-eight.
chunks.notes: Citations to Luke 1:43 and Luke 1:38

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quamvis Christus aliud ex Patre, aliud ex Virgine, non tamen alius est ex Patre, alius ex Virgine; sed ipse est aeternus ex Patre, ipse temporalis ex matre.
chunks.english: Although Christ is one thing from the Father and another from the Virgin, he is not one person from the Father and another from the Virgin. Rather, he himself is eternal from the Father, he himself is temporal from his mother.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ipse qui fecit, ipse qui factus est. Ipse speciosus forma prae filiis hominum per divinitatem, et ipse de quo dictum est: Vidimus eum, et non erat aspectus, et non est species ei, neque decor (Isai., LIII, 2), per humanitatem.
chunks.english: He himself who made, he himself who was made. He himself is beautiful in form beyond the children of men through divinity, and he himself is the one of whom it was said in the book of Isaiah, chapter fifty-three, verse two: We saw him, and there was no attractiveness, and there is no beauty to him, nor comeliness, through his humanity.
chunks.notes: Citation to Isaiah 53:2

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ipse ante saecula de Patre sine matre; ipse in fine saeculorum de matre sine Patre, Ipse Conditoris templum, ipse Conditor templi. Ipse auctor operis, ipse opus auctoris.
chunks.english: He himself before the ages from the Father without a mother; he himself at the end of the ages from his mother without a father. He himself is the temple of the Creator, he himself is the Creator of the temple. He himself is the author of the work, he himself is the work of the author.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Manens unus ex utraque natura, nec naturarum copulatione confusus, nec naturarum distinctione geminatus.
chunks.english: Remaining one person from both natures, neither confused by the union of the natures nor doubled by the distinction of the natures.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ev., hom. 10, n. 1.) Coeli Rege nato, rex terrae turbatus est; quia nimium terrena altitudo confunditur, cum celsitudo coelestis aperitur.
chunks.english: In his first book of Homilies on the Gospels, Gregory writes: When the King of heaven was born, the king of earth was troubled, because earthly power is greatly confounded when heavenly majesty is revealed.
chunks.notes: Citation to Homilies on the Gospels, book 1, homily 10, paragraph 1

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quaerendum nobis est quidnam sit quod, Redemptore nato, pastoribus in Judaea angelus apparuit, atque ad adorandum hunc ab Oriente Magos non angelus, sed stella perduxit.
chunks.english: We must ask why it is that when the Redeemer was born, an angel appeared to the shepherds in Judea, yet it was not an angel but a star that led the Magi from the East to worship him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia utique, Judaeis tanquam ratione utentibus, rationale animal, id est angelus, praedicare debuit; gentiles vero, quia uti ratione nesciebant, ad cognoscendum Dominum non per vocem, sed per signa ducuntur; cum et illis prophetiae tanquam fidelibus [non infidelibus], et istis signa tanquam infidelibus [non fidelibus] (I Cor. XIV, 22) data sunt.
chunks.english: For indeed, to the Jews as those using reason, a rational being, that is an angel, ought to preach. But the Gentiles, because they did not know how to use reason, are led to know the Lord not by voice but by signs, since to the former prophecies were given as to the faithful, and to the latter signs as to the unfaithful, as we read in Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, chapter fourteen, verse twenty-two.
chunks.notes: Citation to 1 Corinthians 14:22; bracketed editorial corrections noted in source text

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 6.) Nos, qui gremio sanctae Ecclesiae continemur, nato Domino offeramus aurum, ut hunc ubique regnare fateamur; offeramus thus, ut credamus quod is qui in tempore apparuit, Deus ante tempora exstitit; offeramus myrrham, ut eum quem credimus in sua divinitate impassibilem, credamus etiam in nostra carne fuisse mortalem.
chunks.english: We who are held in the bosom of holy Church, when the Lord is born let us offer gold, that we may confess that he reigns everywhere. Let us offer frankincense, that we may believe that he who appeared in time existed as God before all times. Let us offer myrrh, that we may believe that he whom we believe impassible in his divinity was also mortal in our flesh.
chunks.notes: Continues from previous citation context

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nato Regi coelorum aurum offerimus, si in conspectu illius claritate supernae sapientiae resplendemus; thus offerimus, si cogitationes carnis per sancta orationum studia in ara cordis incendimus, ut suave aliquid Deo per coeleste desiderium redolere valeamus; myrrham offerimus, si carnis vitia per abstinentiam mortificamus.
chunks.english: We offer gold to the newborn King of heaven if we shine in his sight with the brightness of heavenly wisdom. We offer frankincense if we kindle the thoughts of the flesh through holy practices of prayer on the altar of the heart, so that we may be able to give off something sweet to God through heavenly desire. We offer myrrh if we mortify the vices of the flesh through abstinence.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Preaching Ministry of Christ
chunks.latin: CAPUT II. De praedicatione Christi.
chunks.english: Chapter Two: The Preaching Ministry of Christ.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ezech., homil. 9, n. 19.) Si virtutes suas omnipotens Deus taceret, eum nullus agnosceret, nullus amaret.
chunks.english: In his first book of Homilies on Ezekiel, Gregory writes: If Almighty God were silent about his mighty works, no one would know him, no one would love him.
chunks.notes: Citation to Homilies on Ezekiel, book 1, homily 9, paragraph 19

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Virtutes ergo suas annuntiat, non ut laudibus suis ipse proficiat, sed ut hi qui hunc ex sua laude cognoverint, ad perpetuam haereditatem perveniant.
chunks.english: Therefore he announces his mighty works, not that he himself might profit from his own praises, but that those who come to know him through his praise might arrive at the eternal inheritance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XVIII, c. 7, n. 14.) Idcirco Deus laudes suas indicat, ut valeamus eum audientes cognoscere, cognoscentes amare, amantes sequi, sequentes adipisci, adipiscentes vero ejus visione perfrui.
chunks.english: In his eighteenth book of Moralia, Gregory writes: For this reason God declares his praises, that hearing them we may be able to know him, knowing him to love him, loving him to follow him, following him to attain him, and attaining him to enjoy the vision of him.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 18, chapter 7, paragraph 14

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Virtutem, inquit Propheta, operum suorum Dominus annuntiavit populo suo, ut det illis haereditatem gentium (Psalm. CX, 6).
chunks.english: The prophet says: The Lord has announced the power of his works to his people, that he may give them the inheritance of the nations, as we read in Psalm one hundred ten, verse six.
chunks.notes: Citation to Psalm 110:6

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ac si aperte dicat: Idcirco fortitudinem suae operationis insinuat, ut eam qui audierit donis ditescat.
chunks.english: As if he were saying openly: For this reason he makes known the strength of his working, that whoever hears it may be enriched with gifts.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Evang., homil. 19, n. 5.) David propheta ait: Annuntiavi et locutus sum, multiplicati sunt super numerum (Psalm. XXXIX, 6).
chunks.english: In his first book of Homilies on the Gospels, Gregory writes: The prophet David says: I have announced and spoken, they are multiplied beyond number, as we read in Psalm thirty-nine, verse six.
chunks.notes: Citation to Homilies on the Gospels, book 1, homily 19, paragraph 5 and Psalm 39:6

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Annuntiante Domino, super numerum multiplicantur fideles, quia nonnunquam etiam hi ad fidem veniunt qui ad electorum numerum non pertingent.
chunks.english: When the Lord announces, the faithful are multiplied beyond number, because sometimes even those come to faith who will not reach the number of the elect.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hic enim fidelibus per confessionem admixti sunt, sed propter vitam reprobam illic numerari in sorte fidelium non merentur.
chunks.english: For here they are mingled with the faithful through confession, but because of their reprobate life they do not deserve to be numbered there in the lot of the faithful.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXV, c. 8, n. 21.) Propheta intuens tantos, vocante et annuntiante Domino, specietenus credere, quantos nimirum certum est electorum numerum summamque transire, ait: Multiplicati sunt super numerum (Psalm. XXXIX, 6).
chunks.english: In his twenty-fifth book of Moralia, Gregory writes: The prophet, seeing so many believe outwardly when the Lord calls and announces, so many indeed that they certainly exceed the number and total of the elect, says: They are multiplied beyond number, as we read in Psalm thirty-nine, verse six.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 25, chapter 8, paragraph 21 and Psalm 39:6

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ac si diceret: Multis Ecclesiam intrantibus, etiam hi ad fidem specietenus veniunt qui a numero regni coelestis excluduntur, quia electorum summam, sua videlicet multiplicitate, transcendunt.
chunks.english: As if he were saying: With many entering the Church, even those come to faith outwardly who are excluded from the number of the heavenly kingdom, because by their sheer multiplicity they exceed the total of the elect.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Calling of the Apostles
chunks.latin: CAPUT III. De apostolorum vocatione.
chunks.english: Chapter Three: The Calling of the Apostles.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXXV, c. 8, n. 15.) Sancti apostoli gratia septiformis Spiritus implendi, vocante Christo, duodecim sunt electi.
chunks.english: In his thirty-fifth book of Moralia, Gregory writes: The holy apostles, when called by Christ and about to be filled with the grace of the sevenfold Spirit, were chosen as twelve.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 35, chapter 8, paragraph 15

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In quatuor enim mundi partibus Trinitatem, quae Deus est, innotescere mittebantur. Duodecim ergo electi sunt, ut etiam ex ipsius numeri ratione causa claresceret quod per quatuor infima tria summa praedicarent.
chunks.english: For they were being sent to make known the Trinity, who is God, in the four parts of the world. Therefore twelve were chosen, so that even from the logic of the number itself it might become clear that through the four lowest regions they would preach the three highest realities.
chunks.notes: Explanation of symbolic numerology: 4 x 3 = 12

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ev., homil. 5, n. 1.) Ad unius jussionis vocem Petrus et Andreas, relictis retibus, secuti sunt Redemptorem. Nulla hunc facere adhuc miracula viderant; nihil ab eo de praemio aeternae retributionis audierant; et tamen ad unum Domini praeceptum hoc quod possidere videbantur obliti sunt.
chunks.english: In his first book of Homilies on the Gospels, Gregory writes: At the voice of a single command, Peter and Andrew, leaving their nets, followed the Redeemer. They had not yet seen him perform any miracles. They had heard nothing from him about the reward of eternal recompense. And yet at one precept of the Lord they forgot what they seemed to possess.
chunks.notes: Citation to Homilies on the Gospels, book 1, homily 5, paragraph 1

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 21.) Negotiatores nostri sancti apostoli perpetuam angelorum vitam, datis retibus et navi, mercati sunt. Aestimationem quippe pretii non habet regnum Dei, sed tamen tantum valet quantum habes.
chunks.english: Our merchants, the holy apostles, purchased the perpetual life of the angels by giving their nets and boat. For indeed the kingdom of God has no fixed price, but it is nevertheless worth as much as you have.
chunks.notes: Continues from previous citation context, paragraph 21

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 4.) Sancti apostoli per Mediatorem Dei atque hominum vocati, studuerunt in hoc saeculo nil amare, nil unquam appetere.
chunks.english: The holy apostles, called through the Mediator between God and humanity, strove in this age to love nothing, to desire nothing.
chunks.notes: Continues from citation context, paragraph 4

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quos bene Isaias intuens: Qui sunt isti, ait, qui ut nubes volant, et quasi columbae ad fenestras suas (Isai. LX, 8)?
chunks.english: Isaiah, looking upon them well, says: Who are these who fly like clouds, and like doves to their windows? As we read in the book of Isaiah, chapter sixty, verse eight.
chunks.notes: Citation to Isaiah 60:8

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Vidit quippe eos terrena despicere, mente coelestibus propinquare, verbis pluere, miraculis coruscare. Et quos a terrenis contagiis et sancta praedicatio et sublimis vita suspenderat, hos volantes columbas pariter et nubes appellat.
chunks.english: For he saw them despise earthly things, draw near to heavenly things in their minds, rain down in words, flash with miracles. And those whom both holy preaching and sublime life had lifted from earthly contaminations, these he calls both flying doves and clouds together.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quasi columbae ergo ad fenestras suas sunt electi, qui nihil in hoc mundo concupiscunt, qui omnia simpliciter aspiciunt, et in his quae vident rapacitatis studio non trahuntur.
chunks.english: The elect are therefore like doves at their windows, who desire nothing in this world, who look upon all things simply, and are not drawn by the desire for plunder in the things they see.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scriptum quippe est: Verbo Domini coeli firmati sunt, et spiritu oris ejus omnis virtus eorum (Psalm. XXXII, 6).
chunks.english: For it is written: By the word of the Lord the heavens were established, and by the spirit of his mouth all their power, as we read in Psalm thirty-two, verse six.
chunks.notes: Citation to Psalm 32:6

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Evang., homil. 30, n. 7.) Verbum enim Domini Filius est Patris: coelorum igitur virtus de spiritu sumpta est, quia mundi hujus potestatibus apostoli contraire non praesumerent, nisi eos sancti Spiritus fortitudo solidasset.
chunks.english: In his second book of Homilies on the Gospels, Gregory writes: For the Word of the Lord is the Son of the Father. Therefore the power of the heavens was received from the Spirit, because the apostles would not presume to stand against the powers of this world unless the strength of the Holy Spirit had fortified them.
chunks.notes: Citation to Homilies on the Gospels, book 2, homily 30, paragraph 7

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Jewish Unbelief and Violence Toward Christ
chunks.latin: CAPUT IV. De incredulitate vel saevitia Judaeorum erga Christum.
chunks.english: Chapter Four: Jewish Unbelief and Violence Toward Christ.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXXV, c. 14, n. 26.) Isaac caligantibus oculis Judaeos significat perfidia cordis sui caecatos, quorum et notitia prior et ignorantia posterior bene ac breviter designatur (Gen. XXVII).
chunks.english: In his thirty-fifth book of Moralia, Gregory writes: Isaac with his clouded eyes signifies the Jews blinded by the treachery of their hearts, whose earlier knowledge and later ignorance are well and briefly indicated in the book of Genesis, chapter twenty-seven.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 35, chapter 14, paragraph 26 and Genesis 27

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui dum Jacob benediceret, et quid ei eveniret in futuro videbat, et quis illi praesens assisteret, nesciebat.
chunks.english: For while he was blessing Jacob, he saw what would happen to him in the future, yet did not know who was present assisting him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Israelitarum populus prophetiae mysteria accepit, sed tamen caecos oculos in contemplatione tenuit, quia eum praesentem non vidit de quo tam multa in futuro praevidit.
chunks.english: The people of Israel received the mysteries of prophecy, yet nevertheless held blind eyes in contemplation, because they did not see him present concerning whom they foresaw so much in the future.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ante se enim positum nequaquam cernere valuit, cujus adventus potentiam longe ante nuntiavit.
chunks.english: For they could in no way perceive the one placed before them, whose powerful coming they announced long before.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ev., homil. 10, n. 2.) In omnibus signis quae nascente Domino, vel moriente, monstrata sunt, considerandum nobis est quanta fuerit in quorumdam Judaeorum corde duritia, quae hunc nec per prophetiae donum, nec per miracula agnovit.
chunks.english: In his first book of Homilies on the Gospels, Gregory writes: In all the signs that were shown when the Lord was born or dying, we must consider how great was the hardness in the hearts of certain Jews, which recognized him neither through the gift of prophecy nor through miracles.
chunks.notes: Citation to Homilies on the Gospels, book 1, homily 10, paragraph 2

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Omnia elementa auctorem suum venisse testata sunt. Ut enim de eis quaedam usu humano loquar, Deum hunc coeli esse cognoverunt, quia protinus stellam miserunt. Mare cognovit, quia sub plantis ejus se calcabile praebuit. Terra cognovit, quia eo moriente contremuit. Sol cognovit, quia lucis suae radios abscondit. Saxa et parietes cognoverunt, quia tempore mortis ejus scissa sunt. Infernus agnovit, quia hos quos tenebat mortuos reddidit.
chunks.english: All the elements testified that their creator had come. For to speak of them in human terms: the heavens knew him to be God, because they immediately sent forth a star. The sea knew him, because it presented itself as walkable under his feet. The earth knew him, because it trembled when he was dying. The sun knew him, because it hid the rays of its light. The rocks and walls knew him, because they were split at the time of his death. Hell acknowledged him, because it gave back the dead whom it had been holding.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et tamen hunc, quem Dominum omnia insensibilia elementa senserunt, adhuc infidelium Judaeorum corda Deum esse minime cognoscunt, et duriora saxis, scindi ad poenitendum nolunt; eumque confiteri abnegant quem elementa, ut diximus, aut signis, aut scissionibus Deum clamabant.
chunks.english: And yet the hearts of unbelieving Jews still do not at all recognize as God the one whom all insensible elements perceived as Lord. Harder than rocks, they refuse to be split open to repentance, and they refuse to confess the one whom the elements, as we have said, proclaimed as God either by signs or by being split.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nonnulli Judaeorum, ad damnationis suae cumulum, eum, quem natum despiciunt, nasciturum longe ante praescierunt. Et non solum quia nasceretur noverant, sed etiam ubi nasceretur.
chunks.english: Some of the Jews, to the increase of their condemnation, foreknew long before that he would be born, this one whom they despise once born. And they knew not only that he would be born, but also where he would be born.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam ab Herode requisiti, locum nativitatis ejus exprimunt, quem de Scripturae auctoritate didicerunt.
chunks.english: For when questioned by Herod, they specify the place of his birth, which they had learned from the authority of Scripture.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et testimonium proferunt quod Bethlehem honorari nativitate novi Ducis ostenditur, ut ipsa eorum scientia et illis fieret testimonium damnationis, et nobis adjutorium credulitatis.
chunks.english: And they bring forward testimony that Bethlehem is shown to be honored by the birth of a new Leader, so that their very knowledge might become for them a testimony of damnation and for us an aid to belief.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Judaicum populum bene Isaac, cum Jacob filium suum benediceret, designavit, quia caligantibus oculis et prophetans in praesenti filium non vidit, cui tam multa in posterum praevidit; quia nimirum Judaicus populus prophetiae spiritu plenus, et caecus, eum de quo multa in futuro praedixit in praesenti positum non agnovit.
chunks.english: Isaac well represented the Jewish people when he blessed his son Jacob, because with clouded eyes and prophesying, he did not see in the present the son for whom he foresaw so much in the future. For indeed the Jewish people, full of the spirit of prophecy yet blind, did not recognize when present the one about whom they predicted much in the future.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXIX, c. 26, n. 52.) Timuerunt Judaei ne locum atque gentem, non occiso Domino, perderent. Sed cur ista miseris evenerunt? quia eorum cordibus defuit aeternitatis scientia, et nullo eos refecit pabulo viriditatis internae doctrina.
chunks.english: In his twenty-ninth book of Moralia, Gregory writes: The Jews feared that if they did not kill the Lord, they would lose both their place and their nation. But why did these things happen to these wretched people? Because knowledge of eternity was lacking in their hearts, and doctrine refreshed them with no food of internal vitality.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 29, chapter 26, paragraph 52

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XVIII, c. 32, n. 51.) Synagoga, quae mandata Dei per Legem protulit, nascentem Ecclesiam persequens, invidiae sese igne consumpsit.
chunks.english: In his eighteenth book of Moralia, Gregory writes: The Synagogue, which brought forth the commandments of God through the Law, persecuting the nascent Church, consumed itself in the fire of envy.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 18, chapter 32, paragraph 51

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: An non aemulationis suae facibus ardebat, cum Redemptoris nostri signa conspiciens, per quosdam suos diceret: Quid facimus, quia hic homo multa signa facit (Joan. XI, 47)?
chunks.english: Was it not burning with the torches of its own jealousy when, seeing the signs of our Redeemer, it said through some of its members: What are we doing, because this man performs many signs? As we read in the Gospel of John, chapter eleven, verse forty-seven.
chunks.notes: Citation to John 11:47

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Vel certe: Videtis quia nihil proficimus. Ecce totus mundus post eum vadit.
chunks.english: Or indeed: You see that we are accomplishing nothing. Behold, the whole world is going after him.
chunks.notes: Continues reference to John 11/12 context

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Videbant Judaei unde converti debuerant, atque exinde perversiores fiebant. Quaerebant exstinguere quem cernebant mortuos vivificare. In ore tenebant Legem, sed Legis persequebantur auctorem.
chunks.english: The Jews saw that by which they ought to have been converted, and from that very thing they became more perverse. They sought to extinguish the one whom they saw bringing the dead to life. They held the Law in their mouths, but they persecuted the author of the Law.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XVII, c. 33, n. 54.) Redemptor noster, priusquam se a Judaeis teneri permitteret, persecutores suos requisivit, dicens: Quem quaeritis? Cui illico responderunt: Jesum Nazarenum (Joan. XVIII, 4).
chunks.english: In his seventeenth book of Moralia, Gregory writes: Our Redeemer, before he allowed himself to be seized by the Jews, sought out his persecutors, saying: Whom do you seek? To whom they immediately responded: Jesus of Nazareth, as we read in the Gospel of John, chapter eighteen, verse four.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 17, chapter 33, paragraph 54 and John 18:4

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quibus cum repente diceret: Ego sum, vocem solummodo mitissimae responsionis edidit, et armatos persecutores suos protinus in terram stravit.
chunks.english: When he suddenly said to them: I am he, he uttered only the voice of a most gentle response, and immediately laid his armed persecutors flat on the ground.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid ergo facturus est, cum judicaturus venerit, qui una voce hostes suos perculit, etiam cum judicandus venit? Quod est illud judicium quod immortalis exerit, qui in una voce non potuit ferri moriturus? Aut quis ejus iram toleret, cujus et ipsa non potuit mansuetudo tolerari?
chunks.english: What therefore will he do when he comes to judge, he who struck down his enemies with one word even when he came to be judged? What is that judgment which the immortal one will exercise, who could not be endured in one word when about to die? Or who will tolerate his anger, whose very gentleness could not be tolerated?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. II, c. 2, n. 2.) De negaturo Petro praemittitur: Quia frigus erat, et stans ad prunas calefaciebat se (Joan. XVIII, 18).
chunks.english: In his second book of Moralia, Gregory writes: Concerning Peter who was about to deny, it is mentioned beforehand: Because it was cold, and standing at the fire he was warming himself, as we read in the Gospel of John, chapter eighteen, verse eighteen.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 2, chapter 2, paragraph 2 and John 18:18

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Jam Petrus intus a charitatis calore torpuerat, et ad amorem praesentis saeculi, quasi ad persecutorum prunas desiderio aestuante se calescebat.
chunks.english: Already Peter had grown cold within from the warmth of charity, and toward the love of the present age, as if toward the fires of persecutors, he was warming himself with burning desire.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Praefat. l. IV Moral., c. 4.) Gelboe montes superba Judaeorum corda significant, quae dum in hujus mundi desideriis defluunt, in Christi, id est uncti, se morte miscuerunt.
chunks.english: In his preface to the fourth book of Moralia, Gregory writes: The mountains of Gilboa signify the proud hearts of the Jews, who, while flowing down into the desires of this world, involved themselves in the death of Christ, that is, the Anointed One.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, preface to book 4, chapter 4

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et quia in eis unctus Rex corporaliter moritur, ipsi ab omni gratiae rore siccantur. Hebraeorum superbae mentes primitivos fructus non ferunt, quia in Redemptoris adventu ex parte maxima in perfidia remanentes, primordia fidei sequi noluerunt.
chunks.english: And because the anointed King dies bodily among them, they themselves are dried up from all dew of grace. The proud minds of the Hebrews do not bear first fruits, because at the Redeemer's coming, remaining for the most part in treachery, they refused to follow the beginnings of faith.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XXVII, c. 26, n. 49.) Judaeorum persequentium corda, nunquid antrum diaboli non fuerunt? In quorum diu consiliis latuit, sed repente vocibus erupit clamantium: Crucifige, crucifige (Joan. XIX, 6).
chunks.english: In his twenty-seventh book of Moralia, Gregory writes: Were not the hearts of the persecuting Jews the cavern of the devil? In their counsels he lay hidden for a long time, but suddenly burst forth in the voices of those shouting: Crucify him, crucify him, as we read in the Gospel of John, chapter nineteen, verse six.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 27, chapter 26, paragraph 49 and John 19:6

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et quia ad lacerationem mentis pertingere tentando non potuit, in Redemptore nostro ad mortem carnis anhelavit.
chunks.english: And because by tempting he could not reach the tearing apart of the mind, he panted for the death of the flesh in our Redeemer.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Suffering and Death of Jesus Christ
chunks.latin: CAPUT V. De passione et morte Jesu Christi.
chunks.english: Chapter Five: The Suffering and Death of Jesus Christ.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XII, c. 12, n. 16.) Passioni Dominus appropinquans, infirmantium in se vocem sumpsit, eorumque timorem ut abstraheret suscepit, dicens: Pater mi, si possibile est, transeat a me calix iste (Matth. XXVI, 39).
chunks.english: In his twelfth book of Moralia, Gregory writes: As the Lord approached his passion, he took upon himself the voice of those weakening in themselves, and he took up their fear in order to remove it, saying: My Father, if it is possible, let this cup pass from me, as we read in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-six, verse thirty-nine.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 12, chapter 12, paragraph 16 and Matthew 26:39

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et rursum per obedientiam vim fortitudinis ostendens, ait: Verumtamen non sicut ego volo, sed sicut tu.
chunks.english: And again, showing the force of strength through obedience, he says: Nevertheless, not as I will, but as you will.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ut cum hoc imminet quod fieri nolumus, sic per infirmitatem petamus ut non fiat, quatenus per fortitudinem parati simus ut voluntas Conditoris nostri etiam contra nostram voluntatem fiat.
chunks.english: So that when something is imminent which we do not wish to happen, we may in weakness ask that it not happen, in order that through strength we may be prepared for the will of our Creator to be done even against our will.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. II, c. 38, n. 62.) Redemptor noster interrogatus passionis tempore, Dei se Filium testatur. Unde et conquirentes dicunt: Quid adhuc egemus testibus? ecce ipsi audivimus blasphemias (Matth. XXVI, 65).
chunks.english: In his second book of Moralia, Gregory writes: Our Redeemer, when questioned at the time of his passion, testified that he is the Son of God. Hence those seeking to condemn him say: What further need do we have of witnesses? Behold, we ourselves have heard his blasphemy, as we read in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-six, verse sixty-five.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 2, chapter 38, paragraph 62 and Matthew 26:65

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed contra Deum stulte nil dixit, quia vera loquens, hoc de se infidelibus etiam moriendo intulit quod paulo post Redemptor omnibus resurgendo monstravit.
chunks.english: But he said nothing foolishly against God, because speaking the truth, he brought upon himself from unbelievers even by dying what the Redeemer shortly afterward showed to all by rising.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXXIII, c. 15, n. 31.) Diabolus confessus fuerat Filium Dei (Matth. VIII, 29), sed tamen purum illum hominem mori credidit ad cujus mortem Judaeorum persequentium animas concitavit.
chunks.english: In his thirty-third book of Moralia, Gregory writes: The devil had confessed the Son of God, as we read in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter eight, verse twenty-nine, but nevertheless he believed that a mere man was dying, and he stirred up the souls of persecuting Jews to his death.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 33, chapter 15, paragraph 31 and Matthew 8:29

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed in ipso traditionis tempore tarde jam cognovisse intelligitur, quod illa ejus morte puniretur. Unde et Pilati conjugem somniis terruit, ut vir illius a Justi persecutione cessaret.
chunks.english: But at the very time of the betrayal he is understood to have realized too late that he would be punished by that death. Therefore he also terrified Pilate's wife with dreams, so that her husband might cease from the persecution of the Just One.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed res interna dispensatione disposita nulla valuit machinatione refragari. Expediebat valde ut peccatorum mortem juste morientium solveret mors justi injuste morientis.
chunks.english: But what had been arranged by internal dispensation could not be opposed by any stratagem. It was very fitting that the death of the just one dying unjustly should release the death of sinners dying justly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod quia diabolus usque ad tempus passionis illius ignoravit, quasi more avis illusus, divinitatis ejus laqueum pertulit, dum humanitatis ejus escam momordit.
chunks.english: Because the devil was ignorant of this until the time of his passion, deceived like a bird, he endured the snare of his divinity while he bit at the bait of his humanity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Evang. homil. 21, n. 7.) Si passionis tempore Christus de cruce descenderet, nimirum insultantibus cedens, virtutem nobis patientiae non demonstraret.
chunks.english: In his second book of Homilies on the Gospels, Gregory writes: If at the time of his passion Christ had descended from the cross, certainly yielding to those mocking him, he would not have demonstrated to us the virtue of patience.
chunks.notes: Citation to Homilies on the Gospels, book 2, homily 21, paragraph 7

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed exspectavit paululum, toleravit probra, irrisiones sustinuit, servavit patientiam, distulit admirationem; et qui de cruce descendere noluit (Matth. XXVII, 42), de sepulcro surrexit.
chunks.english: But he waited a little while, endured reproaches, sustained mockeries, preserved patience, postponed wonder. And he who refused to descend from the cross, as we read in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-seven, verse forty-two, rose from the tomb.
chunks.notes: Citation to Matthew 27:42

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plus igitur est de sepulcro resurgere quam de cruce descendere. Plus fuit mortem resurgendo destruere quam vitam descendendo servare.
chunks.english: Therefore it is more to rise from the tomb than to descend from the cross. It was more to destroy death by rising than to preserve life by descending.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum Judaei Christum ad insultationes suas de cruce descendere minime cernerent, eum se vicisse crediderunt: nomen illius se quasi exstinxisse gavisi sunt.
chunks.english: When the Jews saw Christ in no way descending from the cross at their taunts, they believed they had conquered him. They rejoiced that they had apparently extinguished his name.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed ecce de morte nomen ejus per mundum crevit, ex qua hoc infidelis turba se exstinxisse credidit; et quae gaudebat occisum, dolet mortuum, quia hunc ad gloriam suam cognoscit pervenisse per poenam.
chunks.english: But behold, his name grew throughout the world from that death by which this unbelieving crowd believed they had extinguished it. And those who rejoiced that he was killed grieve that he died, because they recognize that he came to his glory through punishment.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XIV, c. 49, n. 57.) Cum ad crucis horam ventum esset, Domini discipulos gravis ex persecutione Judaeorum timor invasit: fugerunt singuli, mulieres astiterunt, de quibus figuraliter recte beatus Job ait: Et consumptis carnibus, remanserunt tantummodo labia circa dentes meos (Job XIX, 20).
chunks.english: In his fourteenth book of Moralia, Gregory writes: When the hour of the cross had come, a heavy fear from the persecution of the Jews invaded the Lord's disciples. They fled individually, but women stood by, concerning whom blessed Job rightly says figuratively: And when the flesh was consumed, only the lips remained around my teeth, as we read in the book of Job, chapter nineteen, verse twenty.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 14, chapter 49, paragraph 57 and Job 19:20

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quasi ergo consummata carne, os Domini pelli suae adhaesit, quia fortitudo ejus, passionis tempore fugientibus discipulis, juxta se mulieres invenit.
chunks.english: Therefore, as if when the flesh was consumed, the mouth of the Lord clung to his skin, because his strength, at the time of the passion when the disciples were fleeing, found women near him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Stetit equidem aliquandiu Petrus in Domini passione, sed tamen post territus negavit (Matth. XXVI, 70). Stetit etiam Joannes, cui ipso crucis tempore dictum est: Ecce mater tua (Joan. XIX, 27). Sed perseverare minime potuit, quia de ipso quoque scriptum est: quod adolescens quidam sequebatur illum amictus sindone super nudo, et tenuerunt eum: at ille, rejecta sindone, nudus profugit ab eis (Marc. XIV, 51).
chunks.english: Indeed Peter stood for some time during the Lord's passion, but afterward, terrified, he denied him, as we read in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-six, verse seventy. John also stood, to whom at the very time of the cross it was said: Behold your mother, as we read in the Gospel of John, chapter nineteen, verse twenty-seven. But he could not persevere, because it is also written of him that a certain young man followed him clothed in a linen cloth over his naked body, and they seized him. But he, throwing off the linen cloth, fled naked from them, as we read in the Gospel of Mark, chapter fourteen, verse fifty-one.
chunks.notes: Citations to Matthew 26:70, John 19:27, and Mark 14:51; note textual uncertainty about whether Mark passage refers to John

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Lib. I in Ezech., homil. 8, n. 24.] Qui etsi post, ut verba sui Redemptoris audiret, ad horam crucis rediit, prius tamen territus fugit.
chunks.english: As Gregory writes in his first book of Homilies on Ezekiel: Though he afterward returned to the hour of the cross to hear the words of his Redeemer, nevertheless he first fled in terror.
chunks.notes: Citation to Homilies on Ezekiel, book 1, homily 8, paragraph 24

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Mulieres autem non solum non timuisse, neque fugisse, sed etiam usque ad sepulcrum stetisse memorantur.
chunks.english: But the women are remembered not only as not having feared nor fled, but even as having stood by all the way to the tomb.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: De Domino Jesu Christo ante passionem scriptum est: Ecce angeli accesserunt, et ministrabant ei (Matth. IV, 11). Sed tamen dum passioni propinquaret, ut humanitatis ejus infirmitas monstraretur, rursum scriptum est de eo: Apparuit illi angelus de coelo confortans eum (Luc. XXII, 43).
chunks.english: Concerning the Lord Jesus Christ before his passion it is written: Behold, angels came and ministered to him, as we read in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter four, verse eleven. But nevertheless, as he drew near to the passion, that the weakness of his humanity might be shown, it is written again of him: An angel appeared to him from heaven strengthening him, as we read in the Gospel of Luke, chapter twenty-two, verse forty-three.
chunks.notes: Citations to Matthew 4:11 and Luke 22:43

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In documento ergo utriusque naturae huic et angeli ministrare, hunc et angelus confortare describitur. Unus in utraque natura; quoniam qui Deus ante saecula exstitit, homo factus est in fine saeculorum.
chunks.english: Therefore as evidence of both natures it is described that angels minister to him and that an angel strengthens him. One person in both natures, for he who existed as God before the ages became man at the end of the ages.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cui ante passionem suam et angeli ministrant, et hunc angelus confortat. Post passionem vero atque resurrectionem ejus, huic angeli ministrare possunt, sed jam hunc confortare non possunt.
chunks.english: Before his passion, angels minister to him and an angel strengthens him. But after his passion and resurrection, angels can minister to him, but can no longer strengthen him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XVIII, c. 40, n. 64.) Libet inter haec mentis oculos ad illum latronem ducere, qui de fauce diaboli ascendit crucem, de cruce paradisum.
chunks.english: In his eighteenth book of Moralia, Gregory writes: Among these things it is pleasing to direct the eyes of the mind to that thief who ascended from the jaws of the devil to the cross, from the cross to paradise.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 18, chapter 40, paragraph 64

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Intueamur qualis ad patibulum venerit, et qualis a patibulo abscessit. Venit reus fraterno sanguine, venit cruentus, sed interna gratia est mutatus in cruce.
chunks.english: Let us contemplate what sort of person came to the gibbet, and what sort departed from the gibbet. He came guilty of fraternal blood, he came bloodstained, but he was changed on the cross by internal grace.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et ille qui mortem fratri intulit, morientis Domini vitam praedicavit, dicens: Memento mei, Domine, dum veneris in regnum tuum (Luc. XXIII, 42).
chunks.english: And he who brought death to his brother proclaimed the life of the dying Lord, saying: Remember me, Lord, when you come into your kingdom, as we read in the Gospel of Luke, chapter twenty-three, verse forty-two.
chunks.notes: Citation to Luke 23:42

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hujus latronis in cruce clavi manus pedesque ligaverunt, nihilque in eo a poenis liberum, nisi cor et lingua, remanserat. Inspirante Deo totum illi obtulit quod in se liberum invenit, ut juxta hoc quod scriptum est, corde crederet ad justitiam, ore confiteretur ad salutem (Rom. X, 10).
chunks.english: Of this thief on the cross, nails bound his hands and feet, and nothing remained free from punishment except his heart and tongue. At God's inspiration he offered all that he found free in himself, so that according to what is written, he believed with the heart unto righteousness and confessed with the mouth unto salvation, as we read in Paul's letter to the Romans, chapter ten, verse ten.
chunks.notes: Citation to Romans 10:10

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Confitebatur Deum latro quem videbat secum humana infirmitate morientem, quando negabant apostoli eum quem miracula viderant divina virtute facientem.
chunks.english: The thief confessed as God the one whom he saw dying with him in human weakness, when the apostles were denying the one whom they had seen performing miracles by divine power.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 65.) Sed hi qui salvari hominem propriis viribus astruunt, eamdem confessionem hominis ab ipsius esse virtute hominis suspicantur. Quod si ita esset, in Dei laude Psalmista non diceret: Confessio et magnificentia opus ejus (Ps. CX, 3).
chunks.english: But those who assert that a person is saved by his own powers suspect that this same confession of the man comes from the man's own strength. If this were so, the Psalmist would not say in praise of God: Confession and magnificence are his work, as we read in Psalm one hundred ten, verse three.
chunks.notes: Citation to Psalm 110:3; continues from previous paragraph in source

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ab eo itaque accipimus recta confiteri a quo nobis et magna dantur operari.
chunks.english: Therefore we receive the ability to confess rightly from the one from whom great works are also given to us to perform.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXIX, 14, n. 26.) Dum Jesus angustias mortis petiit, fidem suam in gentibus dilatavit, atque ad innumera corda credentium sanctam Ecclesiam tetendit, cui per prophetam dicitur: Dilata locum tentorii tui, et pelles tabernaculorum tuorum extende, ne parcas, longos fac funiculos tuos, et clavos tuos consolida. Ad dexteram enim et ad laevam penetrabis, et semen tuum gentes haereditabit (Isai. LIV, 2).
chunks.english: In his twenty-ninth book of Moralia, Gregory writes: While Jesus sought the straits of death, he spread his faith among the nations, and extended the holy Church to the innumerable hearts of believers, to whom it is said through the prophet: Enlarge the place of your tent, and stretch out the skins of your tabernacles, do not spare, make your cords long and strengthen your stakes. For you will penetrate to the right and to the left, and your seed will inherit the nations, as we read in the book of Isaiah, chapter fifty-four, verse two.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 29, chapter 14, paragraph 26 and Isaiah 54:2

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae latitudo terrae profecto non fieret, nisi ipse prius et vitam quam novimus moriendo despiceret, et vitam quam non novimus resurgendo monstraret.
chunks.english: This breadth of the earth would surely not happen unless he first despised by dying the life we know, and showed by rising the life we do not know.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Redemptor noster in morte sua nostrae oculos mentis aperuit, et quae esset vita quae sequeretur ostendit. Unde et hunc in Evangelio ordinem tenens, discipulis dicit: Sic oportebat Christum pati, et resurgere a mortuis die tertia, et praedicari in nomine ejus poenitentiam et remissionem peccatorum per omnes gentes (Luc. XXIV, 46).
chunks.english: Our Redeemer in his death opened the eyes of our mind, and showed what the life would be that follows. Therefore keeping this order in the Gospel, he says to his disciples: Thus it was necessary for Christ to suffer, and to rise from the dead on the third day, and for repentance and forgiveness of sins to be preached in his name through all nations, as we read in the Gospel of Luke, chapter twenty-four, verse forty-six.
chunks.notes: Citation to Luke 24:46

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Redemptor noster, ut nos a morte redimeret, ad mortem venit, et defectum nostrae carnis in suo corpore poenasque toleravit; qui prius quam ad crucis patibulum perveniret, teneri, conspui, illudi, alapis caedi se pertulit. Ecce ad quanta propter nos venire probra consensit!
chunks.english: Our Redeemer, to redeem us from death, came to death, and endured the weakness of our flesh and its punishments in his own body. Before he came to the gibbet of the cross, he endured being seized, spat upon, mocked, and struck with blows. Behold to what great reproaches he consented to come for our sake!

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. III, c. 16, n. 29.) Cum se pro nostra redemptione Dominus membrorum Satanae manibus tradidit, quid aliud quam ejusdem Satanae manus in se saevire permisit, ut unde ipse exterius occumberet, inde nos exterius interiusque liberaret?
chunks.english: In his third book of Moralia, Gregory writes: When the Lord handed himself over to the hands of Satan's members for our redemption, what else did he do but allow Satan's own hands to rage against him, so that from where he himself fell externally, from there he might free us both externally and internally?
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 3, chapter 16, paragraph 29

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si Satanae manus ejus potestas accipitur, ejus manus Redemptor noster juxta carnem pertulit, cujus potestatem corporis usque ad sputa, colaphos, flagella, crucem lanceamque toleravit.
chunks.english: If Satan's hand is understood as his power, our Redeemer endured his hand according to the flesh, whose power against his body he tolerated even to spittle, blows, scourges, cross, and lance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde et Pilato, ejus videlicet corpori, ad passionem veniens dicit: Non haberes in me potestatem, nisi tibi esset data desuper (Joan. XIX, 11).
chunks.english: Hence coming to his passion he says to Pilate, regarding his body: You would have no power over me unless it had been given to you from above, as we read in the Gospel of John, chapter nineteen, verse eleven.
chunks.notes: Citation to John 19:11

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed tamen hanc potestatem, quam contra se ei extrinsecus dederat, suis servire lucris intrinsecus compellebat. Pilatus scilicet vel Satan, qui ejus Pilati caput exstiterat, sub potestate illius super quem potestatem acceperat tenebatur.
chunks.english: But nevertheless this power, which he had given externally against himself, he compelled internally to serve his own benefits. For Pilate, or Satan who had been Pilate's head, was held under the power of the one over whom he had received power.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia et superior ipse Redemptor noster disposuerat hoc [quod] inferius accidens [Edit., accedens] a persecutore tolerabat; ut cum ex mala mente infidelium surgeret, utilitati tamen electorum omnium ipsa quoque crudelitas deserviret.
chunks.english: Because the superior one, our Redeemer himself, had arranged what he was enduring below as it befell him from his persecutor, so that though it arose from the evil mind of unbelievers, nevertheless even that very cruelty might serve the benefit of all the elect.
chunks.notes: Text includes editorial notation about variant readings

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Pie igitur disponebat intus quod semetipsum pati nequiter permittebat foris.
chunks.english: Therefore he mercifully arranged internally what he wickedly allowed himself to suffer externally.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Evang., homil. 2, n. 1.) Redemptor noster, praevidens ex passione sua discipulorum animos perturbandos, eis longe ante et ejusdem passionis poenam et resurrectionis suae gloriam praedicit, ut cum morientem, sicut praedictum est, cernerent, etiam resurrecturum non dubitarent.
chunks.english: In his first book of Homilies on the Gospels, Gregory writes: Our Redeemer, foreseeing that the minds of his disciples would be troubled by his passion, predicted to them long before both the punishment of that same passion and the glory of his resurrection, so that when they saw him dying, as it was predicted, they would not doubt that he would also rise.
chunks.notes: Citation to Homilies on the Gospels, book 1, homily 2, paragraph 1

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Single Death of Christ and Our Double Death
chunks.latin: CAPUT VI. De simpla morte Christi et dupla nostra.
chunks.english: Chapter Six: The Single Death of Christ and Our Double Death.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. IV, c. 16, n. 31.) Ad delenda peccata hominum ante Dei oculos Mediator Dei et hominum venit, qui solam pro nobis mortem carnis susciperet, et veram mortem delinquentium per umbram suae mortis deleret.
chunks.english: In his fourth book of Moralia, Gregory writes: The Mediator between God and humanity came before the eyes of God to destroy the sins of humanity, he who would take upon himself for us only the death of the flesh, and would destroy the true death of transgressors through the shadow of his own death.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 4, chapter 16, paragraph 31

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Redemptor noster ad nos pia miseratione descendit, qui in morte spiritus carnisque tenebamur; unam ad nos suam mortem detulit, et duas nostras quas reperit solvit.
chunks.english: Our Redeemer descended to us with merciful compassion, we who were held in the death of spirit and flesh. He brought down to us his one death, and released our two deaths which he found.
chunks.notes: The two deaths are spiritual death (separation from God) and bodily death

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si Redemptor noster utramque mortem susciperet, nos a nulla liberaret. Sed unam misericorditer accepit, et juste utramque damnavit.
chunks.english: If our Redeemer had taken upon himself both deaths, he would have freed us from neither. But he mercifully accepted one, and justly condemned both.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Simplam suam duplae nostrae contulit, et duplam nostram moriens subegit.
chunks.english: He applied his single death to our double death, and by dying he conquered our double death.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Mediator Dei et hominum homo Christus Jesus non immerito uno die in sepulcro et duabus noctibus jacuit, quia videlicet lucem suae simplae mortis tenebris duplae mortis nostrae adjunxit.
chunks.english: Christ Jesus, the human mediator between God and humanity, not undeservedly lay in the tomb one day and two nights, because he joined the light of his single death to the darkness of our double death.
chunks.notes: Refers to the Good Friday through Easter Sunday timeline

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui ergo solam pro nobis mortem carnis accepit, umbram mortis pertulit, et a Dei oculis culpam quam fecimus abscondit.
chunks.english: Therefore he who accepted only the death of the flesh for us endured the shadow of death, and hid from God's eyes the guilt which we committed.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Resurrection of Christ
chunks.latin: CAPUT VII. De resurrectione Christi.
chunks.english: Chapter Seven: The Resurrection of Christ.
chunks.notes: This chapter continues but the provided text appears to be cut off. Only including what was provided in the source.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XXXI, 49, n. 99.) Mediator Dei et nominum homo Christus Jesus instaurare omnia venit, ut, redempto humano genere, illa angelica damna sarciret, et mensuram coelestis patriae locupletius fortasse cumularet.
chunks.english: In his thirty-first book of Moralia, Gregory writes: Christ Jesus, the human mediator between God and humanity, came to restore all things, so that, with the human race redeemed, he might repair those angelic losses and perhaps heap up the measure of the heavenly homeland more abundantly.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 31, chapter 49, paragraph 99; refers to fallen angels being replaced by redeemed humans

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Propter hanc instaurationem de Patre dicitur: Proposuit in eo, in dispensatione plenitudinis temporum, instaurare omnia in Christo, quae in coelis et quae in terra sunt in ipso (Ephes. I, 9, 10).
chunks.english: Concerning this restoration it is said of the Father: He purposed in him, in the dispensation of the fullness of times, to restore all things in Christ, both those in the heavens and those on earth in him, as we read in Paul's letter to the Ephesians, chapter one, verses nine and ten.
chunks.notes: Citation to Ephesians 1:9-10

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In ipso quippe restaurantur ea quae in terra sunt, dum peccatores ad justitiam convertuntur. In ipso restaurantur ea quae in coelis sunt, dum illuc humiliati homines redeunt unde apostatae angeli superbiendo ceciderunt.
chunks.english: For in him are restored the things that are on earth, while sinners are converted to righteousness. In him are restored the things that are in heaven, while humbled humans return to that place from which apostate angels fell through pride.
chunks.notes: Continues the theme of humans filling the places of fallen angels

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ezech. homil. 8, n. 23.) Unigenitus Patris per hoc quod homo factus est infra angelos fuit, sicut de eo scriptum est: Minuisti eum paulo minus ab angelis (Ps. VIII, 6). Resurgens autem et ascendens in coelos, omnibus angelicis potestatibus praesidet, sicut de eo illic rursum scriptum est: Omnia subjecisti sub pedibus ejus (Ibid. 7). Et sicut ipse ait: Data est mihi omnis potestas in coelo et in terra (Matth. XXVIII, 18).
chunks.english: In his first book of Homilies on Ezekiel, Gregory writes: The Only-Begotten of the Father, by the fact that he became man, was below the angels, as it is written of him: You made him a little lower than the angels, as we read in Psalm eight, verse six. But rising and ascending into heaven, he presides over all angelic powers, as it is written again of him in the same place: You have subjected all things under his feet, verse seven. And as he himself says: All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me, as we read in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-eight, verse eighteen.
chunks.notes: Citations to Homilies on Ezekiel book 1, homily 8, paragraph 23; Psalm 8:6-7; and Matthew 28:18; this passage repeats content from earlier in the text

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Moral. lib. XIV, c. 53, n. 68.] Redemptor noster suscepit mortem, ne mori timeremus. Ostendit resurrectionem, ut nos resurgere posse confidamus. Unde et eamdem mortem non plusquam triduanam esse voluit, ne si in illo resurrectio differretur, in nobis omnimodo desperaretur.
chunks.english: In his fourteenth book of Moralia, Gregory writes: Our Redeemer took upon himself death, lest we should fear to die. He showed forth resurrection, that we might have confidence that we can rise. Therefore he willed that same death to be no more than three days, lest if resurrection were delayed in him, it should be utterly despaired of in us.
chunks.notes: Citation to Moralia in Job, book 14, chapter 53, paragraph 68; text appears to continue beyond what was provided

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Early Formation of the Church
chunks.latin: CAPUT XII. De initio nascentis Ecclesiae.
chunks.english: Chapter 12: The Early Formation of the Church

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XXVI, c. 41, n. 75.) Omnipotens Deus Ecclesiam suam digna sine administratione non deserit; nam cum fortes ad praemium vocat, eorum vice debiles ad certamina roborat. Cum illos suscipiendo remunerat, istis laborum virtutes [Edit. vires] quas remuneret subministrat. In virtute antiquorum Patrum hi qui postmodum praelati sunt subrogantur. Quia et cum annosa arbusta succiduntur, in eorum robur tenera virgulta succrescunt. Unde recte per Psalmistam dicitur: Pro patribus tuis nati sunt tibi filii, constitues eos principes super omnem terram (Ps. XLIV, 17).
chunks.english: Almighty God never abandons his Church without worthy leaders. When he calls the strong to their reward, he strengthens the weak in their place to carry on the struggle. Even as he receives those departed into glory, he supplies to these remaining the strengths and virtues he will later reward. Those who later become leaders are raised up in the strength of the ancient Fathers. Just as when old trees are cut down, tender shoots spring up to replace their strength. The Psalmist rightly says: In place of your fathers, sons have been born to you; you will make them princes over all the earth, as stated in the forty-fourth Psalm, verse seventeen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Deus in gradibus ejus dignoscetur, dum suscipiet eam (Ps XLVII, 4). [Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 3, n. 3.] Dum enim sanctam Ecclesiam Dominus suscipit, in gradibus ejus dignoscitur, quia ejus gloria per illius incrementa declaratur. Quantum enim sancta Ecclesia ascendendo profecerit, tantum Deus hominibus ex ejus virtutibus innotescit.
chunks.english: God will be recognized in her stages of growth when he receives her, as the forty-seventh Psalm, verse four, tells us. When the Lord receives the holy Church, he is recognized in her stages of ascent, because his glory is made known through her growth. The more the holy Church advances in her ascent, the more God becomes known to humanity through her virtues.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: De his quoque gradibus beatus Job loquitur, dicens: Per singulos gradus meos pronuntiabo illum (Job. XXXI, 37). Omnipotens Deus in gradibus Ecclesiae agnoscitur, quia in singulis ejus virtutibus atque miraculis, quam sit timendus et amandus, omnibus demonstratur: cum videlicet tunc suscipit, cum a culpis suis ad eum per poenitentiam redit.
chunks.english: Blessed Job speaks of these stages, saying: Through each of my steps I will proclaim him, from the book of Job, chapter thirty-one, verse thirty-seven. Almighty God is recognized in the Church's stages of growth because in each of her virtues and miracles, how much he is to be feared and loved is demonstrated to all. He receives her especially when she returns to him from her sins through repentance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. VIII, c. 48, n. 82.) Filia regum sancta Ecclesia est, quae in bono opere spiritualium principum praedicatione generata, gloriam intus habet, sicut scriptum est: Omnis gloria ejus filiae regum ab intus (Psalm. XLIV, 14); quia hoc quod quotidie agit in ostentationis jactantiam non habet. (Mor. XXXV, c. 18.) Nam si foras gloriam quaereret, intus speciem quam rex concupisceret non haberet.
chunks.english: The daughter of kings is the holy Church, who was born in good works through the preaching of spiritual princes. She has her glory within, as it is written: All the glory of this daughter of kings is within, from the forty-fourth Psalm, verse fourteen. For what she does daily, she does not do for the boasting of outward display. If she sought glory externally, she would not possess within the beauty that the King desires.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Mor. XIX, c. 12, n. 20.) Quia sancta Ecclesia exteriora sua a primordiis suis usque nunc irreprehensibilia custodit, jure de ea Psalmista ait: In fimbriis aureis circumamicta varietate (Ps. XLIV, 14), ut et pulchra intus sibi sit et aliis foras, et se provehens per internam gloriam, et alios erudiens per exteriora operum exempla.
chunks.english: Because the holy Church has kept her outward conduct blameless from her beginnings until now, the Psalmist rightly says of her: Clothed around with golden fringes in variety, from the forty-fourth Psalm, verse fourteen. Thus she is beautiful inwardly to herself and outwardly to others, advancing herself through inner glory while instructing others through outward examples of her works.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Apud Pater., c. 53, super Gen.; Moral. lib. XIV, c. 43, n. 51.) Sola electorum Ecclesia unigenito Filio Dei Patris copulanda erat, quam ipse Unigenitus ex praedestinatione jam et praesentia extraneam non habebat. Sancta Ecclesia quot praecepta ex Redemptoris nostri praedicatione cognovit, quasi tot oris ejus oscula accepit, sicut scriptum est: Osculetur me osculis oris sui (Cant. I, 1); ac si apertis vocibus dicat (Moral. XXVII, c. 17, n. 34): Dudum mihi quidem prophetarum praedicamentis, quasi quibusdam labiis, osculum porrexit, nunc vero tangat me ipsa dulcedo praesentiae unigeniti Filii, Redemptoris mei.
chunks.english: Only the Church of the elect was to be joined to the only-begotten Son of God the Father, whom the Only-Begotten himself, through predestination and presence, never considered foreign. The holy Church has received as many kisses from his mouth as she has learned commandments from our Redeemer's preaching, as it is written: Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth, from the Song of Songs, chapter one, verse one. It is as if she openly declares: Long ago he extended kisses to me through the prophecies of the prophets, as through certain lips, but now may the very sweetness of the presence of the only-begotten Son, my Redeemer, touch me.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XIX, c. 12, n. 19.) Universae Ecclesiae, quae unam catholicam faciunt, adolescentulae vocantur, non vetustae per culpam, sed novellae per gratiam; non senio steriles, sed aetate mentis ad spiritualem fecunditatem congruae.
chunks.english: All the churches that make up the one catholic Church are called young maidens, not aged through guilt but renewed through grace. They are not barren through old age, but in the maturity of mind suited for spiritual fruitfulness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Apud Pater. ubi supra.) A priori populo naturae legem sancta Ecclesia se scisse monstravit, et praedicationis verba in amplo charitatis gremio suscepit. Sancta Ecclesia verba vitae audiens, et ad verae fidei conversationem veniens, studuit non plus sapere quam oportet sapere, sed sapere ad sobrietatem.
chunks.english: The holy Church showed that she knew the law of nature from the earlier people, and she received the words of preaching in the broad embrace of charity. Hearing the words of life and coming to the way of true faith, the holy Church strove not to be wiser than one ought to be, but to exercise wisdom with sobriety.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ev. homil. 17, n. 7.) Sed tamen terrena stipendia praedicatoribus reddidit; quae dum Paulus apostolus quasi pro nihilo acciperet dixit: Si nos vobis spiritualia seminavimus, magnum est, si a vobis carnalia metamus (I Cor. IX, 11)?
chunks.english: Yet she gave earthly wages to preachers. When Paul the apostle received these as though they were nothing, he said: If we have sown spiritual things among you, is it too much if we reap material benefits from you? This is from Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, chapter nine, verse eleven.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sancta Ecclesia, quae ante per fidem, obedientiam, et operationem percepit, excrescens postmodum etiam ad spiritualia dona convalescit (Apud Pater. ubi supra); ut prophetiae spiritu et virtutum gratia repleta, ampliatis jam muneribus ditescat. Unigenitus Dominus ac Redemptor noster veniente ad se Ecclesia in illorum mentibus mansit quos ex Judaea editos non torporis frigus, sed fervor charitatis tenuit. Ex illo quippe populo Anna prophetissa, ex illo Simeon exstitit, qui in ulnas Dominum accepit.
chunks.english: The holy Church, who first received through faith, obedience, and action, growing afterward also becomes strong in spiritual gifts, so that filled with the spirit of prophecy and the grace of miracles, she might become rich with multiplied gifts. When the Church came to him, our only-begotten Lord and Redeemer remained in the minds of those from Judea who were held not by the coldness of sluggishness but by the fervor of charity. From that people came Anna the prophetess, from that people came Simeon, who received the Lord in his arms.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sancta Ecclesia praedicatorum suorum desiderio ex virtute suae fidei satisfecit. Quia enim Deum quem audivit confessa est, praedicatori suo quasi aquam refectionis obtulit, ejusque animum refrigeravit. Quod Rebecca proprie significavit, cum hydriam ab humero in ulnas posuit, et puero Abrahae ad bibendum aquam praebuit. Quia sancta Ecclesia in eo quod credidit vacua non remansit. Nam protinus praedicare studuit quod audivit, et docendo multos ex se praedicatores protulit.
chunks.english: The holy Church satisfied the desire of her preachers through the strength of her faith. Because she confessed the God she had heard about, she offered her preacher refreshing water, as it were, and cooled his soul.
