Rebecca properly signified this when she placed the water jar from her shoulder into her arms and gave water to Abraham's servant to drink. For the holy Church did not remain empty in what she believed. She immediately strove to preach what she had heard, and through teaching she brought forth many preachers from herself.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. I, c. 15, n. 21; apud Pater., lib. I sup. Genes., c. 53.) Quid est quod Rebecca ad Isaac dorso cameli deducitur, nisi quod per Rebeccam significatur Ecclesia, et per camelum cui praesidet tortuosus moribus, atque onustus idolorum cultibus, gentilium populus designatur? Qui enim ex semetipsis sibi invenerunt deos quos colerent, quasi a semetipsis eis onus in dorso excreverat quod portarent. Sancta Ecclesia quanto Redemptorem suum subtilius agnoscit, tanto carnalis vitae illecebram studio humilitatis deserit, atque in semetipsam tortitudini vitiosae contradicit: quod Rebecca significat cum, Isaac viso, de camelo descendit; quia. Domino cognito, vitia sua gentilitas deseruit, et ab elatione celsitudinis ima humilitatis petit.
chunks.english: What does it mean that Rebecca is led to Isaac on the back of a camel? Through Rebecca the Church is signified, and by the camel over which she presides is designated the gentile people, crooked in morals and burdened with the worship of idols. For they who found gods for themselves to worship had, as from themselves, caused a burden to grow on their backs that they must carry. The more subtly the holy Church recognizes her Redeemer, the more she abandons the enticements of carnal life through the pursuit of humility and contradicts within herself the crookedness of vice. Rebecca signifies this when, having seen Isaac, she descends from the camel. For having known the Lord, the gentiles abandoned their vices and sought the depths of humility from the heights of pride.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XXX, c. 25, n. 71.) Sancta Ecclesia Christum sequens terrenae concupiscentiae vitia poenitendo contexit, quod recte Rachel significavit, quae idola Laban patris sui sedendo cooperuit. De hac coopertione vitiorum per prophetam dicitur: Beati quorum remissae sunt iniquitates, et quorum tecta sunt peccata (Ps. XXXI, 1). Nos igitur Rachel illa signavit, qui idola sedendo premimus, si culpas avaritiae poenitendo damnamus.
chunks.english: Following Christ, the holy Church covers over the vices of earthly desire through repentance, which Rachel rightly signified when she covered her father Laban's idols by sitting on them. Of this covering of vices the prophet says: Blessed are those whose iniquities are forgiven and whose sins are covered, from the thirty-first Psalm, verse one. Therefore Rachel signified us, who press down idols by sitting on them, if we condemn the sins of avarice through repentance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ev., hom. 29, n. 4; Reg. Past., part. II, c. 4.) In exordio nascentis Ecclesiae necessaria fuerunt signa vel miracula. Ut enim ad fidem cresceret, miraculis fuerat nutrienda. In sacerdotis veste juxta divinam vocem tintinnabulis mala punica conjunguntur. Quid enim per mala punica nisi unitas fidei designatur? Nam sicut in malo punico una exterius cortice multa interius grana muniuntur, sic innumeros sanctae Ecclesiae populos unitas fidei contegit, quos intus diversitas meritorum tenet.
chunks.english: At the beginning of the newborn Church, signs and miracles were necessary. For the Church to grow in faith, she had to be nourished by miracles. On the priest's robe, according to the divine command, pomegranates are joined with bells. What else does the pomegranate signify but the unity of faith? Just as in a pomegranate one rind protects many seeds within, so the unity of faith covers the innumerable peoples of the holy Church, whom diversity of merits holds within.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Grace of Baptism
chunks.latin: CAPUT XIII. De gratia baptismi.
chunks.english: Chapter 13: The Grace of Baptism

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Praef. Moral. IV, 3.) Quisquis regenerationis unda non solvitur, reatu primi vinculi ligatus tenetur. Quod vero apud nos valet aqua baptismatis, hoc egit apud veteres, vel pro parvulis sola fides, vel pro majoribus virtus sacrificii, vel pro his qui ex Abrahae stirpe prodierant mysterium circumcisionis.
chunks.english: Whoever is not loosed by the water of rebirth remains bound by the guilt of the first bond. What the water of baptism accomplishes among us was done among the ancients either by faith alone for infants, or by the power of sacrifice for adults, or by the mystery of circumcision for those descended from Abraham's line.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unusquisque cum primi parentis culpa concipitur. sicut propheta testatur, dicens: Ecce enim in iniquitatibus conceptus sum (Ps. L, 7). Et quia is quem salutis unda non diluit, originalis culpae supplicia non amittit, aperte per semetipsam Veritas perhibet, dicens: Nisi quis renatus fuerit ex aqua et Spiritu sancto, non habebit vitam aeternam (Joan. III, 5).
chunks.english: Everyone is conceived with the sin of the first parent, as the prophet testifies, saying: Behold, I was conceived in iniquities, from the fiftieth Psalm, verse seven. And because one whom the water of salvation does not wash away does not lose the penalties of original sin, the Truth himself openly declares: Unless someone is reborn of water and the Holy Spirit, he will not have eternal life, from the Gospel of John, chapter three, verse five.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Lib. II in Ev., homil. 29, n. 3.] Tunc veraciter fideles sumus, si quod verbis promittimus operibus implemus. In die quippe baptismatis omnibus nos antiqui hostis operibus atque omnibus pompis abrenuntiare promittimus. Itaque unusquisque vestrum ad considerationem suam mentis oculos reducat, et si servat post baptismum quod ante baptismum spopondit, certus jam quia fidelis est, gaudeat.
chunks.english: We are truly faithful when we fulfill by our works what we promise with our words. On the day of baptism we promise to renounce all the works of the ancient enemy and all his pomps. Therefore let each of you turn the eyes of your mind to consideration of yourself, and if you keep after baptism what you promised before baptism, rejoice with certainty that you are faithful.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XV, c. 51, n. 57.) Originale peccatum a parentibus trahimus, et nisi per gratiam baptismatis solvamur, etiam parentum peccata portamus, quia unum adhuc videlicet cum illis sumus. Scriptum est in libro Exodi: Qui reddis iniquitatem patrum in filiis (Exod. XXXIV, 7). Reddit ergo Dominus iniquitatem patrum in filiis, dum pro culpa parentis ex originali peccato animus polluitur prolis. Et rursum non reddit parentum iniquitatem in filiis, quia cum ab originali culpa per baptismum liberamur, non jam parentum culpas, sed quas ipsi commisimus habemus.
chunks.english: We inherit original sin from our parents, and unless we are released through the grace of baptism, we also bear the sins of our parents, because we are still one with them. It is written in the book of Exodus: You visit the iniquity of the fathers upon the children, from the book of Exodus, chapter thirty-four, verse seven. Therefore the Lord visits the iniquity of the fathers upon the children when the soul of the offspring is polluted by original sin because of the parent's fault. But again he does not visit the iniquity of the parents upon the children, because when we are freed from original sin through baptism, we no longer bear our parents' sins but only those we ourselves have committed.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Holy Communion
chunks.latin: CAPUT XIV. De communione.
chunks.english: Chapter 14: The Holy Communion

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XIII, c. 23, n. 26.) Unusquisque peccator redemptionis suae pretium sumens, confitetur ac laudat Deum, et quibus valet verbis, hoc ipsum proximis innotescit, sicut beatus Job sub figura Redemptoris nostri ait: Terra, ne operias sanguinem meum (Job. XVI, 19). Terra namque sanguinem Christi non operuit, quia sancta Ecclesia redemptionis suae mysterium in cunctis jam mundi partibus praedicavit.
chunks.english: Each sinner, receiving the price of his redemption, confesses and praises God, and makes this known to his neighbors with whatever words he can, as blessed Job says in the figure of our Redeemer: Earth, do not cover my blood, from the book of Job, chapter sixteen, verse nineteen. The earth did not cover the blood of Christ, because the holy Church has preached the mystery of her redemption in all parts of the world.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ipse enim sanguis redemptionis qui sumitur clamor nostri Redemptoris est. Paulus apostolus ait: Et sanguinis Christi aspersionem melius loquentem, quam Abel (Heb. XII, 24). De Abel sanguine dictum fuerat: Vox sanguinis tui fratris clamat ad me de terra (Gen. IV, 10); sed sanguis Jesu melius loquitur quam Abel, quia sanguis Abel mortem fratricidae fratris petiit, sanguis autem Domini vitam persecutoribus impetravit.
chunks.english: For the very blood of redemption that is received is the cry of our Redeemer. Paul the apostle says: And to the sprinkling of Christ's blood that speaks better than Abel, from the letter to the Hebrews, chapter twelve, verse twenty-four. Of Abel's blood it had been said: The voice of your brother's blood cries to me from the earth, from the book of Genesis, chapter four, verse ten. But the blood of Jesus speaks better than Abel, because Abel's blood sought the death of his fratricide brother, but the Lord's blood obtained life for his persecutors.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ut sacramentum dominicae passionis in nobis non sit otiosum, debemus imitari quod sumimus, et praedicare caeteris quod veneramur. Hinc iterum beatus Job ait: Neque inveniat in te locum latendi clamor meus. Locum enim latendi clamor ejus in nobis invenit, si hoc quod mens credit lingua tacet. Sed ne in nobis clamor ejus lateat, restat ut unusquisque juxta modum suum vivificationis suae mysterium proximis innotescat.
chunks.english: That the sacrament of the Lord's passion may not be idle in us, we must imitate what we receive and preach to others what we venerate. Therefore blessed Job again says: Let my cry find no place to hide in you. For his cry finds a hiding place in us if the tongue is silent about what the mind believes. But lest his cry be hidden in us, it remains that each according to his ability make known to his neighbors the mystery of his vivification.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Evang., homil. 22, n. 7.) Quis namque sit sanguis Christi non jam audiendo, sed bibendo didicimus. Qui sanguis super utrumque postem ponitur (Exod. XII, 7), quando non solum ore corporis, sed etiam ore cordis hauritur. In utroque etenim poste agni sanguis est positus, quando sacramentum passionis Christi cum ore ad redemptionem sumitur, ad imitationem quoque intenta mente cogitatur. Quasi in nocte agni carnes comedimus, cum in sacramento modo dominicum corpus accipimus, quando adhuc ab invicem nostras conscientias non videmus.
chunks.english: Who the blood of Christ is we have learned not by hearing but by drinking. This blood is placed on both doorposts, as the book of Exodus, chapter twelve, verse seven tells us, when it is drunk not only by the mouth of the body but also by the mouth of the heart. On both doorposts the blood of the lamb is placed when the sacrament of Christ's passion is received with the mouth for redemption and also pondered with attentive mind for imitation. We eat the flesh of the lamb as if in the night when we now receive the Lord's body in the sacrament, when we do not yet see one another's consciences.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 8.) Nam nihil prodest corpus et sanguinem Christi Jesu ore percipere, et ei perversis moribus contraire. Qui scelerate vivunt in Ecclesia, et communicare non desinunt, putantes se tali communione mundari, discant nihil de mundatione proficere, sibi dicente Propheta: Quid est, quod dilectus meus in domo mea fecit scelera multa? Nunquid carnes sanctae auferent a te malitias tuas (Jerem. XI, 15)?
chunks.english: For it profits nothing to receive the body and blood of Christ Jesus with the mouth while contradicting him with perverse behavior. Those who live wickedly in the Church and do not cease to receive communion, thinking they are cleansed by such communion, should learn that they gain nothing from cleansing, with the Prophet saying to them: What has my beloved done in my house when she has committed many crimes? Will holy flesh take away your wickedness from you? This is from the book of Jeremiah, chapter eleven, verse fifteen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et Apostolus: Probet, inquit, se homo, et sic de pane illo edat, et de calice bibat: qui enim indigne hoc accipit, judicium sibi manducat et bibit (I Cor. XI, 28).
chunks.english: And the Apostle says: Let a person examine himself, and thus let him eat of that bread and drink of that cup, for whoever receives it unworthily eats and drinks judgment upon himself. This is from Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, chapter eleven, verse twenty-eight.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Width, Length, Height, and Depth of God
chunks.latin: CAPUT XV. Quid significet latitudo et longitudo Dei , sublimitas et profundum.
chunks.english: Chapter 15: The Width, Length, Height, and Depth of God

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. X, c. 9, n. 15.) Habet latitudinem, quia omnipotens Deus dilectionem suam usque ad collectionem persequentium tendit. Habet longitudinem, quia ad vitae patriam nos longanimiter tolerando perducit. Habet sublimitatem, quia ipsorum quoque intelligentiam qui recepti fuerint in superna congregatione transcendit. Habet profundum, quia damnatis inferius districtionis suae judicium incomprehensibiliter exerit.
chunks.english: He has width, because almighty God extends his love even to gathering in persecutors. He has length, because he leads us to our heavenly homeland by bearing with us patiently. He has height, because he transcends even the understanding of those who will be received into the heavenly assembly. He has depth, because to the condemned below he exercises the judgment of his severity incomprehensibly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quatuor nobis Deus in hac vita positis singulis exercet: quia et latitudinem amando, et longitudinem tolerando, et celsitudinem, non solum nostram intelligentiam, sed etiam vota superando, et profunditatem suam exhibet, occultos et illicitos cogitationum motus districte judicando.
chunks.english: God exercises four qualities toward each of us placed in this life: both width by loving, and length by tolerating, and height by surpassing not only our understanding but also our desires, and he displays his depth by strictly judging the hidden and illicit movements of our thoughts.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Celsitudo omnipotentis Dei et profunditas, quam sit investigabilis, nullus agnoscit, nisi qui vel contemplatione ad summa provehi, vel occultis motibus resistens, tentationum coeperit importunitate turbari.
chunks.english: No one recognizes how unsearchable is the height and depth of almighty God except one who has either advanced to the highest things through contemplation or, resisting hidden movements, has begun to be troubled by the importunity of temptations.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (August. in Spec. c. 14; Isidor. quoque lib. I Sentent., c. 2.) Cum de Deo omnipotente nec secundum situm, nec secundum qualitatem, nec secundum habitum aut motum aliquid digne dicatur, inest tamen ei quodammodo latitudo, longitudo, altitudo, et profundum. Est in omnipotente Deo latitudo charitatis, qua nos et ab errore corrigit, et continet in veritate. Inest ei et longitudo, quae nos longanimiter malos portat, donec emendatos patriae futurae restituat. Inest ei et altitudo, per quam omnem sensum suae scientiae immensitate exsuperat. Inest ei et profundum, quo damnandos inferius juxta aequitatem disponens, praeordinat.
chunks.english: Although nothing can be said worthily of almighty God according to position, quality, condition, or motion, yet there exists in him in some manner width, length, height, and depth. In almighty God there is the width of charity, by which he both corrects us from error and keeps us in truth. There is in him also length, which patiently bears with us as evil until he restores us, amended, to our future homeland. There is in him also height, through which he surpasses all understanding by the immensity of his knowledge. There is in him also depth, by which, disposing the damned below according to equity, he preordains them.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Call of the Gentiles to the Church
chunks.latin: CAPUT XVI. De vocatione gentium ad Ecclesiam convenientium.
chunks.english: Chapter 16: The Call of the Gentiles to the Church

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Evang., homil. 33, n. 6.) Ad fidem vocata gentilitas, Redemptoris sui vestigia osculari desiderans, nequaquam cessat ab intentione boni operis, quia in ejus continuo amore suspirat. Unde et sponsae voce de eodem Redemptore suo in Canticis canticorum ita incipit: Osculetur me osculis oris sui (Cant. I, 1). Osculum recte Conditoris sui desiderat, quae se ei obsequi per amorem parat.
chunks.english: The gentiles, called to faith and desiring to kiss the footsteps of their Redeemer, never cease from the intention of good work, because they sigh in continuous love for him. Hence with the voice of the bride concerning this same Redeemer of hers, the Song of Songs begins thus: Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth, from the Song of Songs, chapter one, verse one. She rightly desires the kiss of her Creator, who prepares herself to serve him through love.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XXX, c. 25, n. 72.) Eripiens gentilitatem Dominus superavit jugum oneris ejus, cum eam adventu suo ab illa daemoniacae tyrannidis servitute liberavit. Superavit virgam humeri ejus (Isa. IX, 4), cum percussionem illius, quae ex perverso opere graviter deprimebat, ab humano genere redempto compescuit. Superavit sceptrum exactoris ejus, cum regnum ejusdem diaboli, qui pro pestifera perpetratione vitiorum exigere consueverat debita tributa poenarum, de fidelium corde destruxit.
chunks.english: Rescuing the gentiles, the Lord overcame the yoke of their burden when by his coming he freed them from that demonic tyranny. He overcame the rod of their shoulder, as the book of Isaiah, chapter nine, verse four states, when he restrained from redeemed humanity the blow that gravely oppressed them through perverse work. He overcame the scepter of their oppressor when he destroyed from the hearts of the faithful the kingdom of that same devil, who used to exact the owed tributes of punishments for the pestilential perpetration of vices.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. I, c. 16, n. 23.) Scriptum quippe est: Cognovit bos possessorem suum, et asinus praesepe domini sui (Isa. I, 3). Per bovem Judaeae operarii, per asinum vero gentiles populi designantur. Quis enim bos nisi judaicus populus exstitit, cujus cervicem jugum Legis attrivit? Et quis asinus nisi gentilitas fuit, quam quilibet seductor reperit, quasi brutum animal et nulla ratione renitens, quo voluit errore substravit? Bos ergo possessorem, et asinus domini praesepe cognovit; quia et Hebraicus populus Deum quem colebat, sed ignorabat, reperit; et gentilitas legis pabulum, quod non habebat, accepit.
chunks.english: For it is written: The ox knows its owner, and the donkey its master's manger, from the book of Isaiah, chapter one, verse three. By the ox are designated the workers of Judea, but by the donkey the gentile peoples. For who was the ox but the Jewish people, whose neck the yoke of the Law wore down? And who was the donkey but the gentiles, whom any deceiver found like a dumb animal resisting by no reason and subdued to whatever error he wished? Therefore the ox knew its owner and the donkey its master's manger, because both the Hebrew people found the God whom they worshiped but did not know, and the gentiles received the food of the law which they did not have.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Habet denique post Mediatoris adventum catholica Ecclesia simplices asinos, quia vocatae plebes gentilium, dum ad requiem pervenire desiderant, cuncta mandatorum onera libenter portant. (Num. 24.) Unde bene, quod hanc requiem populus gentilis appeteret, Jacob, filios alloquens, prophetica hoc studuit voce signare, dicens: Issachar asinus fortis accubans in terminos, vidit requiem quod esset bona, et terram quod optima; et supposuit humerum ad portandum (Gen. XLII, 14, 15).
chunks.english: After the Mediator's coming, the catholic Church has simple donkeys, because the called peoples of the gentiles, while desiring to arrive at rest, willingly bear all the burdens of the commandments. Therefore Jacob, addressing his sons, strove to signify this prophetically, saying that the gentile people would seek this rest: Issachar is a strong donkey lying down between the boundaries; he saw that rest was good and that the land was excellent, and he bent his shoulder to carry, from the book of Genesis, chapter forty-two, verses fourteen and fifteen.
chunks.notes: This appears to be Genesis 49:14-15, not 42:14-15 - common scribal error in medieval texts

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. II, c. 35, n. 37.) Isaias propheta clamat dicens: Verbum misit Dominus in Jacob, et illud cecidit in Israel (Isa. IX, 8). Jacob quippe Supplantator, Israel vero Videns Deum dicitur. Et quid per Jacob, nisi Judaicus; quid per Israel, nisi gentilis populus designatur? Quia quem Jacob per carnis mortem supplantare studuit, hunc nimirum per oculos fidei gentilitas Deum vidit. Ad Jacob ergo verbum missum in Israel cecidit, quia quem ad se venientem Judaicus respuit, hunc repente confitens populus gentilis invenit.
chunks.english: The prophet Isaiah cries out saying: The Lord sent a word to Jacob, and it fell upon Israel, from the book of Isaiah, chapter nine, verse eight. Jacob indeed means Supplanter, while Israel means One Who Sees God. And what is designated by Jacob but the Jewish people, what by Israel but the gentile people? Because the one whom Jacob strove to supplant through death of the flesh, this one the gentiles surely saw as God through the eyes of faith. Therefore the word sent to Jacob fell upon Israel, because the one whom the Jewish people rejected when he came to them, the gentile people suddenly found by confessing him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 9, n. 5.) Cum Judaeorum populum propheta a fide perire cognosceret, et sanctos apostolos surgere in Ecclesia praevideret, per quos multi sunt ex gentibus in fidei et vitae fortitudine solidati, in magna consolatione locutus est, dicens: Lateres ceciderunt, sed quadris lapidibus aedificavimus (Isa. IX, 10). Videns quippe in sancta Ecclesia apostolos, martyres atque doctores surgere, de laterum casu, id est de Judaeorum perditione, minus doluit, quia omnipotentis Dei aedificium, id est sanctam Ecclesiam, de quadris lapidibus aedificari conspexit.
chunks.english: When the prophet recognized that the Jewish people were perishing from faith, and foresaw the holy apostles rising in the Church, through whom many from the gentiles were strengthened in the fortitude of faith and life, he spoke in great consolation, saying: Bricks have fallen, but we will build with squared stones, from the book of Isaiah, chapter nine, verse ten. Seeing apostles, martyrs, and teachers rising in the holy Church, he grieved less over the fall of bricks, that is, over the destruction of the Jews, because he beheld the building of almighty God, that is, the holy Church, being built with squared stones.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 6, n. 21.) Hinc idem propheta ait: Et frenum erroris, quod erat in maxillis populorum, canticum erit vobis (Isa. XXX, 28, 29). Frenum quippe erroris maxillas populorum constrinxerat, quando idolorum errore obligata gentilitas Deo vero confessionis laudem dare nesciebat. Sed hoc ipsum erroris frenum jam nobis in canticum versum est, cum gaudendo psallimus atque cantamus: Omnes dii gentium daemonia, Dominus autem coelos fecit (Ps. XCV, 5). Et rursum: Simulacra gentium argentum et aurum, opera manuum hominum. Os habent et non loquentur, oculos habent et non videbunt (Ps. CXIII, 4).
chunks.english: Hence the same prophet says: And the bridle of error that was in the jaws of the peoples will be a song for you, from the book of Isaiah, chapter thirty, verses twenty-eight and twenty-nine. The bridle of error had bound the jaws of the peoples when the gentiles, bound by the error of idols, did not know how to give praise of confession to the true God. But this very bridle of error has now been turned into a song for us, when we joyfully sing in psalms and chant: All the gods of the gentiles are demons, but the Lord made the heavens, from the ninety-fifth Psalm, verse five. And again: The idols of the gentiles are silver and gold, the works of human hands. They have mouths and will not speak, they have eyes and will not see, from the one hundred thirteenth Psalm, verse four.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Haec nos omnipotenti Domino cum psallendo dicimus, ipsum erroris nostri frenum, quod a laude Dei ora nostra ligaverat, vero Domino canticum facimus. Bene autem subinfertur: Sicut nox sanctificatae solemnitatis (Isa. XXX, 29): quia dum confessionis laudem Deo reddimus, in sanctificata solemnitate gaudemus.
chunks.english: When we sing these things to the almighty Lord in psalms, we make the very bridle of our error, which had bound our mouths from praising God, into a song for the true Lord. But it is well added: Like the night of a sanctified solemnity, from the book of Isaiah, chapter thirty, verse twenty-nine, because while we render praise of confession to God, we rejoice in sanctified solemnity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XXIX, c. 26, n. 52.) Scriptum est: In cubilibus, in quibus prius dracones habitabant, orietur viror calami et junci (Isa. XXXV, 7). In draconum namque cubilibus viror calami et junci oritur, quia in eis populis, quos antiqui hostis malitia possidebat, et doctorum scientia, et auditorum obedientia coacervatur.
chunks.english: It is written: In the lairs where dragons formerly dwelt, there will arise the greenness of reed and rush, from the book of Isaiah, chapter thirty-five, verse seven. For in the lairs of dragons the greenness of reed and rush arises, because in those peoples whom the malice of the ancient enemy possessed, both the knowledge of teachers and the obedience of hearers are heaped up.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 1, n. 11.) Orietur in ea viror calami et junci, id est, in sancta Ecclesia oriuntur scriptores et auditores; ut per calamum scriptores, per juncum vero debeant auditores intelligi. Per aquae humorem juncus et calamus nasci solet. Ex una eademque aqua utraque proficiunt. Et calamus quidem ad scribendum assumitur, eum junco vero scribi non potest: quid in junco et calamo accipere debemus, nisi quod una est doctrina veritatis quae multos auditores irrigat?
chunks.english: There will arise in her the greenness of reed and rush, that is, in the holy Church arise writers and hearers, so that by the reed are understood writers, but by the rush should be understood hearers. Reed and rush are accustomed to grow through the moisture of water. Both flourish from one and the same water. And indeed the reed is taken up for writing, but with the rush nothing can be written. What should we understand in rush and reed except that there is one doctrine of truth that irrigates many hearers?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed irrigati alii ad hoc usque in verbo Dei proficiunt, ut etiam scriptores fiant, videlicet tanquam calami; alii vero verbum vitae audiunt, bonae spei et rectorum operum viriditatem tenent, sed tamen ad scribendum proficere nullatenus possunt. Qui hi, qui in aqua fidei, nisi quidam, ut ita dicam, junci sunt? Qui quidem viridescendo proficiunt, sed litteras exprimere nequaquam possunt.
chunks.english: But when irrigated, some advance so far in the word of God that they even become writers, namely like reeds; others truly hear the word of life and retain the greenness of good hope and right works, but nevertheless cannot advance to writing. Who are these in the water of faith except certain, so to speak, rushes? Who indeed flourish by growing green, but can in no way express letters.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ev., homil. 20, n. 3.) In fide Mediatoris Dei et hominum hominis Christi Jesu, et gentilitas plenitudinem gratiae accepit, et Judaea per errorem perfidiae hoc unde tumebat perdidit. Desertum Dominus in stagna aquarum (Isa. XLI, 18) posuit, quia gentilitati, quae prius per ariditatem mentis nullos bonorum operum fructus ferebat, fluenta sanctae praedicationis dedit: et ipsa, ad quam prius pro asperitate suae siccitatis via praedicatoribus non patebat, doctrinae postmodum rivos emanavit.
chunks.english: In faith in the Mediator between God and humanity, the man Christ Jesus, the gentiles received the fullness of grace, and Judea through the error of faithlessness lost that by which she had been puffed up. The Lord placed the desert into pools of water, as the book of Isaiah, chapter forty-one, verse eighteen states, because to the gentiles, who previously through dryness of mind bore no fruits of good works, he gave the streams of holy preaching. And she herself, to whom previously because of the harshness of her dryness the way was not open to preachers, afterward poured forth streams of doctrine.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XXVII c. 43, n. 71.) Scriptum est: Dicam Aquiloni, Da; et Austro, Noli prohibere (Is. XLIII, 6). Sicut per Aquilonem gentilitas, sic per Austrum Judaea signatur. Quae quasi meridiano sole incaluit; quia Redemptore in carne veniente fervorem fidei prima suscepit. Aquiloni ergo, Da, dicitur, cum offerre Deo suae fidei munera gentilitas imperatur. Austro autem jubetur ne prohibeat, quia Hebraeis in fide consistentibus praecipitur, ne vitam gentium repellendo contemnant.
chunks.english: It is written: I will say to the north, Give up, and to the south, Do not withhold, from the book of Isaiah, chapter forty-three, verse six. Just as by the north the gentiles are signified, so by the south is Judea signified. She as it were grew warm with the midday sun, because when the Redeemer came in flesh she was the first to receive the fervor of faith. Therefore to the north it is said, Give up, when the gentiles are commanded to offer to God the gifts of their faith. But the south is ordered not to withhold, because it is commanded to the Hebrews standing in faith that they not contemptuously reject the life of the gentiles.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XX, c. 25, n. 58.) Sicut indumentum Christi tota generaliter Ecclesia dicitur, sic indumentum sunt Ecclesiae singulorum animae, quae ab errore conversae, eamdem Ecclesiam credendo eique fideliter inhaerendo circumdant. (Moral. lib. XXIX, c. 6, n. 13.) Tot nunc quasi vestibus sancta Ecclesia induitur, quot fidelium veneratione decoratur. Sanctae Ecclesiae ostensis gentibus a Domino per prophetam dicitur: Vivo ego, quia omnibus his velut ornamento vestieris (Isa. XLV, 18).
chunks.english: Just as the whole Church generally is called the garment of Christ, so the garment of the Church consists of individual souls, which, converted from error, surround that same Church by believing and faithfully clinging to her. The holy Church is now clothed with as many garments, as it were, as she is adorned with veneration by the faithful. To the holy Church, when the gentiles have been shown to her, it is said by the Lord through the prophet: As I live, you will surely clothe yourself with all these as with an ornament, from the book of Isaiah, chapter forty-five, verse eighteen.
chunks.notes: The verse reference appears incorrect - likely Isaiah 49:18

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Moran. lib. XX, c. 29, n. 58.] Si enim sancta Ecclesia vestimentum Christi non esset, Paulus apostolus profecto non diceret: Ut exhiberet sibi gloriosam Ecclesiam non habentem maculam, aut rugam (Ephes. V, 27), id est, nec per peccatum maculam, nec per duplicitatem rugam; quia et per justitiam munda est, et per simplicem intentionem tensa; quae ergo abluta est ne habeat maculam, tensa est ne habeat rugam, utique vestis est.
chunks.english: For if the holy Church were not the garment of Christ, Paul the apostle certainly would not have said: That he might present to himself a glorious Church not having spot or wrinkle, from Paul's letter to the Ephesians, chapter five, verse twenty-seven, that is, neither spot through sin nor wrinkle through duplicity. Because she is clean through righteousness and stretched out through simple intention, therefore what has been washed lest it have a spot and stretched lest it have a wrinkle is certainly a garment.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral., lib. XXV, c. 8, n. 21.) Sancta Ecclesia in tanta multitudino gentium ad dexteram extenditur, dum quosdam justificandos suscipit. Ad laevam quoque dilatatur, dum ad se quosdam etiam in iniquitate permansuros admittit. Propter hanc multitudinem, quae extra electorum numerum jacet, in Evangelio Dominus dicit: Multi vocati, pauci autem electi (Matth. XX, 16).
chunks.english: The holy Church extends to the right in such a great multitude of peoples when she receives some who are to be justified. She also expands to the left when she admits to herself some who will remain in iniquity. Because of this multitude that lies outside the number of the elect, the Lord says in the Gospel: Many are called, but few are chosen, from the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty, verse sixteen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ezech., homil. 10, n. 39.) Cum Judaei a fide caderent, ad cognitionem fidei corda gentilium cucurrerunt: quae videlicet gentes in sacrae lectionis pabulo os cordis aperiunt, et in occulto sicut pauper comedunt, quia cum festinatione et silentio verba vitae legentes sumunt.
chunks.english: When the Jews fell from faith, the hearts of the gentiles ran to the knowledge of faith. These gentiles open the mouth of the heart in the food of sacred reading and eat in secret like a poor person, because reading they receive the words of life with haste and silence.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXIX, c. 14, n. 26.) Dum Redemptor noster angustias mortis petiit, fidem suam in gentibus dilatavit, atque in innumera corda credentium sanctam Ecclesiam tetendit. Cui per prophetam dicitur: Dilata locum tentorii tui, et pelles tabernaculorum tuorum extende, ne parcas, longos fac funiculos tuos, et clavos tuos consolida: ad dexteram enim et ad laevam penetrabis, et semen tuum gentes haereditabit (Isa. LIV, 2). Quae latitudo terrae profecto non fieret, nisi ipse prius et vitam quam novimus moriendo despiceret, et vitam quam non novimus resurgendo monstraret.
chunks.english: When our Redeemer sought the straits of death, he expanded his faith among the gentiles and stretched out the holy Church into the innumerable hearts of believers. To her it is said through the prophet: Enlarge the place of your tent, and stretch out the skins of your tabernacles, do not spare; make your cords long and strengthen your stakes, for you will penetrate to the right and to the left, and your seed will inherit the gentiles, from the book of Isaiah, chapter fifty-four, verse two. This breadth of the earth certainly would not have happened unless he first scorned by dying the life we know and showed by rising the life we do not know.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Holy Preachers
chunks.latin: CAPUT XVII. De sanctis praedicatoribus.
chunks.english: Chapter 17: Holy Preachers

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Apud Paterium, c. 53 super Genes.) Sancti viri, dum verbum praedicationis bonis mentibus faciunt, ad unamquamque animam unigenito Filio conjungendam quasi provisores fiunt. Et in his quae de Domino loquuntur in semetipsis virtutum divitias ostendunt, ut tanto citius ad sequendum Deum pertrahant, quanto auditoribus suis in semetipsis monstrant quae narrant.
chunks.english: Holy men, when they deliver the word of preaching to good minds, become as it were providers for each soul to be joined to the only-begotten Son. And in the things they speak about the Lord, they show in themselves the riches of virtues, so that they may draw others more quickly to following God, inasmuch as they show to their hearers in themselves what they narrate.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unusquisque sanctae fidei praedicator in semetipso gestans ornamenta virtutum, et auditum Sanctae Ecclesiae scilicet per discretionis obedientiam componit, et manus per bonae operationis meritum exornat. Unicuique praedicatori, quasi ad manendum locus spatiosus est in auditoris corde, latitudo bonitatis.
chunks.english: Each preacher of holy faith, bearing in himself the ornaments of virtues, both arranges the hearing of the holy Church through obedience of discretion and adorns the hands through the merit of good work. For each preacher, the breadth of goodness is like a spacious place for dwelling in the hearer's heart.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde et quibusdam dicitur: Capite nos, neminem laesimus, neminem corrupimus. Non angustiamini in nobis, angustiamini autem in visceribus vestris (II Cor. VI, 12). Ac si eis aperte diceretur: Ad suscipiendam doctrinam spatiosum locum mentis facite; sed ad cogitanda carnalia angusti remanete.
chunks.english: Hence to certain ones it is said: Receive us, we have wronged no one, we have corrupted no one. You are not restricted by us, but you are restricted in your own affections, from Paul's second letter to the Corinthians, chapter six, verse twelve. It is as if it were openly said to them: Make a spacious place of mind for receiving doctrine, but remain narrow for thinking carnal thoughts.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt plerique qui doctores suos ex temporalibus stipendiis continere parati sunt, sed praedicatores sancti percipere nolunt temporalia, nisi prius obtineant aeterna. Si enim in animabus fructum non inveniunt, sumere stipendia corporalia contemnunt. Praedicatores sancti, cum praedicando vitam audientium obtinent, illi mox gratias reddunt de cujus hoc munere perceperunt, ut sibi in ea operatione nil tribuant, sed Auctori omnium cum lucris animarum gratiarum actiones reportent.
chunks.english: There are many who are prepared to support their teachers with temporal wages, but holy preachers do not wish to receive temporal things unless they first obtain eternal things. For if they do not find fruit in souls, they disdain to receive bodily wages. Holy preachers, when they obtain the life of their hearers through preaching, immediately give thanks to him from whose gift they have received this, so that they attribute nothing to themselves in that work, but report acts of thanksgiving with the gains of souls to the Author of all.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Praedicatores sancti, quamvis jam ad superiora intelligenda atque proferenda, et intellectu, et vita emicent, adhuc tamen in semetipsis contradictionem carnis sentiunt. Nam vident aliam legem in membris suis repugnantem legi mentis suae, et captivos reducen in lege peccati (Rom. VII, 23). Quia ne magnitudo revelationum extollat eos, datus est eis stimulus carnis suae (II Cor. XII). Habent praedicatores sancti thesaurum in vasis fictilibus, ut sublimitas sit virtutis Dei, et non ex ipsis.
chunks.english: Holy preachers, although they now shine forth both in understanding and in life for understanding and proclaiming higher things, nevertheless still feel in themselves the contradiction of the flesh. For they see another law in their members fighting against the law of their mind and making them captive to the law of sin, as Paul's letter to the Romans, chapter seven, verse twenty-three states. Because lest the greatness of revelations exalt them, there has been given to them a thorn in their flesh, from Paul's second letter to the Corinthians, chapter twelve. Holy preachers have treasure in earthen vessels, so that the sublimity may be of God's power and not from themselves.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui enim per carnem coelestia loquuntur, et tamen adhuc in carne contradictionem de vitio sentiunt, quid aliud quam super tortuosa camelorum dorsa divitias ferunt?
chunks.english: For those who speak of heavenly things through the flesh, yet still feel contradiction from vice in the flesh, what else do they do but carry riches on the twisted backs of camels?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Praedicatores sancti plus volunt Deum diligi, quam timeri; sed si timorem non insinuant, ad amorem dilectionis intimae non perducunt. Unde prius terribilia, et postmodum dulcia loqui solent. Sicut per Psalmistam dicitur: Virtutem terribilium tuorum dicent: et magnitudinem tuam narrabunt (Ps. CXLVI, 6).
chunks.english: Holy preachers prefer that God be loved rather than feared. But if they do not instill fear, they do not lead to the love of intimate affection. Hence they customarily speak first of terrible things and afterward of sweet things. As it is said through the Psalmist: They will speak of the power of your terrible deeds, and they will narrate your greatness, from the one hundred forty-sixth Psalm, verse six.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. VII, c. 4, n. 4.) Sanctae praedicationis eloquia aliquando sagittis exprimuntur, quia in eo quod vitia feriunt male viventium corda transfigunt. De his sagittis venienti Redemptori dicitur: Sagittae tuae acutae, potentissime, populi sub te cadent in corde (Ps. XLIV, 6). De quo Isaias dicit: Mittam ex eis, qui salvati fuerint, ad gentes in mare, in Africam, in Lydiam, tenentes sagittam, in Italiam, et in Graeciam (Isai. LXVI, 19).
chunks.english: The utterances of holy preaching are sometimes expressed as arrows, because in that they strike vices they pierce through the hearts of those living badly. Of these arrows it is said to the coming Redeemer: Your arrows are sharp, most powerful one; peoples will fall under you in their hearts, from the forty-fourth Psalm, verse six. Of this Isaiah says: I will send from those who have been saved to the nations, to the sea, to Africa, to Lydia, holding arrows, to Italy and to Greece, from the book of Isaiah, chapter sixty-six, verse nineteen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scriptum est: Domine, inclina caelos tuos, et descende (Ps. CXLIII, 5). [Moral. lib. XXX, c. 13, n. 48]. Qui ergo coelorum nomine nisi praedicatorum ordo signatur? Nisi ergo praedicatores sancti ab illa summitate contemplationis internae quam capiunt, ad infirmitatem nostram humillima praedicatione, quasi quadam inclinatione, descenderent, nunquam utique in fide filios gignerent. Nobis quippe prodesse non possent, si in suae altitudinis erectione persisterent.
chunks.english: It is written: Lord, bend down your heavens and descend, from the one hundred forty-third Psalm, verse five. Who therefore is signified by the name of heavens but the order of preachers? Unless therefore holy preachers were to descend from that summit of internal contemplation which they attain to our weakness through most humble preaching, as by a certain bending down, they would never beget children in faith. Indeed they could not benefit us if they persisted in the erectness of their own height.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sancti viri, si cuncta praedicare vellent quae capiunt, cum in superna contemplatione debriantur, et non magis scientiam suam quodam moderamine et sobrietate temperarent, adhuc angusto intelligentiae sinu illa superni fontis fluenta quis caperet? Cum se in praedicatione sua sancti doctores attrabunt, divinitatis notitiam nostris cordibus infundunt. Nequaquam quippe ad nos Deus descenderet, si praedicatores ejus in contemplationis rigore inflexibiles permanerent.
chunks.english: If holy men wished to preach all that they grasp when they are intoxicated in heavenly contemplation, and did not rather temper their knowledge with a certain moderation and sobriety, who in the still narrow bosom of understanding could grasp those streams of the heavenly fountain? When holy teachers draw themselves back in their preaching, they pour the knowledge of divinity into our hearts. For God would by no means descend to us if his preachers remained unbending in the rigor of contemplation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Inclinantur coeli, ut descendat Dominus, quia incurvantur praedicatores sancti ut nos in nova fidei luce nascamur. Quoniam si nostrae infirmitati non condescenderent, nos ad suam celsitudinem nunquam levarent. Lex est praedicatoribus posita, ut vivendo impleant quod loquendo suadere festinant; nam loquendi auctoritas perditur, quando vox opere non adjuvatur.
chunks.english: The heavens are bent that the Lord may descend, because holy preachers are bowed down that we may be born in the new light of faith. Since if they did not condescend to our weakness, they would never raise us to their own height. A law is placed upon preachers, that they fulfill by living what they hasten to persuade by speaking. For the authority of speaking is lost when the voice is not supported by action.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXIII, c. 1, n. 8.) Sanctae universalis Ecclesiae spiritualis quisque praedicator in cunctis quae dicit solerti cura se inspicit, ne in eo quod recta praedicat vitio se elationis extollat, ne vita a lingua discordet, ne pacem quam in Ecclesia annuntiat, in seipso, dum bene docet et male vivit, amittat.
chunks.english: Each spiritual preacher of the holy universal Church inspects himself with careful attention in all that he says, lest in what he rightly preaches he exalt himself by the vice of pride, lest his life disagree with his tongue, lest he lose in himself the peace he announces in the Church when he teaches well but lives badly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Studet summopere sanctus praedicator contra maledicos rumores adversantium et defendere loquendo quod vivit, et ornare vivendo quod dicit. Nec in his omnibus suam, sed Auctoris gloriam quaerit, atque omnem sapientiae gratiam, quam, ut loqueretur, accepit, non suis se aestimat meritis, sed eorum intercessionibus pro quibus loquitur, accepisse.
chunks.english: The holy preacher strives with utmost effort both to defend by speaking what he lives and to adorn by living what he says against the slanderous rumors of adversaries. Nor in all these things does he seek his own glory but the Author's, and he esteems that he has received all the grace of wisdom, which he received that he might speak, not by his own merits but by the intercessions of those for whom he speaks.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Electus quisque praedicator dum se infra per humilitatem dejicit, superest, quia suae nimirum magis mercedi proficit, quod bona quae exercere praevalet alienis meritis reddit. Indignum se omnibus judicat, etiam cum dignus cunctis vivat. Optime novit praedicator quod bona quae innotescunt hominibus, sine periculo esse vix possunt. Et quamvis sapientem esse se sentiat, vellet tamen esse sapiens, nec videri, atque hoc sibi omnimodo, quod loquendo proditur, pertimescit.
chunks.english: Each chosen preacher surpasses himself when he casts himself down through humility, because he profits more for his own reward by attributing to the merits of others the good things he is able to accomplish. He judges himself unworthy of all, even when he lives worthily for all. The preacher knows very well that good things made known to people can scarcely be without danger. And although he perceives himself to be wise, he would nevertheless prefer to be wise and not be seen as such, and he fears in every way this exposure that comes through speaking.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et si liceat, tacere appetit, dum esse multis tutius silentium cernit, eosque esse feliciores putat quos intra sanctam Ecclesiam locus inferior per silentium occultat. Dum ad loquendum praedicator vi charitatis impellitur, ex necessitate quidem officium locutionis suscipit; sed ex magno desiderio otium taciturnitatis quaerit. Hoc servat voto, illud exercet ministerio. Hanc autem dicendi formulam arrogantes ignorant; neque enim loquuntur quia causae eveniunt, sed causas evenire appetunt ut loquantur.
chunks.english: And if it were permitted, he desires to be silent, since he sees that silence is safer for many, and he considers those happier whom a lower place within the holy Church conceals through silence. While the preacher is compelled to speaking by the force of charity, he undertakes the duty of speaking from necessity, but he seeks the leisure of silence from great desire. He keeps this in his wish, he exercises that in his ministry. But the arrogant do not know this manner of speaking; for they do not speak because occasions arise, but they desire occasions to arise so that they may speak.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Ibid. c. 10, n. 17.) Praedicatores sancti hanc partem suam reputant, si intus quidem ipsi de sapientia gaudeant, foris autem alios ab errore compescant. Neque a se ita loquendo exeunt, ut gaudium mentis in ostensione ponant disertae locutionis; sed bonum scientiae in cordis secreto meditantur, et ibi gaudent ubi hoc percipiunt, non ubi inter tot tentationum laqueos innotescere compelluntur.
chunks.english: Holy preachers consider this their portion, if indeed they themselves rejoice inwardly about wisdom, but outwardly restrain others from error. Nor do they so depart from themselves in speaking that they place the joy of mind in the display of eloquent speech; but they meditate on the good of knowledge in the secret of the heart, and they rejoice there where they perceive it, not where they are compelled to make it known among so many snares of temptations.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum praedicatores bonum quod accipiunt innotescunt, media interveniente charitate, ex profectu audientium et non ex propria ostensione gratulantur.
chunks.english: When preachers make known the good they have received, with charity intervening in the middle, they rejoice from the progress of their hearers and not from their own display.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Ibid. c. 11, n. 28.) Saepe contingit ut sapientes viri, cum se non audiri considerant, ori suo silentium indicant. Sed plerumque dum conspiciunt quod iniquorum facinora, ipsis tacentibus et non corripientibus, crescunt, vim quamdam spiritus sui sustinent, ut in locutionem apertae correptionis erumpant.
chunks.english: It often happens that wise men, when they consider that they are not being heard, impose silence on their mouth. But frequently when they observe that the wicked deeds of the unrighteous grow while they remain silent and do not rebuke, they sustain a certain force of their spirit so that they burst forth into speech of open correction.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Propheta Jeremias, cum sibi praedicationis silentium indixisset, dicens: Non recordabor ejus, neque loquar ultra in nomine illius, illico adjunxit: Et factus est in corde meo quasi ignis exaestuans, claususque in ossibus meis, et defeci, ferre non sustinens: audivi enim contumelias multorum (Jer, XX, 9).
chunks.english: The prophet Jeremiah, when he had imposed on himself silence from preaching, saying: I will not remember him, nor will I speak anymore in his name, immediately added: And there was in my heart as it were a burning fire shut up in my bones, and I was weary, not able to bear it, for I heard the reproaches of many. This is from the book of Jeremiah, chapter twenty, verse nine.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Inflammantur quippe corda justorum, cum non correpta crescere conspiciunt acta malorum, eorumque culpae se participes credunt quos in iniquitate crescere silendo permittunt. David propheta postquam sibi silentium indixerat, dicens: Posui ori meo custodiam, dum consisteret peccator adversum me, obmutui et humiliatus sum, et silui a bonis (Ps. XXXIII, 2); in ipso suo silentio isto zelo charitatis exarsit, qui illico subdidit: Et dolor meus renovatus est: concaluit cor meum intra me, et in meditatione mea exardescet ignis (Ibid. 4).
chunks.english: The hearts of the just are inflamed when they see the uncorrected deeds of the wicked growing, and they believe themselves participants in the guilt of those whom they permit to grow in iniquity by remaining silent. The prophet David, after he had imposed silence on himself, saying: I set a guard to my mouth when the sinner stood against me, I was dumb and humbled and kept silence from good things, from the thirty-third Psalm, verse two, in that very silence of his burned with this zeal of charity, and immediately added: And my pain was renewed; my heart grew hot within me, and in my meditation fire will burn, from the same Psalm, verse four.
chunks.notes: The verse references appear to be Psalm 39 (38 Vulgate), not 33

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Intus cor caluit, quia dilectionis ardor per admonitionem locutionis exterius emanare recusavit. (Moral. XXX, c. 2, n. 6). Ignis in meditatione cordis exarsit, quia increpatio delinquentium a correptione oris frixit.
chunks.english: The heart grew hot within, because the ardor of love refused to emanate outwardly through the admonition of speech. Fire burned in the meditation of the heart, because rebuke of offenders cooled from correction by the mouth.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sancti praedicatores verbis suis quasi quibusdam jaculis adversarios feriunt, armis vero, id est miraculis, semetipsos tuentur; ut et quantum sint audiendi sonent per impetum jaculorum, et quantum sint reverendi clarescant per arma miraculorum.
chunks.english: Holy preachers strike their adversaries with their words as with certain javelins, but they protect themselves with arms, that is, with miracles, so that both how much they should be heard may sound through the assault of javelins, and how much they should be revered may shine clear through the arms of miracles.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Evang. homil. 11, n. 4.) Ille in sancta Ecclesia doctus praedicator est qui et nova scit proferre de suavitate regni, et vetusta dicere de terrore supplicii, ut vel poenae terreant quos praemia non invitant. Audiat de regno quod amet, audiat de supplicio unusquisque quod timeat: ut torpentem animum et terrae vehementer inhaerentem si amor ad regnum non trahit, timor minet aeterni supplicii.
chunks.english: That one is a learned preacher in the holy Church who both knows how to bring forth new things about the sweetness of the kingdom and to speak old things about the terror of punishment, so that either penalties may terrify those whom rewards do not invite. Let each one hear about the kingdom that he may love, let him hear about punishment that he may fear, so that if love does not draw the sluggish soul clinging vehemently to earth toward the kingdom, fear may threaten eternal punishment.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Reg. Past., part. I, c. 7.) Praedicationis officium nonnulli laudabiliter appetunt, et ad hoc nonnulli laudabiliter coacti pertrahuntur. Quod liquide agnoscimus, si duorum prophetantium facta pensamus, quorum unus ut ad praedicandum mitti debuisset sponte se praebuit, quo tamen alter pergere cum pavore recusavit.
chunks.english: Some laudably desire the office of preaching, and to this some are laudably drawn though compelled. We clearly recognize this if we consider the deeds of two prophets, one of whom freely offered himself that he should be sent to preach, to which the other refused to go with fear.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Isaias Domino quaerenti quem mitteret ultro se obtulit, dicens: Ecce ego, mitte me (Isa. VI, 8). Jeremias autem mittitur, et tamen ne mitti debeat, humiliter reluctatur, dicens: A, a, a, Domine Deus, ecce nescio loqui, quia puer ego sum (Jer. I, 6).
chunks.english: Isaiah offered himself freely to the Lord seeking whom he should send, saying: Here I am, send me, from the book of Isaiah, chapter six, verse eight. But Jeremiah is sent, and yet humbly resists that he should be sent, saying: Ah, ah, ah, Lord God, behold I do not know how to speak, for I am a child, from the book of Jeremiah, chapter one, verse six.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: En ab utrisque exterius diversa vox prodiit, sed non a diverso fonte dilectionis emanavit. In utrisque prophetis subtiliter intuendum est quia et is qui recusavit plene non restitit, et is qui mitti voluit ante se per altaris calculum purgatum vidit; ne aut non purgatus adire quisque sacra mysteria audeat, aut quem superna gratia elegit, sub humilitatis specie superbe contradicat.
chunks.english: Behold from both a different voice came forth externally, but it did not emanate from a different fountain of love. In both prophets it must be subtly observed that both he who refused did not fully resist, and he who wished to be sent saw himself first purified by the coal from the altar, lest anyone dare to approach sacred mysteries unpurified, or lest one whom heavenly grace has chosen proudly contradict under the appearance of humility.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXIX, 26.) Scriptum est: Qui producit in montibus fenum, et herbam servituti hominum (Ps. CXLVI, 8, n. 52). Quid per herbam nisi sustentatio praedicantium demonstratur? In montibus quippe fenum, et servituti hominum herba producitur, cum sublimes hujus saeculi ad fidei cognitionem vocati, sanctis praedicatoribus in hujus vitae itinere spiritualiter sibi servientibus transitoria alimenta largiuntur.
chunks.english: It is written: Who produces hay on the mountains and grass for the service of people, from the one hundred forty-sixth Psalm, verse eight. What is demonstrated by grass except the sustenance of preachers? For hay is produced on the mountains and grass for the service of people when the lofty ones of this world, called to the knowledge of faith, bestow transitory foods on holy preachers serving them spiritually in the journey of this life.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXIX, c. 23, n. 47.) Plerumque etenim praedicatio ad aures venit, sed cessante interna gratia ad corde audientium non pertransit. De cujus praedicationis verbis propter electos dicitur: Etenim sagittae tuae pertransierunt (Ps. LXXVI, 19). Sagittae quippe Dei pertranseunt, quando verba praedicationis ejus ab auribus ad corda descendunt.
chunks.english: For frequently preaching comes to the ears, but when internal grace ceases it does not pass through to the hearts of the hearers. Of the words of this preaching it is said on account of the elect: For your arrows have passed through, from the seventy-sixth Psalm, verse nineteen. The arrows of God truly pass through when the words of his preaching descend from ears to hearts.
chunks.notes: Likely Psalm 77:17-18 in modern numbering

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Divine Mysteries and Miracles
chunks.latin: CAPUT XVIII. De mysteriis vel miraculis divinis.
chunks.english: Chapter 18: Divine Mysteries and Miracles

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 8, n. 10.) Divinae virtutis mysteria, quae comprehendi non possunt, non intellectu discutienda sunt, sed fide veneranda. Sciendum nobis est quia quidquid ratione hominis comprehendi potest, mirum esse jam non potest. Sed sola est in miraculis ratio, potentia facientis.
chunks.english: The mysteries of divine power, which cannot be comprehended, should not be discussed by understanding but venerated by faith. We must know that whatever can be comprehended by human reason can no longer be wonderful. But the sole reason in miracles is the power of the one performing them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech. homil. 5, n. 11.) Quantumlibet intenderit anima, nec semetipsam perfecte sufficit penetrare, quanto magis illius magnitudinem qui potuit et animam condere? Cum David propheta in scientiae Dei intellectu laboraret, lassescens ac deficiens ait: Mirabilis facta est scientia tua ex me, confortata est, nec potero ad eam (Ps. CXXXVIII, 6).
chunks.english: However much the soul may strive, it does not suffice to penetrate even itself perfectly; how much less the magnitude of him who was able to create the soul? When the prophet David labored in understanding God's knowledge, growing weary and failing he said: Your knowledge has become too wonderful for me, it is strengthened, and I cannot attain to it, from the one hundred thirty-eighth Psalm, verse six.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Lib. I in Ev., hom. 2, n. 1.] Miracula Domini et Salvatoris nostri sic accipienda sunt, ut et in veritate credantur facta, et tamen per significationem nobis aliquid innuant. Opera Redemptoris nostri et per potentiam aliquid ostendunt, et per mysterium aliquid loquuntur.
chunks.english: The miracles of our Lord and Savior are to be received in such a way that they are both believed to have been done in truth, and yet through their significance they indicate something to us. The works of our Redeemer both show something through power and speak something through mystery.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod bene caecus ille significat, qui mendicans juxta viam sedebat (Luc. XXVIII, 35). Dum igitur Conditor noster appropinquat Jericho, caecus ad lumina redit: quia dum Divinitas defectum nostrae carnis suscepit, humanum genus lumen quod amiserat recepit. Unde enim Deus humana patitur, inde homo ad divina sublevatur.
chunks.english: This is well signified by that blind man who sat begging beside the road, as the Gospel of Luke, chapter twenty-eight, verse thirty-five relates. Therefore when our Creator approached Jericho, the blind man returned to sight, because when the Divinity took on the defect of our flesh, the human race received the light it had lost. For from whence God suffers human things, thence is humanity raised to divine things.
chunks.notes: This should be Luke 18:35, not 28:35

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ezech. homil. 5, n. 12.) Perfecti viri contemplatione mentis mysterium suavitatis intimae quia utcunque possunt, velut ex quodam corusco, praegustando tangere, ejus memoriam student recolendo semper et loquendo eructare. Unde apte nos Psalmista admonet dicens: Lux orta est justis, et rectis corde laetitia. Laetamini justi in Domino, et confitemini memoriae sanctitatis ejus (Ps. XCVI, 11).
chunks.english: Perfect men, because they can somehow touch the mystery of intimate sweetness by tasting it beforehand through contemplation of mind, as from a certain flash of lightning, strive always to recall its memory and to pour it forth by speaking. Hence the Psalmist aptly admonishes us saying: Light has risen for the just, and joy for the upright of heart. Rejoice, you just, in the Lord, and give praise to the memory of his holiness, from the ninety-sixth Psalm, verse eleven.
chunks.notes: Likely Psalm 97:11-12 in modern numbering

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Lib. II in Evang., hom. 22, n. 8.] Hoc quod de mysterio incarnationis Christi intelligere et penetrare non possumus, potestati sancti Spiritus humiliter reservamus, ut non superbe quis audeat vel contemnere, vel denuntiare quod non intelligit, sed hoc igni tradat quod sancto Spiritui reservat.
chunks.english: What we cannot understand and penetrate concerning the mystery of Christ's incarnation, we humbly reserve to the power of the Holy Spirit, so that no one may proudly dare either to despise or to denounce what he does not understand, but let him commit to the fire what he reserves to the Holy Spirit.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Holy Martyrs
chunks.latin: CAPUT XIX. De sanctis martyribus.
chunks.english: Chapter 19: The Holy Martyrs

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. III. c. 17, n. 32.) Nullus in hanc vitam electorum venit, qui non antiqui hostis adversa sustinuit. Membra autem nostri Redemptoris exstiterunt, etiam qui ab ipso mundi exordio, dum pie viverent, crudelia passi sunt. Membrum nostri Redemptoris Abel se esse perhibuit, qui ejus mortem de quo scriptum est: Sicut agnus coram tondente se obmutescet, et non aperiet os suum (Isa. LVII, 7), non solum placens in sacrificio, sed etiam moriens tacendo signavit.
chunks.english: None of the elect comes into this life who has not endured adversities from the ancient enemy. Moreover, they have been members of our Redeemer even those who from the very beginning of the world, while living piously, suffered cruel things. Abel showed himself to be a member of our Redeemer, who signified his death, of whom it is written: Like a lamb before its shearer he will be silent and will not open his mouth, from the book of Isaiah, chapter fifty-seven, verse seven, not only pleasing in sacrifice but also by dying in silence.
chunks.notes: This should be Isaiah 53:7

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ab ipso mundi exordio Redemptoris nostri corpus antiquus hostis expugnare conatus est, qui ab hominibus primis [Edit., puris] inchoans usque ad ipsum caput Ecclesiae saeviendo pervenit.
chunks.english: From the very beginning of the world the ancient enemy attempted to destroy the body of our Redeemer, who beginning from the first pure men advanced by raging all the way to the very head of the Church.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. III, c. 21, n. 50.) Sancti martyres tribulationum bello deprehensi, cum uno eodemque tempore alios ferientes atque alios suadentes ferunt, illis opponunt scutum patientiae, istis jacula intorquent doctrinae. Insurgentes hostes martyres patiendo despiciunt, infirmantes vero cives compatiendo ad salutem reducunt. Illis resistunt, ne alios subtrahant; istos metuunt, ne vitam rectitudinis funditus perdant.
chunks.english: The holy martyrs, caught in the warfare of tribulations, when at one and the same time they endure some striking them and some persuading them, oppose to those the shield of patience, against these they hurl the javelins of doctrine. The martyrs scorn rising enemies by suffering, but they bring back wavering citizens to salvation by compassion. They resist those lest they draw away others; they fear for these lest they utterly lose the life of righteousness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 40.) Videamus castrorum Dei militem Paulum apostolum contra utraque praeliantem. Foris, inquit, pugnae, intus timores (II Cor. VII, 5). Sancti martyres ad utraque se solerter extendunt, et cum tribulationibus fortasse feriuntur, sic exteriora bella suscipiunt, ut sollicite cogitent ne proximorum interiora lacerentur. Sic sancti viri fortes in acie bellandi assistunt, ut illinc jaculis adversantia pectora feriant, hinc scuto postpositos debiles tueantur, atque ita utrobique velocitate circumspectionis invigilant; quatenus et ante se audaces confodiant, et post se trepidos a vulnere defendant.
chunks.english: Let us see Paul the apostle, soldier of God's camp, fighting against both. He says: Outside, conflicts; inside, fears, from Paul's second letter to the Corinthians, chapter seven, verse five. The holy martyrs skillfully extend themselves toward both, and when they are perhaps struck with tribulations, they thus undertake exterior battles that they solicitously think lest the interiors of their neighbors be torn. Thus holy men strong in the battle line stand ready, that on one side they may strike opposing breasts with javelins, on the other side they may protect with shield the weak placed behind, and thus they keep watch on both sides with swiftness of circumspection, so that both before themselves they may strike down the bold, and behind themselves they may defend the trembling from wounds.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXX, 25, n. 74.) Cum his electis Dominus noster adversarios fidei destruit, cum his ad praedicationis bella descendit, qui possunt divina cognoscere, qui sciunt de Trinitate, quae Deus est, perfecta sentire. Cum illis Christus contra hostes fidei pergit ad praelium, qui cum doctrinae fluenta hauriunt, rectitudinem operum non inflectunt. Ipsi cum Christo duce ad bellum prodeunt, qui hoc quod ore annuntiant opere ostendunt, qui fluenta doctrinae spiritaliter hauriunt, nec tamen in pravis operibus carnaliter inflectuntur.
chunks.english: With these elect ones our Lord destroys the adversaries of faith, with these he descends to the battles of preaching, who can know divine things, who know how to have perfect understanding about the Trinity, which is God. Christ goes to battle against the enemies of faith with those who, when they drink the streams of doctrine, do not bend the rectitude of their works. These go forth to war with Christ as leader, who show by their work what they announce with their mouth, who drink the streams of doctrine spiritually, yet are not bent carnally in wicked works.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num 75.) Tales secum dux noster ad praedicationis praelium adduxit, qui, despecta salute corporum, hostes suos moriendo prosternerent, eorumque gladios non armis et gladiis, sed patientia superarent. Armati venerunt sub duce suo ad praelium martyres nostri, sed cum tubis, lagenis et lampadibus. Qui sonuerunt tubis, dum praedicant; confregerunt lagenas, dum solvenda in passione sua corpora hostilibus gladiis opponunt. Resplenduerunt lampadibus, dum post solutionem corporum miraculis coruscaverunt.
chunks.english: Our leader brought with him to the battle of preaching such men who, despising the safety of their bodies, would prostrate their enemies by dying and would overcome their swords not with arms and swords but with patience. Our martyrs came armed to battle under their leader, but with trumpets, jars, and lamps. They sounded with trumpets when they preached; they broke the jars when they opposed their bodies, to be destroyed in their passion, to hostile swords. They shone with lamps when after the dissolution of their bodies they gleamed with miracles.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Moxque hostes in fugam versi sunt, quia dum mortuorum martyrum corpora miraculis coruscare conspiciunt, luce veritatis fracti, quod impugnaverunt crediderunt. Cecinerunt tubis milites nostri, ut lagenae frangerentur. Lagenae fractae sunt, ut lampades apparerent. Apparuerunt lampades, ut hostes in fugam verterentur; id est praedicaverunt martyres, donec eorum corpora in morte solverentur. Corpora eorum in morte soluta sunt, ut miraculis coruscarent: coruscaverunt miraculis, ut hostes suos ex divina luce prosternerent, quatenus nequaquam Deo erecti resisterent, sed eum subditi formidarent.
chunks.english: And immediately the enemies were turned to flight, because while they beheld the bodies of the dead martyrs gleaming with miracles, broken by the light of truth, they believed what they had attacked. Our soldiers sounded with trumpets that the jars might be broken. The jars were broken that the lamps might appear. The lamps appeared that the enemies might be turned to flight. That is, the martyrs preached until their bodies were dissolved in death. Their bodies were dissolved in death that they might gleam with miracles; they gleamed with miracles that they might prostrate their enemies with divine light, so that they might by no means resist God standing erect, but might fear him in subjection.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 77.) Christi martyres pro magno habent praedicationis gratiam, corporum vero utilitatem pro minimo. Quisquis enim plus facit utilitatem corporis quam gratiam praedicationis, in sinistra tubam atque in dextra lagenam tenet. Si enim priori loco gratia praedicationis attenditur, et posteriori utilitas corporis, certum est quia dextris tubae, et sinistris lagenae teneantur.
chunks.english: The martyrs of Christ hold the grace of preaching as great, but the usefulness of bodies as least. For whoever makes the usefulness of the body more than the grace of preaching holds the trumpet in the left hand and the jar in the right. For if the grace of preaching is attended to in the first place and the usefulness of the body in the second place, it is certain that trumpets are held in the right hands and jars in the left.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum in morte passionis pro veritate justus efficitur, in aeternae vitae viriditate recuperatur; et qui hic virebat per fidem, illic virescit per speciem. Plerumque ex passione justi fideles quique ad amorem coelestis patriae multiplicantur, et viriditatem spiritalis vitae accipiunt, dum hunc pro Deo fortiter egisse gratulantur. Exstincto corporaliter justo, ipso suae passionis exemplo multorum corda suscitare, et ex fidei rectitudine viriditatem ostendere certissimum est.
chunks.english: When a just person is made in the death of passion for truth, he is recovered in the greenness of eternal life; and he who flourished here through faith, there flourishes through sight. Often from the passion of the just, each of the faithful are multiplied in love of the heavenly homeland and receive the greenness of spiritual life, while they rejoice that he acted bravely for God. When a just person is extinguished bodily, it is most certain that by the very example of his passion he raises up the hearts of many and shows greenness from the rectitude of faith.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XIII, c. 13, n. 16.) Sanctus Ecclesiae populus, cum adversa graviter perpeti coeperit, et infirmos suos conspexerit ad deteriora delabi, pacis suae tempora ad mentem revocat, quando fideles suos praedicationis suae opulentia pascebat. Unde apte per beatum Job figuraliter dicitur: Ego ille quondam opulentus repente contritus sum (Job. XVI, 13).
chunks.english: The holy people of the Church, when they have begun to suffer adversities grievously and have seen their weak ones slip toward worse things, recall to mind the times of their peace when they fed their faithful ones with the abundance of their preaching. Hence it is aptly said figuratively through blessed Job: I who was once wealthy am suddenly crushed, from the book of Job, chapter sixteen, verse thirteen.
chunks.notes: Likely verse 12, not 13

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Moral. lib. XIII, c. 44, n. 17.] In eo quod se repente contritum asseruit, infirmorum mentem improvidam designavit. Qui dum mala quae ventura sunt praevidere nesciunt, tanto eis graviora fiunt, quanto et ab eis inopinata tolerantur. Electus quisque martyrium, quod per infirmitatem carnis non vult, per virtutem spiritus amat. Quidam per carnem ad poenas trepidat, per spiritum ad gloriam exsultat. Unusquisque cruciatum martyrii nolendo vult, et odiendo amat, sicut nos quoque, cum gaudium quaerimus salutis, amarum poculum sumimus purgationis. Amaritudo quidem in poculo displicet, sed restituenda per amaritudinem salus placet.
chunks.english: In that he asserted himself suddenly crushed, he designated the improvident mind of the weak. Who, while they do not know how to foresee the evils that are to come, they become so much more grievous to them as they are also endured unexpectedly by them. Each chosen one loves martyrdom through the virtue of the spirit, which he does not want through the weakness of the flesh. A certain one trembles through the flesh toward punishments, through the spirit exults toward glory. Each one by not willing wills the torture of martyrdom, and by hating loves it, just as we also, when we seek the joy of salvation, we take the bitter cup of purgation. Indeed the bitterness in the cup displeases, but the health to be restored through bitterness pleases.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. IV, c. 16, n. 30.) Voce sanctorum martyrum per Psalmistam dicitur: Humiliasti nos in loco afflictionis, et operuit nos umbra mortis (Ps. XLIII, 20). Umbra igitur mortis mors carnis accipitur, quia sicut vera mors est qua anima separatur a Deo, ita umbra mortis est qua caro separatur ab anima. Quos constat non spiritu, sed sola carne mori, nequaquam se vera morte, sed umbra dicunt mortis operiri.
chunks.english: In the voice of the holy martyrs it is said through the Psalmist: You have humbled us in the place of affliction, and the shadow of death has covered us, from the forty-third Psalm, verse twenty. Therefore the shadow of death is understood as the death of the flesh, because just as true death is that by which the soul is separated from God, so the shadow of death is that by which the flesh is separated from the soul. Those who are known to die not in spirit but in flesh alone say by no means that they are covered with true death but with the shadow of death.
chunks.notes: Likely Psalm 44:19 in modern numbering

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXXIII, c. 3, n. 6.) Umbra enim mortis electos Dei opprimit, cum mors carnis, quae imago mortis aeternae est, ab hac eos vita disjungit; quia sicut illa a Deo animam, ita haec ab anima separat corpus.
chunks.english: For the shadow of death oppresses the elect of God when the death of the flesh, which is the image of eternal death, separates them from this life, because just as that separates the soul from God, so this separates the body from the soul.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XX, c. 27, n. 56.) Locus afflictionis est vita praesens. Martyres ergo sancti in hoc loco afflictionis humiliati sum, quia in aeterna vita, id est in loco gaudii, sublimantur. (Moral. XXVI, c. 28, n. 54.) Qui ergo ad aeternam patriam tendunt, nunc semetipsos temporaliter in afflictionis loco despiciunt, ut tunc in loco gaudii veraciter sublimentur.
chunks.english: The place of affliction is the present life. Therefore the holy martyrs are humbled in this place of affliction because they are exalted in eternal life, that is, in the place of joy. Those therefore who strive toward the eternal homeland now temporally despise themselves in the place of affliction, so that then they may be truly exalted in the place of joy.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Evang., homil. 3, n. 4.) Quamvis occasio persecutionis in hoc tempore pacis desit, habet tamen et pax nostra martyrium suum; quia etsi carnis collum ferro non subdimus, spiritali tamen gaudio carnalia desideria in mente trucidamus. (Lib. II in Ev., homil. 27, n. 9.) Nos igitur si pro Christo corpus in passione non ponimus, saltim tempore pacis animum vincamus. Placatur Deus isto sacrificio. Approbat in judicio pietatis suae victoriam pacis nostrae; certamen nostri cordis aspicit: et qui post vincentes remunerat, nunc decertantes juvat.
chunks.english: Although the occasion of persecution is lacking in this time of peace, nevertheless our peace also has its martyrdom, because even if we do not submit the neck of flesh to the sword, yet with spiritual joy we slaughter carnal desires in the mind.
