Therefore if we do not lay down our body in passion for Christ, at least in time of peace let us conquer our soul. God is appeased by this sacrifice. He approves in the judgment of his mercy the victory of our peace; he looks upon the struggle of our heart, and he who rewards after they have conquered now helps those fighting.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Persecutors of Martyrs
chunks.latin: CAPUT XX. De persecutoribus martyrum.
chunks.english: Chapter 20: The Persecutors of Martyrs

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XIII, c. 10, n. 12, 13.) Antiquus hostis Ecclesiae contra hanc quasi dentibus frendet, [Edit., fremit], eamque quasi terribilibus oculis intuetur; quia per alios crudelia exercet, et per alios quae exerceat providet. Dentes hujus hostis sunt bonorum persecutores, atque carnifices, qui Ecclesiae membra laniant, dum electos illius suis persecutionibus affligunt.
chunks.english: The ancient enemy of the Church gnashes his teeth against her, as it were, and gazes upon her as with terrible eyes, because through some he exercises cruelties, and through others he devises what he may exercise. The teeth of this enemy are the persecutors and executioners of the good, who tear the members of the Church while they afflict her elect with their persecutions.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Oculi antiqui hostis sunt hi qui contra eam provident mala quae faciant, suisque consiliis persecutorum ejus crudelitates inflammant. Antiquus Ecclesiae adversarius fremit contra Ecclesiam dentibus suis, dum per crudeles reprobos in ea insequitur vitam bonorum. Intuetur hanc terribilibus oculis, quia pravorum consiliis non cessat mala exquirere, in quibus hanc semper deterius affligat.
chunks.english: The eyes of the ancient enemy are those who devise evils to do against her and inflame the cruelties of her persecutors with their counsels. The ancient adversary of the Church rages against the Church with his teeth when through cruel reprobates he persecutes the life of the good in her. He gazes upon her with terrible eyes because through the counsels of the wicked he does not cease to seek out evils by which to afflict her always more severely.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Ibid. c. 11, n. 14; c. 12, n. 15; c. 13, n. 16.) Sciendum est quia illos praecipue in sancta Ecclesia reprobi persequuntur quos multis conspiciunt esse profuturos, qui vitam carnalium verbo correptionis conterunt, eosque in Ecclesiae corpore spiritaliter vertunt. Recte figuraliter beatus Job ait: Percusserunt maxillam meam, satiati sunt poenis meis (Job XVI, 11). Maxillam ergo Ecclesiae perversi feriunt, cum bonos praedicatores insequuntur.
chunks.english: It should be known that the reprobate especially persecute in the holy Church those whom they see will be beneficial to many, who crush the life of the carnal with the word of correction and spiritually convert them in the body of the Church. Blessed Job rightly says figuratively: They have struck my jaw, they are satisfied with my punishments, from the book of Job, chapter sixteen, verse eleven. Therefore the perverse strike the jaw of the Church when they persecute good preachers.
chunks.notes: Likely verse 10, not 11

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et quia tunc reprobi grande se aliquid fecisse aestimant, cum vitam praedicatorum necant, post percussionem maxillae apte subjungitur: Satiati sunt poenis meis. Illa quippe eos poena satiat quae mentem Ecclesiae praecipue castigat. Rursum scriptum est: Conclusit me Deus apud iniquum, et manibus impiorum me tradidit (Ibid. 12).
chunks.english: And because then the reprobate consider themselves to have done something great when they kill the life of preachers, after the striking of the jaw it is aptly added: They are satisfied with my punishments. For that punishment satisfies them which especially chastises the mind of the Church. Again it is written: God has shut me up with the wicked and has delivered me into the hands of the impious, from the same book, verse twelve.
chunks.notes: Likely verse 11, not 12

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Electorum populus apud iniquum concluditur, cum ejus caro antiqui hostis persecutionibus temporaliter datur. Qui non spiritui, sed manibus impiorum traditur; quia quo hunc in mente capere nequeunt, eo contra carnem illius crudelius inardescunt.
chunks.english: The people of the elect are shut up with the wicked when their flesh is temporally given to the persecutions of the ancient enemy. They are delivered not to the spirit but to the hands of the impious, because by how much they cannot capture him in mind, by so much more cruelly do they burn against his flesh.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. III, c. 25, n. 76.) Persecutores sanctae fidei martyribus adhuc in corpore positis restiterunt. Post solutionem vero corporum apparentibus miraculis, in fugam versi sunt; quia pavore conterriti a persecutione fidelium cessaverunt.
chunks.english: The persecutors of holy faith resisted the martyrs while they were still placed in the body. But after the dissolution of their bodies, when miracles appeared, they were turned to flight, because terrified by fear they ceased from persecuting the faithful.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Elect Who Abandon All to Judge with Christ
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXI. De electis omnia relinquentibus, et cum Christo judice venientibus.
chunks.english: Chapter 21: The Elect Who Abandon All to Judge with Christ

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Mor. X, c. 31, n. 52.) In fine saeculi cum Deo judices veniunt qui nunc pro Deo injuste judicantur. Tunc eorum lux tanto latius emicat, quanto eos nunc manus persequentium durius angustat. Tunc reproborum oculis patescet, quod coelesti potestate subnixi sunt qui terrena omnia sponte reliquerunt. Electis suis Veritas dicit: Vos, qui secuti estis me, in regeneratione, cum sederit Filius hominis in sede majestatis suae, sedebitis et vos super duodecim sedes, judicantes duodecim tribus Israel (Matth. XIV, 28).
chunks.english: At the end of the age those come as judges with God who now are unjustly judged for God. Then their light shines so much more widely as the hands of persecutors now more harshly constrict them. Then it will be revealed to the eyes of the reprobate that those who spontaneously abandoned all earthly things were supported by heavenly power. The Truth says to his elect: You who have followed me, in the regeneration, when the Son of Man sits on the throne of his majesty, you also will sit on twelve thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel, from the Gospel of Matthew, chapter fourteen, verse twenty-eight.
chunks.notes: This should be Matthew 19:28

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Neque enim plus quam duodecim judices illa interni consessus curia non habebit, sed nimirum duodenario numero quantitas universitatis exprimitur; quia quisquis stimulo divini amoris excitatus, hic possessa reliquerit, illic proculdubio culmen judiciariae potestatis obtinebit, ut simul tunc judex cum judice veniat qui nunc consideratione judicii sese spontanea paupertate castigat.
chunks.english: For that court of the internal assembly will not have more than twelve judges, but certainly by the number twelve the quantity of universality is expressed, because whoever, stirred by the goad of divine love, has abandoned possessions here, will without doubt there obtain the summit of judicial power, so that he who now chastises himself with voluntary poverty in consideration of judgment may then come as judge with the Judge.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: De sanctae Ecclesiae Sponso per Salomonem dicitur: Nobilis in portis vir ejus, quando sederit cum senatoribus terrae (Prov. XXXI, 23). Hinc Isaias ait: Dominus ad judicium veniet cum senioribus populi sui (Isai. III, 14). Hinc eosdem senatores Veritas, non jam famulos, sed amicos denuntiat, dicens: Non jam dicam vos servos, sed amicos (Joan. XV, 15).
chunks.english: Of the Spouse of the holy Church it is said through Solomon: Her husband is noble in the gates when he sits with the senators of the land, from the book of Proverbs, chapter thirty-one, verse twenty-three. Hence Isaiah says: The Lord will come to judgment with the elders of his people, from the book of Isaiah, chapter three, verse fourteen. Hence the Truth declares these same senators not now servants but friends, saying: I will no longer call you servants but friends, from the Gospel of John, chapter fifteen, verse fifteen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Moral XX, c. 16, n. 41.] Ecce relinquentes temporalia, gloriam potestatis aeternae mercati sunt. Quid itaque in hoc mundo stultius quam sua deserere? Et quid in aeternitate nobilius quam cum Deo judices venire?
chunks.english: Behold, abandoning temporal things, they have purchased the glory of eternal power. What therefore in this world is more foolish than to desert one's own things? And what in eternity is nobler than to come as judges with God?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral, VI, c. 7, n. 9.) Redemptor noster judicii sententiam cum sanctis Ecclesiae praedicatoribus decernit, sicut ipse in Evangelio dicit: Vos, qui reliquistis omnia, et secuti estis me, in regeneratione, cum sederit Filius hominis in sede majestatis suae, sedebitis et vos super duodecim sedes judicantes duodecim tribus Israel. Omnes qui in Ecclesia modo perfecti sunt, perfectionis suae rectitudinem per Evangelium didicerunt.
chunks.english: Our Redeemer decrees the sentence of judgment with the holy preachers of the Church, as he himself says in the Gospel: You who have left all and followed me, in the regeneration, when the Son of Man sits on the throne of his majesty, you also will sit on twelve thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel. All who are now perfect in the Church have learned the rectitude of their perfection through the Gospel.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil 2, n. 18.) Redemptori ergo nostro uniti ejusque majestati conjuncti, cum eo judices videbuntur qui modo perfecta opera juxta evangelica praecepta secuti sunt. Qui in hoc saeculo praeceptis Domini paruit, cum illo postmodum ad judicandos populos judex venit, sicut cuncta relinquentibus dicitur: Sedebitis et vos super duodecim thronos, judicantes duodecim tribus Israel.
chunks.english: Therefore united to our Redeemer and joined to his majesty, they will be seen as judges with him who now have followed perfect works according to evangelical precepts. He who in this age obeyed the precepts of the Lord afterward comes as judge with him to judge peoples, as it is said to those abandoning all: You also will sit on twelve thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XI, c. 22, n. 33.) Rectum quippe est, ut cum Deo de populis in judicio disputent qui ad verba Dei praesens saeculum perfecte derelinquunt: et illi cum Deo postmodum judices veniant qui ei modo in voluntaria paupertate vel in prece familiares exstiterint.
chunks.english: For it is right that those who perfectly abandon the present age at the words of God should dispute with God about peoples in judgment, and that those who now have been intimate with him in voluntary poverty or in prayer should afterward come as judges with God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XV, c. 31, n. 37.) Scriptum est: Advocavit coelos sursum, et terram, ut discerneret populum suum (Ps. XLIX, 4). Coelos quippe sursum advocat, cum hi qui sua omnia relinquentes, conversationem coelestis vitae tenuerunt, ad consedendum in judicio convocantur atque cum eo judices veniunt.
chunks.english: It is written: He has called the heavens above and the earth, that he might judge his people, from the forty-ninth Psalm, verse four. For he calls the heavens upward when those who, having abandoned all their things and maintained the way of life of heavenly living, are summoned to sit together in judgment and come as judges with him.
chunks.notes: Likely Psalm 50:4 in modern numbering

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Terra etiam sursum vocatur, cum hi qui terrenis actibus obligati fuerant, in eis tamen plus coelestia quam terrena lucra quaesierunt, quibus in fine dicitur: Hospes eram, et collegistis me; nudus, et operuistis me (Matth. XXV, 42).
chunks.english: The earth also is called upward when those who had been bound by earthly actions nevertheless sought in them more heavenly gains than earthly, to whom in the end it is said: I was a stranger and you took me in, I was naked and you clothed me, from the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-five, verse forty-two.
chunks.notes: This should be verses 35-36, not 42

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Moral. XXVI, c. 27, n. 51.] Electi viri omnia relinquentes non judicantur et regnant, qui etiam praecepta legis perfectionis virtute transcendunt; quia nequaquam hoc solum quod cunctis divina lex praecipit implere contenti sunt, sed praestantiori desiderio plus exhibere appetunt quam praeceptis generalibus audire potuerunt.
chunks.english: Elect men abandoning all things are not judged but reign, who also transcend the precepts of the law by the virtue of perfection, because they are by no means content to fulfill only what divine law commands to all, but by more excellent desire they seek to exhibit more than they could hear in general precepts.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Electi quique extremo judicio non judicantur et regnant, quia cum Auctore suo etiam judices veniunt. Relinquentes quippe omnia plus prompta devotione executi sunt, quam juberi generaliter audierunt. Speciali jussione paucis perfectioribus, et non generaliter omnibus, dicitur hoc quod adolescens dives audivit: Vade, vende omnia tua, et da pauperibus, et veni, sequere me (Matth. X, 21).
chunks.english: Each of the elect at the final judgment are not judged but reign, because they come also as judges with their Author. For those abandoning all things have accomplished more by ready devotion than they heard commanded generally. By special command to a few more perfect ones, and not generally to all, is said what the rich young man heard: Go, sell all your things and give to the poor, and come, follow me, from the Gospel of Matthew, chapter ten, verse twenty-one.
chunks.notes: This should be Matthew 19:21

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si enim sub hoc praecepto cunctos jussio generalis astringeret, culpa profecto esset aliquid nos de hoc mundo possidere. Sed aliud est quod per Scripturam sacram generaliter omnibus praecipitur, aliud quod specialiter perfectioribus imperatur. Justi omnia relinquentes recte sub generali judicio non tenentur, qui et praecepta generalia vivendo vicerunt.
chunks.english: For if a general command bound all under this precept, it would certainly be a sin for us to possess anything from this world. But it is one thing that is commanded generally to all through sacred Scripture, another that is commanded specially to the more perfect. The just abandoning all things are rightly not held under general judgment, who have also overcome general precepts by living.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sicut enim non judicantur et pereunt qui, suadente perfidia, lege teneri contemnunt, ita non judicantur et regnant qui, suadente pietate, etiam ultra generalia divinae legis praecepta proficiunt.
chunks.english: For just as those who, with treachery urging them, scorn to be bound by law are not judged but perish, so those who, with piety urging them, advance even beyond the general precepts of divine law are not judged but reign.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Paulus apostolus vas electionis specialia praecepta transcendens, plus opere exhibuit quam institutione permissionis accepit. Cum enim accepisset ut Evangelium praedicans de Evangelio viveret, et Evangelium audientibus contulit, et tamen Evangelii sumptibus sustentari recusavit. Cur ergo iste judicetur ut regnet qui minus quod servaret accepit, sed majus quod viveret invenit?
chunks.english: Paul the apostle, vessel of election, transcending special precepts, exhibited more in work than he received in the institution of permission. For when he had received that preaching the Gospel he should live from the Gospel, he both conferred the Gospel on those hearing and yet refused to be sustained by the expenses of the Gospel. Why therefore should he be judged in order that he may reign, who received less to keep but found greater things to live by?

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Interpreters of Divine Scripture
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXII. De tractatoribus divinarum Scripturarum.
chunks.english: Chapter 22: Interpreters of Divine Scripture

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Epist. nuncupat. ad Leand., c. 2.) Quisquis de Deo loquitur, curet necesse est ut quidquid audientium mores instruit rimetur; et hunc rectum loquendo ordinem deputet, si cum opportunitas aedificationis exigit, ab eo se, quod loqui coeperat, utiliter derivet. Sacri enim tractator eloquii morem fluminis debet imitari. Fluvius quippe dum per alveum defluit, si valles concavas ex latere contingit, in eas protinus sui impetus cursum divertit; cumque illas sufficienter impleverit, repente se in alveum refundit.
chunks.english: Whoever speaks about God must necessarily take care to examine whatever instructs the morals of his hearers, and he should consider this the right order in speaking, if when opportunity for edification requires, he usefully digresses from what he had begun to speak about. For the interpreter of sacred speech should imitate the manner of a river. Indeed a river, while it flows through its channel, if it touches hollow valleys from the side, immediately diverts the course of its current into them; and when it has sufficiently filled them, suddenly it pours itself back into the channel.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sic nimirum, sic divini verbi esse tractator debet, ut cum de qualibet re disserit, si fortasse juxta positam occasionem congruae aedificationis invenerit, quasi ad vicinam vallem linguae undas intorqueat. Et cum subjunctae instructionis campum sufficienter infuderit, ad sermonis propositi alveum recurrat.
chunks.english: Thus certainly, thus should the interpreter of the divine word be, that when he discusses any matter, if perhaps he finds near at hand an occasion for fitting edification, he may turn the waves of speech as to a neighboring valley. And when he has sufficiently flooded the field of instruction at hand, he may return to the channel of his proposed discourse.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ezech., homil. 7, n. 8.) Sancti viri in Scriptura sacra intelligunt quemadmodum moraliter vivant, et sese in contemplatione suspendant. Unusquisque tractatorum, quanto in sacra Scriptura profecerit, tanto eadem Scriptura proficit apud ipsum; quia divina eloquia cum legente crescunt. Nam tanto illa quisque altius intelligit, quanto in eis altius intendit; quia nisi legentium mentes ad alta profecerint, divina dicta velut in imis non intellecta jacent.
chunks.english: Holy men understand in sacred Scripture how they should live morally and raise themselves in contemplation. Each of the interpreters, by how much he has advanced in sacred Scripture, by so much does the same Scripture advance for him, because divine words grow with the reader. For one understands them so much more deeply as he directs himself more deeply into them, because unless the minds of readers have advanced to high things, divine sayings lie as if in the depths, not understood.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si quis aperuerit cisternam, et foderit, et non operuerit eam, cecideritque bos, vel asinus in eam, dominus cisternae reddet pretium jumentorum (Exod. XXI, 33). [Moral. XVII, c. 26, n. 38.] Quid namque est aperire cisternam, nisi intellectu valido Scripturae sacrae arcana penetrare? Quid namque per bovem et asinum, id est mundum immundumque animal, nisi fidelis quisque vel infidelis accipitur?
chunks.english: If anyone opens a cistern and digs it and does not cover it, and an ox or a donkey falls into it, the owner of the cistern will pay the price of the beasts, from the book of Exodus, chapter twenty-one, verse thirty-three. For what is opening a cistern but penetrating with strong understanding the secrets of sacred Scripture? For what is understood by ox and donkey, that is clean and unclean animal, but any faithful person or unbeliever?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui ergo cisternam fodit, cooperiat, ne illuc bos vel asinus ruat, id est, qui in sacro eloquio jam alta intelligit, sublimes sensus coram non capientibus per silentium tegat; ne per scandalum mentis, aut fidelem parvulum, aut infidelem, qui credere potuisset, interimat. Ex morte enim jumentorum debet pretium: quia illud scilicet amisisse [Edit., admisisse] convincitur, unde ad agendam poenitentiam reus tenetur.
chunks.english: Therefore he who digs a cistern, let him cover it lest an ox or donkey rush into it, that is, he who now understands high things in sacred speech, let him cover sublime meanings through silence before those not grasping them, lest through scandal of mind he kill either a little faithful one or an unbeliever who could have believed. For from the death of beasts he owes the price, because he is convicted of having lost that for which he is held guilty to do penance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quisquis ad alta scientiae fluenta perveniens, cum haec apud bruta audientium corda non contegit, poenae reus addicitur, si per verba ejus in scandalum sive munda seu immunda mens
chunks.english: Whoever, arriving at the high streams of knowledge, when he does not cover these things before the brutish hearts of hearers, is made liable to punishment if through his words either a clean or unclean mind
chunks.notes: Text appears to be cut off mid-sentence

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: capiatur. Coram infirmis et parvulis mentibus tegenda est alta scientia, ne unde cor docentium ad summa attollitur, inde infirmitas auditorum ad ima delabatur.
chunks.english: is captured. Before weak and childlike minds, higher knowledge must be concealed, lest the very thing that lifts the heart of teachers to the heights should cause the weakness of hearers to fall into the depths.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Epist. nunc. ad Leand., c. 3.) Quid veritatis dicta, nisi reficiendae mentis alimenta credenda sunt, quae modis alternantibus multipliciter disserendo, ferculum oris offerimus; ut invitati lectoris quasi convivae nostri fastidium repellamus? qui dum sibi multa oblata considerat, quod elegantius decernit, assumat.
chunks.english: As Gregory's letter to Leander explains, chapter three: What are the words of truth if not nourishment for restoring the mind, which we offer as a banquet of speech by discussing them in multiple alternating ways, so that we might dispel the distaste of the invited reader, who is like our dinner guest? When he sees many dishes set before him, he may choose whichever he judges more elegant.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aliquando exponere aperta historiae verba negligimus, ne tardius ad obscura veniamus; aliquando autem intelligi juxta litteram nequeunt, quia superficietenus accepta, nequaquam instructionem legentibus, sed errorem gignunt.
chunks.english: Sometimes we deliberately avoid expounding the clear words of the historical narrative, so that we may reach the obscure passages more quickly. At other times, passages cannot be understood according to the letter, because when taken only at the surface level, they produce not instruction for readers, but error.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Verba scilicet litterae, dum collata sibi convenire nequeunt, aliud in se aliquid quod quaeratur ostendunt, ac si quibusdam vocibus dicant: Dum nostra nos conspicitis superficie destrui, hoc in nobis quaerite, quod ordinatum sibique congruens apud nos valeat intus inveniri.
chunks.english: When the words of the letter cannot agree with one another when compared, they show that there is something else to be sought in them, as if they speak with certain voices saying: When you see us being demolished at our surface level, seek in us that which may be found within us, arranged and consistent with itself.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Ibid. c. 4.) Aliquando autem qui verba accipere historiae juxta litteram negligit, oblatum sibi veritatis lumen abscondit; cumque laboriose invenire in eis aliud intrinsecus appetit, hoc quod foris sine difficultate assequi poterat, amittit.
chunks.english: From the same letter, chapter four: Sometimes, however, whoever neglects to receive the words of history according to the letter hides from himself the light of truth that has been offered; and when he strives laboriously to find something else within them, he loses what he could have grasped on the outside without difficulty.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Divinus etenim sermo sicut mysteriis prudenter exercet, sic plerumque superficie simplices refovet. Habet in publico unde parvulos nutriat, servat in secreto unde mentes sublimium in admiratione suspendat.
chunks.english: For divine speech, just as it wisely exercises through mysteries, so it often refreshes the simple at its surface. It has openly that which nourishes the little ones; it preserves in secret that which holds the minds of the lofty in wonder.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quasi quidam quippe est fluvius, ut ita dixerim, planus et altus, in quo et agnus ambulet et elephas natet.
chunks.english: It is like a river, if I may say so, both shallow and deep, in which a lamb can walk and an elephant can swim.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ut ergo uniuscujusque loci opportunitas postulat, ita se per studium ordo expositionis immutat; quatenus tanto verius sensum divinae locutionis inveniat, quanto, ut res quaeque exegerit, per causarum species alternat.
chunks.english: Therefore, as the suitability of each place demands, so the order of exposition changes itself through careful attention, so that it may discover the meaning of divine speech all the more truly, as it alternates through different types of interpretation according to what each matter requires.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Per sacra eloquia ab eorum tractatoribus infructuose loquacitatis levitas studiose compescitur, dum in templo Dei nemus plantare prohibetur.
chunks.english: Through sacred Scripture, the frivolity of fruitless chatter is carefully restrained by those who expound it, since planting a grove in the temple of God is forbidden.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et cuncti procul dubio scimus, quia quoties in foliis male laetae segetis culmi proficiunt, minori plenitudine spicarum grana turgescunt.
chunks.english: And we all know without doubt that whenever the stalks of a poorly flourishing crop grow excessively in leaves, the grains swell with lesser fullness in the ears.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ezech., homil. 6, n. 1.) Scriptum est: Gloria regum celare verbum: et gloria Dei est investigare sermonem (Prov. XXV, 2); quia et honor est hominum eorum secreta abscondere, et gloria Dei est mysteria sermonis ejus aperire.
chunks.english: From Book one of the Homilies on Ezekiel, homily six, paragraph one: It is written in Proverbs, chapter twenty-five, verse two: The glory of kings is to conceal a matter, and the glory of God is to investigate a word. Because it is the honor of men to hide their secrets, and the glory of God is to reveal the mysteries of his speech.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ipsa autem per se Veritas discipulis dicit: Quae dico vobis in tenebris dicite in lumine (Matth. X, 27); id est, aperte exponite quae in allegoriarum obscuritatibus auditis.
chunks.english: But Truth himself says to his disciples, in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter ten, verse twenty-seven: What I tell you in darkness, speak in the light. That is, openly expound what you hear in the obscurities of allegories.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Magnae utilitatis est ipsa obscuritas eloquiorum Dei, quia exercet sensum, ut fatigatione dilatetur, et exercitatus capiat quod capere non potest otiosus.
chunks.english: The very obscurity of God's words is of great usefulness, because it exercises the mind, so that it may be expanded through exertion, and when exercised may grasp what the idle person cannot grasp.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Not Scrutinizing Sacred Scripture Too Deeply
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXIII. Ne sacra nimium scrutentur eloquia.
chunks.english: Chapter Twenty-Three: That Sacred Scripture Should Not Be Scrutinized Too Much.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXI, c. 1, n. 3.) Divinae sententiae aliquando interius rimandae sunt, aliquando exterius observandae.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book twenty-one, chapter one, paragraph three: Divine pronouncements are sometimes to be examined inwardly, sometimes to be observed outwardly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scriptum quippe est: Qui fortiter exprimit ubera ad eliciendum lac, exprimit butyrum: et qui vehementer emulgitur, elicit sanguinem (Prov. XXX, 33).
chunks.english: For it is written in Proverbs, chapter thirty, verse thirty-three: He who presses the breasts forcefully to draw out milk produces butter, and he who blows his nose vehemently draws out blood.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ubera quippe fortiter premimus cum verba sacri eloquii subtili intellectu pensamus, qua pressione dum lac quaerimus, butyrum invenimus; quia dum nutriri vel tenui intellectu quaerimus, ubertate internae pinguedinis ungimur.
chunks.english: We press the breasts firmly when we weigh the words of sacred Scripture with subtle understanding, and by this pressing, while we seek milk, we find butter, because while we seek to be nourished even with slight understanding, we are anointed with the abundance of inner richness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod tamen nec nimie, nec semper agendum est, ne, dum lac quaeritur ab uberibus, sanguis sequatur.
chunks.english: Yet this should not be done excessively or always, lest while milk is sought from the breasts, blood should follow.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerique tractatorum, dum verba sacri eloquii plus quam debent discutiunt, in carnalem intellectum cadunt. Sanguinem quippe elicit qui vehementer emulgitur, quia et carnale efficitur hoc quod ex nimia spiritus discussione sentitur.
chunks.english: Many commentators, when they examine the words of sacred Scripture more than they should, fall into carnal understanding. For he who blows his nose vehemently draws out blood, because what is perceived from excessive spiritual scrutiny becomes carnal.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerumque necessarium est ut nonnulla sacrae legis verba juxta pondus historiae perscrutemur; ne si haec animus plus quam necesse est spiritaliter investiget, a verborum ejus uberibus sanguis nobis pro lacte respondeat.
chunks.english: It is often necessary that we examine some words of sacred law according to the weight of history, lest if the mind investigates these more spiritually than is necessary, blood instead of milk should respond to us from the breasts of its words.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dum sacra Scriptura quaedam mystica in suorum operum narratione permiscet, ad haec necesse est ut mens concita redeat ad quae hanc ipse, ut datur intelligi, sermo loquentis vocet.
chunks.english: When sacred Scripture mingles certain mystical things in the narration of its works, it is necessary that the stirred mind return to those things to which the very speech of the speaker calls it, as it is given to understand.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scriptum est in Proverbiis: Mel invenisti, comede quod sufficit tibi, ne forte satiatus evomas illud (Prov. XXV, 16).
chunks.english: It is written in Proverbs, chapter twenty-five, verse sixteen: If you have found honey, eat what is sufficient for you, lest perhaps being satisfied you vomit it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Moral. XVI, c. 5, n. 8.] Mel quippe invenire est sancti intellectus dulcedinem degustare. Quod tunc sufficienter comeditur, quando nostra intelligentia juxta mensuram sensus sub moderamine tenetur.
chunks.english: To find honey is to taste the sweetness of holy understanding. It is eaten sufficiently when our intelligence is kept under control according to the measure of reason.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam satiatus mel evomit, qui plus appetens penetrare quam capit, et illud perdit unde potuit enutriri.
chunks.english: For he who is satisfied vomits the honey, who desiring to penetrate more than he can grasp, loses even that from which he could have been nourished.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XX, c. 8, n. 18.) Dulcedinem spiritalis intelligentiae qui ultra quam capit comedere appetit, etiam quod comederat vomit; quia dum summa intelligere ultra vires quaerit, etiam quae bene intellexerat amittit.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book twenty, chapter eight, paragraph eighteen: He who desires to eat the sweetness of spiritual understanding beyond what he can grasp, vomits even what he had eaten, because while he seeks to understand the highest things beyond his strength, he loses even what he had understood well.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Gloria invisibilis Conditoris, quae moderate inquisita nos erigit, ultra vires perscrutata premit.
chunks.english: The glory of the invisible Creator, which when moderately sought lifts us up, when scrutinized beyond our strength crushes us.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde recte per Salomonem dicitur: Sicut qui mel multum comedit, non est ei bonum: sic qui scrutator majestatis, opprimetur gloria (Prov. XXV, 27).
chunks.english: Hence it is rightly said through Solomon in Proverbs, chapter twenty-five, verse twenty-seven: As it is not good for one who eats much honey, so he who is a scrutinizer of majesty will be overwhelmed by glory.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quidquid in Scriptura sacra non intelligimus, non superbe reprehendere, sed venerari humiliter debemus.
chunks.english: Whatever we do not understand in sacred Scripture, we should not reproach proudly, but venerate humbly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II, in Ezech., homil. 5, n. 6). Unde et de Domino scriptum est: Palpebrae ejus interrogant filios hominum (Ps. X, 5).
chunks.english: From Book two of the Homilies on Ezekiel, homily five, paragraph six: Hence it is also written of the Lord in Psalm ten, verse five: His eyelids question the sons of men.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Palpebrae quippe ejus judicia ipsius sunt, quae aliquid nobis claudunt, aliquid aperiunt. Palpebrae quippe Dei, scilicet ejus judicia, aperiendo nos interrogant, si intelligendo non extollimur. Claudendo nos interrogant, si non despicimus quae intelligere non valemus.
chunks.english: His eyelids are his judgments, which close something to us and open something. The eyelids of God, that is, his judgments, question us by opening, whether we are lifted up by understanding. They question us by closing, whether we despise what we cannot understand.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Continual Growth of the Holy Church
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXIV. De sanctae Ecclesiae assiduis incrementis.
chunks.english: Chapter Twenty-Four: On the Continual Growth of the Holy Church.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 10, n. 22.) Sancta electorum Ecclesia, cum ab hoc mundo in sanctis precibus ardenti amore se erigit, per desertum quod deserit ascendit sicut virgula fumi ex aromatibus myrrhae et thuris (Cant. III, 6).
chunks.english: From Book two of the Homilies on Ezekiel, homily ten, paragraph twenty-two: The holy Church of the elect, when it lifts itself from this world in holy prayers with burning love, ascends through the desert which it abandons like a column of smoke from the spices of myrrh and frankincense, as the Song of Songs, chapter three, verse six says.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Fumus itaque de incenso nascitur; et per Psalmistam dicitur: Dirigatur oratio mea sicut incensum in conspectu tuo (Ps. CXL, 2).
chunks.english: Smoke is born from incense, and it is said through the Psalmist in Psalm one hundred forty, verse two: Let my prayer be directed like incense in your sight.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Fumus excutere lacrymas solet. Itaque fumus est ex aromatibus compunctio orationis concepta ex virtutibus amoris.
chunks.english: Smoke usually draws out tears. Therefore, smoke from spices is the compunction of prayer conceived from the virtues of love.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. I c. 36, n. 54.) Sancta Ecclesia sicut fumi virgula ex aromatibus ascendit, quia ex vitae suae virtutibus in interni quotidie incensi rectitudinem proficit, nec sparsa per cogitationes diffluit, sed sese intra arcana cordis in rigoris virga constringit.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book one, chapter thirty-six, paragraph fifty-four: The holy Church ascends like a column of smoke from spices, because from the virtues of its life it advances daily in the uprightness of inner incense, and does not flow away scattered through thoughts, but constrains itself within the secrets of the heart in a rod of strictness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sancta Ecclesia, quae quotidie agit dum recogitare semper ac retractare non desinit, myrrham quidem et thus habet in opere, sed pulverem in cogitatione.
chunks.english: The holy Church, which acts daily as it never ceases to reconsider and review, has myrrh and frankincense in its work, but powder in its thought.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Bene autem dicitur myrrhae et thuris. (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 10, n. 23.) Thus enim ex lege Domino in sacrificio incenditur. Per myrrham vero corpora mortua condiuntur, ne a vermibus corrumpantur.
chunks.english: And it is well said myrrh and frankincense. For frankincense is burned to the Lord in sacrifice according to the law. But through myrrh dead bodies are preserved, lest they be corrupted by worms.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Myrrhae ergo et thuris sacrificium offerrunt qui et carnem afficiunt, ne eis corruptionis vitia dominentur, et redolentem in conspectu Domini amoris sui hostiam incendunt.
chunks.english: Therefore they offer a sacrifice of myrrh and frankincense who both afflict the flesh, lest the vices of corruption dominate them, and burn a fragrant sacrifice of their love in the sight of the Lord.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Notandum valde est quod in Ecclesia virtutes bene operantium non pigmenta, sed pulveres dicuntur.
chunks.english: It should be greatly noted that in the Church, the virtues of those who work well are called not ointments, but powders.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum enim quaelibet bona agimus, pigmenta offerimus; cum vero ipsa etiam bona quae agimus retractamus, et ne quid in his sinistrum sit judicio retractationis attendimus, quasi ex pigmentis pulverem facimus, ut orationem nostram Domino per discretionem et amorem subtilius incendamus.
chunks.english: For when we do any good things, we offer ointments. But when we also review the very good things we do, and attend by the judgment of review lest anything wrong be in them, we make powder from ointments, so that we may burn our prayer to the Lord more subtly through discretion and love.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XVIII, c. 48, n. 78.) Sancta Ecclesia Sponsi sui speciem videre in divinitate desiderans, nec tamen valens, quia aeternitatis illius formam, quam intueri concupierat, ab ejus oculis assumpta humanitate abscondebat, moerens dicit: En ipse stat post parietem nostrum (Cant. II, 9): ac si aperte dicat: Ego hunc in divinitatis suae jam specie videre desidero, sed adhuc a visione illius per assumptae carnis parietem excludor.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book eighteen, chapter forty-eight, paragraph seventy-eight: The holy Church, desiring to see the beauty of her Spouse in his divinity, yet unable, because the form of his eternity, which she longed to behold, was hidden from her eyes by his assumed humanity, says sorrowfully in the Song of Songs, chapter two, verse nine: Behold, he stands behind our wallas if to say openly: I desire to see him now in the form of his divinity, but I am still excluded from the vision of him by the wall of his assumed flesh.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 1, n. 15.) Humanis oculis hoc quod de mortali natura Redemptor noster assumpsit, ostendit, et in seipso invisibilis permansit; in aperto se videre quaerenti Ecclesiae, quasi post parietem stetit, quia videndum se manifesta majestate non praebuit.
chunks.english: From Book two of the Homilies on Ezekiel, homily one, paragraph fifteen: To human eyes he showed what our Redeemer assumed from mortal nature, and in himself remained invisible. To the Church seeking to see him in the open, he stood as if behind a wall, because he did not present himself to be seen in manifest majesty.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quasi enim post parietem stetit, quia humanitatis naturam quam assumpsit, ostendit, et divinitatis naturam humanis oculis occultavit.
chunks.english: For he stood as if behind a wall, because he showed the nature of humanity which he assumed, and hid the nature of divinity from human eyes.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II, in Ezech., homil. 4, n. 15.) Sancta Ecclesia, sive unaquaeque electa anima coelesti Sponso est amica per amorem, columba per spiritum, formosa per morum pulchritudinem.
chunks.english: From Book two of the Homilies on Ezekiel, homily four, paragraph fifteen: The holy Church, or each elect soul, is a friend to the heavenly Spouse through love, a dove through spirit, beautiful through the beauty of character.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae cum jam de corruptione carnis educitur, ei proculdubio hiems transit, quia praesentis vitae torpor abscedit.
chunks.english: When it is now led out from the corruption of the flesh, winter without doubt passes away for it, because the torpor of the present life departs.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Imber quoque abit et recedit, quia cum ad contemplandum in sua substantia omnipotentem Deum educitur, jam verborum guttae necessariae non erunt ut pluvia debeat praedicationis infundi.
chunks.english: Rain also departs and recedes, because when it is led to contemplate almighty God in his own substance, the necessary drops of words will no longer be needed, so that the rain of preaching should be poured in.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam quod minus audire potuit, amplius videbit. Tunc apparent flores in terra, cum de aeternae beatitudinis vita quaedam suavitatis primordia praegustare Ecclesia coeperit, et quasi jam in floribus odoratur exiens quod, postquam egressa fuerit, in fructu uberius habebit.
chunks.english: For what it was able to hear less, it will see more. Then flowers appear on the earth, when the Church begins to taste beforehand certain beginnings of sweetness from the life of eternal blessedness, and, going out, smells as if already in flowers what, after it has gone out, it will have more abundantly in fruit.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Ibid., hom. 3, n. 14.) Ferculum regis nostri (Cant. III, 9) sancta Ecclesia est, quae de fortibus Patribus, id est de imputribilibus mentibus, est constructa; quae recte ferculum dicitur, quia ipsa fert quotidie animas ad aeternum convivium Conditoris sui.
chunks.english: From the same work, homily three, paragraph fourteen: The litter of our king, mentioned in the Song of Songs, chapter three, verse nine, is the holy Church, which is constructed from strong Fathers, that is, from incorruptible minds. It is rightly called a litter, because it itself carries souls daily to the eternal banquet of its Creator.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: De sancta Ecclesia scriptum est: Pennae columbae deargentatae, et posteriora dorsi ejus in specie auri (Ps. LXVII 14).
chunks.english: Concerning the holy Church it is written in Psalm sixty-seven, verse fourteen: The wings of the dove covered with silver, and the back of it in the appearance of gold.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae enim hic spiritu mansuetudinis impleta quasi columba pennas deargentatas habet, in posteriora dorsi speciem auri continet, quia hic praedicatores suos sermonis luce induit. In posteriori autem saeculo fulgorem in se claritatis ostendit.
chunks.english: For she who here is filled with the spirit of gentleness, like a dove has silvered wings, contains in the back the appearance of gold, because here she clothes her preachers with the light of speech. In the age to come, however, she shows in herself the brilliance of glory.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Maxima multitudo fidelium in exordio nascentis Ecclesiae per martyrii sanguinem pervenit ad regnum. Rex noster ascensum purpureum fecit in ferculo (Cant. III, 10), quia ad clarum quod intus aspicitur per tribulationem sanguinis pervenitur.
chunks.english: A very great multitude of the faithful in the beginning of the nascent Church reached the kingdom through the blood of martyrdom. Our king made a purple ascent in the litter, as the Song of Songs, chapter three, verse ten says, because that which is seen clearly within is reached through the tribulation of blood.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. IX, c. 11, n. 18.) Alia est Ecclesiae pulchritudo morum, in qua nunc cernitur, atque alia pulchritudo praemiorum, in qua tunc per Conditoris sui speciem sublevabitur, cujus membra videlicet omnes electi, quia ad cuncta simpliciter incedunt, ejus oculi columbarum vocantur: qui magna luce inradiant, quia et signorum miraculis coruscant.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book nine, chapter eleven, paragraph eighteen: One thing is the beauty of the Church's character, in which it is now seen, and another the beauty of rewards, in which it will then be lifted up through the form of its Creator. Its members, namely all the elect, because they proceed simply to all things, are called its eyes of doves, which shine with great light, because they also flash with the miracles of signs.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. II, c. 52, n. 82.) Sicut vitta coccinea labia tua, sponsa (Cant. IV, 3). Vitta quippe crines capitis astringit. Labia sponsae sicut vitta sunt, quia exhortatione sanctae Ecclesiae cunctae in auditorum mentibus diffusae cogitationes ligantur, ne remissae diffluant, ne sese per illicita spargant, ne sparsae cordis oculos deprimant, sed quasi ad unam se intentionem colligant, dum vitta eas sanctae praedicationis ligat.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book two, chapter fifty-two, paragraph eighty-two: Your lips are like a scarlet ribbon, O spouse, as the Song of Songs, chapter four, verse three says. A ribbon binds the hair of the head. The lips of the spouse are like a ribbon, because by the exhortation of the holy Church, all scattered thoughts in the minds of hearers are bound, lest they flow away loosely, lest they spread themselves through illicit things, lest scattered they depress the eyes of the heart, but rather gather themselves as if to one intention, while the ribbon of holy preaching binds them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XXIV, c. 8, n. 17.) Quam recte et coccineam asserit, quia sanctorum praedicatio solo charitatis ardore flammescit.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book twenty-four, chapter eight, paragraph seventeen: How rightly he declares it scarlet, because the preaching of the saints flames with the heat of charity alone.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc rursum scriptum est: Duo ubera tua sicut duo hinnuli capreae gemelti, qui pascuntur in liliis (Cant. IV, 5).
chunks.english: Hence again it is written in the Song of Songs, chapter four, verse five: Your two breasts are like two fawns, twin roe deer, which feed among the lilies.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae enim sunt duo ubera, nisi ex Judaea ac gentilitate uterque populus veniens, qui in sanctae Ecclesiae corpore per intentionem sapientiae arcano est cordis infixus?
chunks.english: For what are the two breasts, if not the two peoples coming from Judea and from the Gentiles, who in the body of the holy Church are fixed through the purpose of wisdom in the secret of the heart?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ex populo Judaico vel gentili hi qui in sancta Ecclesia electi sunt, idcirco capreae hinnulis comparantur, quia per humilitatem quidem parvos se ac peccatores intelligunt; sed his per charitatem currentibus, si qua obstacula de impedimento temporalitatis obviant, transeunt, et datis contemplationis saltibus ad superna conscendunt.
chunks.english: Those who are chosen in the holy Church from the Jewish or Gentile people are therefore compared to the fawns of roe deer, because through humility they understand themselves as small and sinful. But as they run through charity, if any obstacles from the hindrance of temporality appear, they pass beyond them, and with leaps of contemplation they ascend to the heights.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui ut haec agant, praecedentium sanctorum exempla conspiciunt. Unde et in liliis pasci referuntur. Quid enim per lilia, nisi illorum vita declaratur, qui veraciter dicunt: Christi bonus odor sumus in omni loco (II Cor. II, 15)?
chunks.english: To do these things, they look upon the examples of preceding saints. Hence they are said to feed among the lilies. For what is declared by the lilies, except the life of those who truly say in Paul's second letter to the Corinthians, chapter two, verse fifteen: We are the good fragrance of Christ in every place?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sicut cortex mali punici genae tuae, absque occultis tuis (Cant. VI, 6). [Lib. II in Ezech. homil. 4, n. 8.] Genae quippe sunt sanctae Ecclesiae spirituales Patres, qui nunc in ea miraculis coruscant, et velut in ejus facie venerabiles apparent.
chunks.english: As the peel of a pomegranate, so are your cheeks, apart from your hidden things, as the Song of Songs, chapter six, verse six says. The cheeks of the holy Church are the spiritual Fathers who now flash with miracles in her, and appear venerable as if in her face.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum enim videmus multos mira agere, ventura prophetare, mundum perfecte relinquere, coelestibus desideriis ardere, sicut cortex mali punici sanctae Ecclesiae genae rubent.
chunks.english: For when we see many doing wonders, prophesying things to come, leaving the world perfectly, burning with heavenly desires, the cheeks of the holy Church redden like the peel of a pomegranate.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Bene ergo, cum miraretur sponsus genas Ecclesiae, subdidit: Absque occultis tuis; ac si aperte diceretur: Ea quidem quae in te non latent magna sunt, sed illa valde ineffabilia quae latent.
chunks.english: Well then, when the spouse wondered at the cheeks of the Church, he added: Apart from your hidden thingsas if it were said openly: Those things which are not hidden in you are indeed great, but those which are hidden are very ineffable.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. IV, c. 11, n. 19.) Plerumque Ecclesia aurorae comparata describitur, quae per cognitionem fidei a peccatorum suorum tenebris in clara luce justitiae commutatur.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book four, chapter eleven, paragraph nineteen: The Church is often described as compared to the dawn, which through the knowledge of faith is changed from the darkness of its sins into the clear light of righteousness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde et hanc sponsus admiratur, dicens: Quae est ista quae ascendit quasi aurora consurgens (Cant. VI, 9)? Quasi aurora quippe electorum surgit Ecclesia, quae pravitatis pristinae tenebras deserit, et sese in novi luminis splendore transformat.
chunks.english: Hence the spouse also admires her, saying in the Song of Songs, chapter six, verse nine: Who is she who ascends like the rising dawn? For the Church of the elect rises like the dawn, which abandons the darkness of former wickedness and transforms itself in the splendor of new light.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XIX, c. 12, n. 9.) Sicut uniuscujusque hominis, sic sanctae Ecclesiae aetas describitur. Parvula quippe tunc erat, cum a nativitate recens verbum vitae praedicare non poterat.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book nineteen, chapter twelve, paragraph nine: Just as the age of each individual person, so the age of the holy Church is described. For she was little when, fresh from birth, she could not preach the word of life.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde nunc de illa dicitur: Soror nostra parvula est, et ubera non habet (Cant. VIII, 8). Sancta Ecclesia priusquam proficeret per incrementa virtutis, infirmis quibusque auditoribus praebere non potuit ubera praedicationis.
chunks.english: Hence now it is said of her in the Song of Songs, chapter eight, verse eight: Our sister is little and has no breasts. The holy Church, before it advanced through the growth of virtue, could not offer the breasts of preaching to any weak hearers.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Adulta vero Ecclesia dicitur quando Dei verbo copulata, sancto repleta Spiritu, per praedicationis ministerium in filiorum conceptione fetatur, quos exhortando parturit convertendo parit.
chunks.english: But the Church is called adult when, joined to the Word of God, filled with the Holy Spirit, she becomes pregnant with the conception of children through the ministry of preaching, whom she brings forth by exhortation and gives birth by conversion.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XVII, c. 27, n. 39.) Sancta Ecclesia postquam mortem ac resurrectionem Domini, ascensionemque descripsit, clamat ei prophetico plena spiritu: Fuge, dilecte mi, fuge (Cant. VIII, 14). Ac si diceret: Tu qui ex carne comprehensibilis factus es, ex divinitate tua intelligentiam nostram excede, et in te ipso nobis incomprehensibilis permane.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book seventeen, chapter twenty-seven, paragraph thirty-nine: The holy Church, after it has described the death and resurrection and ascension of the Lord, cries out to him, full of prophetic spirit, in the Song of Songs, chapter eight, verse fourteen: Flee, my beloved, flee. As if to say: You who have been made comprehensible from flesh, exceed our understanding from your divinity, and remain incomprehensible to us in yourself.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Prosperity and Adversity in This World
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXV. De prosperis vel adversis hujus mundi.
chunks.english: Chapter Twenty-Five: On the Prosperity or Adversity of This World.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. V, c. 1, n. 1.) Sancti viri, cum sibi suppetere prospera hujus mundi conspiciunt, pavida suspicione turbantur. Timent enim ne hic laborum suorum fructus recipiant.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book five, chapter one, paragraph one: Holy men, when they see that the prosperity of this world abounds for them, are troubled with fearful suspicion. For they fear lest they receive here the fruit of their labors.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Timent ne quod divina justitia latens in eis vulnus aspiciat, et exterioribus eos muneribus cumulans ab intimis repellat.
chunks.english: They fear lest divine justice, seeing some hidden wound in them, should heap upon them external gifts while repelling them from intimate ones.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum taciti electi viri cogitant quod nec bona agunt nisi ut soli Deo placeant, nec in ipsa affluentia suae prosperitatis exsultant, minus quidem de prosperis occulta contra se judicia metuunt; sed tamen eadem prospera, quia se ab intima intentione praepediunt, aegre ferunt, et moleste praesentis vitae blandimenta tolerant, quia per haec se utcunque retardari in interno desiderio non ignorant.
chunks.english: When silent elect men consider that they do good only to please God alone, and do not exult in the very abundance of their prosperity, they indeed fear less the hidden judgments against themselves because of prosperity. But nevertheless, they bear these same prosperous things with difficulty, because they impede them from their intimate intention, and they tolerate with annoyance the enticements of present life, because they are not ignorant that through these they are somehow delayed in internal desire.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plus in hoc mundo honor quam despectio occupat, et magis prosperitatis sublimitas quam necessitatis adversitas gravat. Per hanc namque nonnunquam cum homo exterius premitur, ad concupiscenda quae intus sunt liberior relaxatur. Per illam vero animus, dum multis parere cogitur, a desiderii sui cursu retinetur.
chunks.english: In this world, honor occupies more than contempt, and the height of prosperity weighs more than the adversity of necessity. For through the latter, sometimes when a person is pressed outwardly, he is released more freely to desire what is within. But through the former, the mind, while it is compelled to obey many things, is held back from the course of its desire.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sancti viri magis in hoc saeculo prospera quam adversa formidant: sciunt namque quia mens, dum blanda occupatione premitur, aliquando libens ad exteriora derivatur.
chunks.english: Holy men fear prosperity more than adversity in this age, for they know that the mind, when pressed by pleasant occupation, is sometimes willingly diverted to external things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sciunt quia saepe sic hanc clandestina cogitatio decipit, ut quomodo permutetur ignoret.
chunks.english: They know that often a secret thought deceives it in such a way that it does not know how it is being changed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Electi viri pensant aeterna bona quae cupiunt, et cognoscunt quam nihil sit omne quod blande temporaliter arridet.
chunks.english: Chosen men consider the eternal goods which they desire, and recognize how nothing is all that temporally smiles pleasantly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cuncta quae hujus mundi sunt prospera mens eorum eo aegre tolerat, quo supernae felicitatis est amore sauciata. Tantoque magis in praesentis dulcedinis aspernatione erigitur, quanto hanc conspicit quia furtive sibi in aeternae gloriae despectu blanditur.
chunks.english: Their mind tolerates all the prosperity of this world with such difficulty as it is wounded by love of heavenly happiness. And it is lifted up all the more in the rejection of present sweetness, as it sees that this furtively flatters itself in contempt of eternal glory.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Ibid. c. 2, n. 2.) Sancti viri ita prosperitatem saeculi despicientes calcant, sicut et adversitatem ejus calcantes tolerant.
chunks.english: From the same work, chapter two, paragraph two: Holy men thus trample prosperity of the age in despising it, just as they also tolerate its adversity in trampling it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Per magnam denique mentis celsitudinem mundi sibi et adversa et prospera substernentes dicunt: Sicut tenebrae ejus, ita et lumen ejus (Ps. CXXXVIII, 12).
chunks.english: Through great height of mind, placing both adversity and prosperity of the world beneath themselves, they say in Psalm one hundred thirty-eight, verse twelve: As its darkness, so also its light.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ac si apertius dicant: Sicut intentionis nostrae fortitudinem ejus tristia non premunt, ita hanc nec blanda corrumpunt.
chunks.english: As if to say more openly: Just as its sorrows do not press the strength of our intention, so neither do pleasant things corrupt it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sancti viri, qui se in hujus exsilii aerumna miseros agnoscunt, clarescere in ejus prosperitate refugiunt. Unde bene per beatum Job dicitur: Quare data est misero lux (Job. III, 20)?
chunks.english: Holy men, who recognize themselves as wretched in the hardship of this exile, flee from shining in its prosperity. Hence it is well said through blessed Job, chapter three, verse twenty: Why is light given to the wretched?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Lux enim miseris datur, quando hi qui sublimia contemplantes esse se in hac peregrinatione miseros agnoscunt, claritatem transitoriae prosperitatis accipiunt.
chunks.english: For light is given to the wretched when those who, contemplating sublime things, recognize themselves as wretched in this pilgrimage, receive the brightness of transitory prosperity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum valde justi defleant quia tarde ad patriam redeunt, tolerare insuper honoris onera compelluntur. Amor eos aeternorum conterit, et gloria de temporalibus arridet.
chunks.english: When the very just weep because they return late to their homeland, they are compelled to bear in addition the burdens of honor. Love of eternal things crushes them, and glory from temporal things smiles upon them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Electi viri, dum cogitant quae sint quae in infimis tenent, et quae sint quae in sublimibus non vident, quae sint quae se in terra fulciunt, quae autem de coelestibus perdiderunt, prosperitatis suae moerore mordentur, quia etsi vident nequaquam se ab ea funditus opprimi, pensant tamen sollicite cogitationem suam in amore Domini, et in ejus dispensatione partiri.
chunks.english: Chosen men, when they consider what things hold them in the lowest places, and what things they do not see in the highest, what things support them on earth, but what they have lost from heavenly things, are bitten by sorrow over their prosperity, because even if they see that they are by no means completely oppressed by it, they nevertheless anxiously consider that their thought is divided between love of the Lord and his dispensation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. III, c. 31, n. 61.) Sciendum est quia plerumque in prosperis importuna tentatione mens tangitur, sed tamen aliquando et adversa exterius patimur, et intus tentationis impulsu fatigamur; ut et carnem flagella crucient, et tamen ad mentem carnalis suggestio inundet.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book three, chapter thirty-one, paragraph sixty-one: It should be known that often in prosperity the mind is touched by troublesome temptation, but nevertheless sometimes we both suffer adversity outwardly, and are wearied inwardly by the impulse of temptation, so that both scourges torture the flesh, and yet carnal suggestion floods the mind.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. IV, c. 12, n. 23, 24.) Beatus Job, considerans humanum genus quanta in rebus prosperis fiducia sublevetur, vel quanta ex adversis perturbatione frangatur, ad illum, quem habere in paradiso potuit, incommutabilitatis statum mente recurrit, et mortalitatis lapsum per prospera et adversa variantem, quam despicabilem cerneret maledicendo declaravit, dicens: Pereat dies in qua natus sum, et nox in qua dictum est: Conceptus est homo (Job. III, 3).
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book four, chapter twelve, paragraphs twenty-three and twenty-four: Blessed Job, considering with how much confidence the human race is lifted up in prosperous matters, or with how much disturbance it is broken by adversities, returns in mind to that state of unchangeableness which he could have had in paradise, and by cursing declared how contemptible he saw the fall of mortality varying through prosperity and adversity, saying in Job, chapter three, verse three: Let the day perish in which I was born, and the night in which it was said: A man is conceived.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quasi dies quaedam est, cum mundi hujus prosperitas arridet. Sed dies iste in noctem desinit, quia saepe temporalis prosperitas ad tribulationis tenebras perducit.
chunks.english: It is as if there is a certain day when the prosperity of this world smiles. But this day ends in night, because often temporal prosperity leads to the darkness of tribulation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Prosperitatis diem propheta despexerat, cum dicebat: Diem hominis non concupivi, tu scis (Jerem. XVII, 16). Tribulationis noctem postremo incarnationis suae tempore passurum se Dominus nuntiabat, cum per Psalmistam quasi ex praeterito diceret: Usque ad noctem increpaverunt me renes mei (Psalm. XV, 7).
chunks.english: The prophet had despised the day of prosperity when he said in Jeremiah, chapter seventeen, verse sixteen: I have not desired the day of man; you know. The Lord announced that he would suffer the night of tribulation in the last time of his incarnation, when through the Psalmist he said as if from the past in Psalm fifteen, verse seven: Until night my reins reproved me.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Moral. XII, c. 2, n. 2.] Statutum quippe homini est, vel quantum hunc mundi prosperitas sequatur, vel quantum adversitas feriat; ne electos ejus aut immoderata prosperitas elevet, aut nimia adversitas gravet.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book twelve, chapter two, paragraph two: It is established for man either how much worldly prosperity follows him, or how much adversity strikes him, lest immoderate prosperity lift up his elect, or excessive adversity weigh them down.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Concerning Heretics
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXVI. De haereticis.
chunks.english: Chapter Twenty-Six: Concerning Heretics.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Mor. XIX, c. 18, n. 27.) Omnis haereticae pravitatis auctores, cum dispensationem Dei perverse interpretari non metuunt, profecto plebes subditas non in eam viam quae Christus est, sed in invium trahunt.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book nineteen, chapter eighteen, paragraph twenty-seven: All authors of heretical wickedness, when they do not fear to interpret the dispensation of God perversely, assuredly drag their subject peoples not into that way which is Christ, but into pathlessness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Super quos recte quoque effusa contentio dicitur, quia suis sibi vicissim allegationibus contradicunt. Arius tres personas in Divinitate suscipiens, tres etiam deos credidit. Quem contra Sabellius unum Deum suscipiens, unam credidit esse personam.
chunks.english: Concerning these, poured-out strife is also rightly spoken, because they contradict one another by turns with their own assertions. Arius, accepting three persons in the Divinity, also believed three gods. Against him Sabellius, accepting one God, believed there to be one person.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Inter quos sancta Ecclesia rectum praedicationis suae tramitem indeclinabiliter tenens, et unum Deum praedicans, tres personas contra Sabellium asserit, et tres personas asserens, unum Deum contra Arium confitetur.
chunks.english: Between these, the holy Church, holding unswervingly the straight path of its preaching, both preaching one God, asserts three persons against Sabellius, and asserting three persons, confesses one God against Arius.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia in sacro eloquio Manichaeus virginitatem laudari comperit, conjugia damnavit. At contra Jovinianus, quia concedi conjugia cognovit, virginitatis munditiam despexit.
chunks.english: Because Manichaeus discovered virginity praised in sacred Scripture, he condemned marriages. But on the contrary Jovinian, because he learned that marriages were granted, despised the purity of virginity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde fit ut semper haereticis perversa intelligentia confusis vicissim sibi eorum nequitia et in culpa concordet, et in sententia discrepet.
chunks.english: Hence it happens that, with heretics always confused by perverse understanding, their wickedness both agrees with itself in fault, and differs in opinion.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sancta Ecclesia per medias haereticorum utrarumque partium lites, ordinata pace, graditur, et sic scit superiora bona suscipere, ut noverit etiam inferiora venerari; quatenus nec summa aequet infimis, nec rursum ima despiciat, cum summa veneratur.
chunks.english: The holy Church walks through the midst of the disputes of heretics on both sides with ordered peace, and thus knows how to receive the higher goods so that it also knows how to venerate the lower, so that it neither equates the highest with the lowest, nor despises the lowest when it venerates the highest.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XI, c. 28, n. 39.) Fraudem Deo haeretici exhibent, quia ea astruunt quae nequaquam ipsi pro quo loquuntur placent; eumque, dum quasi defendere nituntur, offendunt; dum in adversitate ejus currunt, cui videntur ex praedicatione famulari.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book eleven, chapter twenty-eight, paragraph thirty-nine: Heretics exhibit fraud toward God, because they establish things which by no means please him on whose behalf they speak. And him, while they strive as if to defend, they offend, while they run in his adversity, whom they seem to serve by preaching.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Inimicus et defensor est, qui Deum quem praedicat impugnat.
chunks.english: He is an enemy and defender, who attacks the God whom he preaches.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Praefat. in Job., c. 6, n. 15; Moral. XI, c. 28, n. 39.) Omnis quippe haereticus omnipotenti Deo inimicus et defensor est, quia unde hunc quasi defendere nititur, inde veritati illius adversatur.
chunks.english: From the Preface to Job, chapter six, paragraph fifteen, and Morals on Job, book eleven, chapter twenty-eight, paragraph thirty-nine: Every heretic is indeed an enemy and defender of almighty God, because from that by which he strives as if to defend him, from that he opposes his truth.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia autem latere Deum nihil potest, hoc in eis judicat quod intus sentiunt, non quod famulari foris videntur.
chunks.english: But because nothing can be hidden from God, he judges in them what they feel within, not what they seem to serve outwardly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XVIII c. 30, n. 49.) Omnes haeretici, dum praedicationem sanctae Ecclesiae fecunditatemque illius deridendo contemnunt, quid aliud quam partum matris despiciunt?
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book eighteen, chapter thirty, paragraph forty-nine: All heretics, when they mockingly despise the preaching and fruitfulness of the holy Church, what else do they do but despise the birth of their mother?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quam non immerito eorum quoque matrem dicimus, quia de ipsa exeunt qui contra ipsam loquuntur, Joanne attestante, qui ait: A nobis exierunt, sed non erant ex nobis; nam si fuissent ex nobis, mansissent utique nobiscum (I Joan. II, 19).
chunks.english: We not undeservedly call her also their mother, because from her go out those who speak against her, as John bears witness, who says in his first letter, chapter two, verse nineteen: They went out from us, but they were not of us; for if they had been of us, they would certainly have remained with us.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [In Praefat. in B. Job., c. 7, n. 16.] Omnes haeretici in his quae de Domino loquuntur, dum non intentione recta, sed appetitione temporalis gloriae, videri praedicatores appetunt, vetustas sola nominantur.
chunks.english: From the Preface to blessed Job, chapter seven, paragraph sixteen: All heretics in what they say about the Lord, while not with right intention but with desire of temporal glory, they desire to be seen as preachers, are called old age alone.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Mentes fidelium ad contemplanda superna se erigunt; sed dum haereticorum verba pervertere recta contemplantes appeunt, quasi speculam dissipare conantur.
chunks.english: The minds of the faithful lift themselves up to contemplate the things above. But when the words of heretics seek to pervert those rightly contemplating, they try as if to destroy the mirror.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nisi haeretici Dominum contemnerent, nequaquam de illo perversa sentirent; et nisi vetustatis cor traherent, in novae vitae intelligentia non errarent. Et nisi speculationem bonorum destruerent, nequaquam eos superna judicia tam districto examine pro verborum suorum culpa reprobarent.
chunks.english: Unless heretics despised the Lord, they would by no means have perverse feelings about him. And unless they drew the heart of oldness, they would not err in understanding the new life. And unless they destroyed the contemplation of the good, the heavenly judgments would by no means reject them with such strict examination for the fault of their words.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Contemnendo igitur Dominum haeretici in vetustate iniquitatis suae se retinent, sed in vetustate retinendo pravis suis sermonibus speculationi rectorum nocent.
chunks.english: Therefore by despising the Lord, heretics retain themselves in the oldness of their iniquity, but by retaining oldness they harm the contemplation of the upright by their wicked speeches.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. V, c. 11, n. 28) Habent hoc haeretici proprium, ut malis bona permisceant, quatenus facile sensui audientis illudant.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book five, chapter eleven, paragraph twenty-eight: Heretics have this peculiarity, that they mix good things with bad things, so that they may easily deceive the understanding of the hearer.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si semper haeretici prava dicerent, citius in sua pravitate cogniti, quod vellent minime suaderent. Rursum, si semper recta sentirent, profecto haeretici non essent.
chunks.english: If heretics always said perverse things, being recognized more quickly in their perversity, they would scarcely persuade what they wanted. Again, if they always thought rightly, they certainly would not be heretics.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed dum fallendi arte ad utraque deserviunt, et ex malis bona inficiunt, et ex bonis mala ut recipiantur abscondunt.
chunks.english: But while they serve both purposes by the art of deceiving, both they infect good things from bad things, and they hide bad things from good things so that they may be received.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sicut qui veneni poculum porrigit, ora poculi dulcedine mellis tangit, dumque hoc quod dulce est primo attactu delibatur, etiam illud quod est mortiferum indubitanter absorbetur: ita haeretici permiscent recta perversis, ut ostendendo bona auditores sibi attrahant, et exhibendo mala latenti eos peste corrumpant.
chunks.english: As one who offers a cup of poison touches the rim of the cup with the sweetness of honey, and while what is sweet is tasted at first contact, even what is deadly is absorbed without doubt: so heretics mix right things with perverse things, so that by showing good things they may attract hearers to themselves, and by exhibiting evil things they may corrupt them with hidden plague.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XVI, c. 47, n. 60.) Jeremias propheta sub specie onagri haereticum quemlibet designat dicens: Onager assuetus in solitudine, in desiderio animae suae attraxit ventum amoris sui (Jer. II, 24).
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book sixteen, chapter forty-seven, paragraph sixty: Jeremiah the prophet designates any heretic under the figure of a wild ass, saying in Jeremiah, chapter two, verse twenty-four: A wild ass accustomed in the wilderness, in the desire of its soul, drew in the wind of its love.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Onager quippe agreste est animal; et recte in hoc loco onagris comparantur haeretici, quia in suis voluptatibus dimissi a vinculis sunt fidei et rationis alieni.
chunks.english: A wild ass is indeed a wild animal, and heretics are rightly compared to wild asses in this place, because dismissed into their pleasures they are strangers from the bonds of faith and reason.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Haereticus quisque quasi onager in solitudine assuetus est, quia dum terram cordis sui disciplinae virtute non excolit, ibi habitat ubi fructus non est.
chunks.english: Every heretic is like a wild ass accustomed in the wilderness, because while he does not cultivate the earth of his heart by the virtue of discipline, he dwells where there is no fruit.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui in desiderio animae suae ventum amoris sui attrahit, quia ea quae ex desiderio scientiae in mente concepit, inflare praevalet, non aedificare; quos contra dicitur: Scientia inflat, charitas vero aedificat (I Cor. VIII, 1).
chunks.english: He draws in the wind of his love in the desire of his soul, because what he has conceived in his mind from desire of knowledge prevails to inflate, not to build up. Against these it is said in Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, chapter eight, verse one: Knowledge puffs up, but charity builds up.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Concerning Faith
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXVII. De fide.
chunks.english: Chapter Twenty-Seven: Concerning Faith.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II, in Ev., hom. 26, n. 8.) Fides illarum rerum argumentum est quae apparere non possunt; quae enim sunt apparentia fidem non habent, sed agnitionem, sicut Paulus apostolus ait: Est enim fides sperandarum substantia rerum, argumentum non apparentium (Hebr. XI, 1).
chunks.english: From Book two of the Homilies on the Gospels, homily twenty-six, paragraph eight: Faith is the evidence of those things which cannot appear. For things which are apparent do not have faith, but recognition, as Paul the apostle says in his letter to the Hebrews, chapter eleven, verse one: For faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not appearing.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Isaias ait: Nisi credideritis, non intelligetis (Isa. VII, 9).
chunks.english: Isaiah says in chapter seven, verse nine: Unless you believe, you will not understand.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. II, c. 46, n. 71.) Tunc enim vere ad intelligendum sapimus, cum cunctis quae Conditor dicit credulitatis nostrae fidem praebemus.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book two, chapter forty-six, paragraph seventy-one: For then we truly have wisdom for understanding, when we offer the faith of our belief to all things which the Creator says.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae si non prima in corde nostro gignitur, reliqua quaeque esse bona non possunt, etiamsi bona videantur. Scriptum quippe est: Sine fide impossibile est placere Deo (Hebr. XI, 6).
chunks.english: If faith is not born first in our heart, the remaining things cannot be good, even if they seem good. For it is written in the letter to the Hebrews, chapter eleven, verse six: Without faith it is impossible to please God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II, in Ev., hom. 29, n. 3.) In Evangelio Veritas ait: Qui crediderit, et baptizatus fuerit, salvus erit: qui vero non crediderit, condemnabitur (Marc. XVI, 16).
