chunks.english: From Book two of the Homilies on the Gospels, homily twenty-nine, paragraph three: In the Gospel, Truth says in the Gospel of Mark, chapter sixteen, verse sixteen: He who believes and is baptized will be saved, but he who does not believe will be condemned.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Fortasse unusquisque apud semetipsum dicat: Ego jam credidi, salvus ero. Verum dicit, si fidem operibus tenet. Vera etenim fides est, quae hoc quod verbis dicit moribus non contradicit.
chunks.english: Perhaps each one may say within himself: I have already believed, I will be saved. He speaks truly, if he holds faith by works. For true faith is that which does not contradict by morals what it says by words.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: De quibusdam falsis fidelibus dicit Paulus apostolus: Confitentur se nosse Deum, factis autem negant (Tit. I, 16). Hinc Joannes ait: Qui dicit se nosse Deum, et mandata ejus non custodit, mendax est (I Joan. II, 4).
chunks.english: Concerning certain false believers, Paul the apostle says in his letter to Titus, chapter one, verse sixteen: They profess to know God, but by deeds they deny him. Hence John says in his first letter, chapter two, verse four: He who says he knows God and does not keep his commandments is a liar.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod cum ita sit, fidei nostrae veritatem in vitae nostrae consideratione debemus agnoscere. Tunc enim veraciter fideles sumus, si quod verbis promittimus operibus implemus.
chunks.english: Since this is so, we should recognize the truth of our faith in the consideration of our life. For then we are truly faithful, if we fulfill by works what we promise by words.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In die baptismatis omnibus nos antiqui hostis operibus atque omnibus pompis abrenuntiare promisimus. Itaque unusquisque vestrum ad considerationem suam mentis oculos reducat; et si servat post baptismum quod ante baptismum spopondit, certus jam quia fidelis est, gaudeat.
chunks.english: On the day of baptism we promised to renounce all the works of the ancient enemy and all his pomps. Therefore, let each of you bring back the eyes of your mind to consideration of yourself, and if you keep after baptism what you promised before baptism, rejoice now certain that you are faithful.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed ecce quod promisit homo in baptismate minime servavit, et qui esse fidelis debuit, ad exercenda prava opera, ad concupiscendas mundi pompas dilapsus est. Videamus si jam scit plangere quod erravit.
chunks.english: But behold, man has scarcely kept what he promised in baptism, and he who should have been faithful has lapsed into practicing evil works, into desiring the pomps of the world. Let us see if he now knows how to lament that he has erred.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Apud misericordem namque judicem nec ille fallax habebitur qui ad veritatem revertitur etiam postquam mentitur: quia omnipotens Deus dum libenter nostram poenitentiam suscipit, ipse suo judicio hoc quod erravimus abscondit, et in gremio fidei colligit.
chunks.english: For before the merciful judge, even he will not be held deceitful who returns to truth even after he lies, because almighty God, while he willingly receives our repentance, himself by his judgment hides what we have done wrong, and gathers it into the bosom of faith.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech. homil. 3, n. 1.) Per sanctae fidei credulitatem ab omnipotente Deo cognoscimur, sicut ipse de suis ovibus dicit: Ego sum Pastor bonus, et cognosco meas oves, et cognoscunt me meae (Joan. X, 14).
chunks.english: From Book two of the Homilies on Ezekiel, homily three, paragraph one: Through the belief of holy faith we are known by almighty God, as he himself says of his sheep in the Gospel of John, chapter ten, verse fourteen: I am the good Shepherd, and I know my sheep, and my sheep know me.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Reg. past., part. III, c. 10.) Sic sunt universi consistentes in fide, sicut multa membra uno continentur in corpore: quae per officium quidem diversa sunt, sed quo sibi vicissim congruunt, unum fiunt.
chunks.english: From the Pastoral Rule, part three, chapter ten: Thus are all standing in faith, as many members are contained in one body, which are indeed diverse by function, but by which they mutually agree with one another, they become one.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde fit ut pes per oculum videat, et per pedes oculi gradiantur, ori auditus aurium serviat, et ad auditum oris lingua concurrat, suffragetur manibus venter, ventri operentur manus.
chunks.english: Hence it happens that the foot sees through the eye, and through the feet the eyes walk, the hearing of the ears serves the mouth, and the tongue runs to the hearing of the mouth, the belly supports the hands, the hands work for the belly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In ipsa igitur corporis positione accipimus quod in actione servemus. Nimis itaque turpe est non imitari quod sumus.
chunks.english: In the very arrangement of the body, therefore, we receive what we should preserve in action. It is therefore very shameful not to imitate what we are.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XXXIII, c. 10, n. 18.) Funiculi nomine aliquando fides exprimitur, sicut scriptum est: Funiculus triplex difficile rumpitur (Eccle. IV, 12); quia videlicet fides, quae de cognitione Trinitatis ab ore praedicantium texitur, fortis in electis permanens, in solo reproborum corde dissipatur.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book thirty-three, chapter ten, paragraph eighteen: By the name of cords, faith is sometimes expressed, as it is written in Ecclesiastes, chapter four, verse twelve: A threefold cord is not easily broken, because indeed faith, which is woven from knowledge of the Trinity from the mouth of preachers, remaining strong in the elect, is dispersed only in the heart of the reprobate.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Concerning Hope
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXVIII. De Spe.
chunks.english: Chapter Twenty-Eight: Concerning Hope.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Reg. Past., part. III, c. 22.) Ad unam vocationis spem nequaquam pertingitur, si non eadem unita cum proximis mente curratur, sicut ait Apostolus: Unum corpus et unus spiritus, sicut vocati estis in una spe vocationis vestrae (Ephes. IV, 4).
chunks.english: From the Pastoral Rule, part three, chapter twenty-two: To the one hope of calling one by no means attains, if one does not run with united mind together with neighbors, as the Apostle says in Paul's letter to the Ephesians, chapter four, verse four: One body and one spirit, as you are called in one hope of your calling.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: [Moral. lib. XVIII, c. 40, n. 64.] In corde fidelium tres summopere manere virtutes testatur Apostolus dicens: Nunc autem manet fides, spes, charitas (I Cor. XIII, 13); quas cunctas, subita repletus gratia, et accepit latro et servavit in cruce.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book eighteen, chapter forty, paragraph sixty-four: The Apostle testifies that three virtues remain supremely in the heart of the faithful, saying in Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, chapter thirteen, verse thirteen: Now there remain faith, hope, and charity. All of these the thief, filled with sudden grace, both received and preserved on the cross.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Fidem latro habuit, qui regnaturum Dominum credidit, quem secum pariter morientem vidit. Spem habuit, qui regni ejus aditum postulavit dicens: Memento mei, dum veneris in regnum tuum (Luc. XXIII, 42).
chunks.english: The thief had faith, who believed the Lord would reign, whom he saw dying equally with himself. He had hope, who requested entrance to his kingdom, saying in the Gospel of Luke, chapter twenty-three, verse forty-two: Remember me when you come into your kingdom.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Charitatem quoque in morte sua vivaciter tenuit, qui fratrem et conlatronem pro simili scelere morientem, et de iniquitate sua arguit, et ei vitam, quam cognoverat, praedicavit dicens: Neque tu times Deum, qui in eadem damnatione es. Et nos quidem juste; nam digna factis recipimus, hic vero nihil mali gessit (Ibid., 40).
chunks.english: He also vigorously held charity in his death, who both accused his brother and fellow thief dying for a similar crime of his iniquity, and preached to him the life which he had known, saying in verses forty through forty-one: Do you not fear God, since you are under the same condemnation? And we indeed justly, for we receive what is worthy of our deeds, but this man has done nothing wrong.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ille qui talis ad crucem venit ex culpa, ecce qualis a cruce recedit ex gratia. Confitebatur idem latro Dominum, quem videbat secum humana infirmitate morientem; quando negabant apostoli eum quem miracula viderant divina virtute facientem.
chunks.english: He who came to the cross as such from guilt, behold how he departs from the cross from grace. The same thief confessed the Lord, whom he saw dying with him in human weakness, when the apostles denied him whom they had seen doing miracles by divine power.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 2, n. 4.) Quasi in hortis unaquaeque anima habitat, quae jam viriditate spei est et bonorum operum charitate repleta. Sicca quippe spes est hujus saeculi, quia omnia quae hic amantur cum festinatione marcescunt.
chunks.english: From Book two of the Homilies on Ezekiel, homily two, paragraph four: As if in gardens each soul dwells, which is now filled with the greenness of hope and with the charity of good works. For the hope of this age is dry, because all things which are loved here wither with haste.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XIII, c. 5, n. 5.) Ille enim bene novit in exterioribus miseriis subsistere qui scit semper de spe gaudere interna.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book thirteen, chapter five, paragraph five: For he knows well how to subsist in external miseries who knows always how to rejoice from internal hope.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Virtutes sanctorum in omne quod agunt spem, fidem et charitatem proferunt; ut quod unaquaeque virtus administrat fides, spes et charitas in opus bonum gaudendo perducat.
chunks.english: The virtues of the saints bring forth hope, faith, and charity into everything they do, so that what each virtue administers, faith, hope, and charity rejoicing may lead into good work.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Moral. lib. V, c. 32, n. 56.) Quoties nobis coelestia demonstrantur, spiritus quidem pavore se concutit, sed tamen spes praesumit.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book five, chapter thirty-two, paragraph fifty-six: Whenever heavenly things are shown to us, the spirit indeed shakes itself with fear, but nevertheless hope presumes.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Inde namque spes ad majora audenda se erigit unde turbatur spiritus, quaeque superna sunt prior videt.
chunks.english: For hope lifts itself up to dare greater things from that source whence the spirit is troubled, and what things are above it sees first.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Concerning Charity
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXIX. De charitate.
chunks.english: Chapter Twenty-Nine: Concerning Charity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XXVIII, 22, n. 46.) Perfectionis vinculum charitas dicitur, quia omne bonum quod agitur, nimirum per illam, ne pereat, ligatur.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book twenty-eight, chapter twenty-two, paragraph forty-six: Charity is called the bond of perfection, because every good which is done is surely bound by it, lest it perish.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: A tentatore namque citius quodlibet opus evellitur, si solutum a vinculo charitatis invenitur.
chunks.english: For any work is more quickly uprooted by the tempter, if it is found loosened from the bond of charity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si uniuscujusque mens Dei ac proximi dilectione constringitur, cum tentationum motus quaelibet ei injusta suggesserint, obicem se illis ipsa dilectio opponit, et pravae suasionis undam virtutum hostiis ac vecte intimi amoris frangit.
chunks.english: If each person's mind is bound by love of God and neighbor, when motions of temptations suggest to it any unjust things, love itself opposes a barrier to them, and breaks the wave of evil persuasion with the barriers and bolt of intimate love.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ezech., homil. 10, n. 31.) Mandata Dei pro jussione facere servientis et obedientis est, diligendo autem facere obedientis est et amantis; quia per scientiam charitas misericordiae discitur, et per charitatem misericordiae scientia multiplicatur, quasi ala in nobis alam percutit, quia virtus virtutem excitat.
chunks.english: From Book one of the Homilies on Ezekiel, homily ten, paragraph thirty-one: To do God's commands according to command is of one serving and obeying, but to do them by loving is of one obeying and loving, because through knowledge the charity of mercy is learned, and through the charity of mercy knowledge is multiplied, as if one wing strikes another wing in us, because virtue stirs up virtue.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ev., hom. 27, n. 1). Omne mandatum de sola dilectione est, et omnia unum praeceptum sunt. Quia quidquid praecipitur, in sola charitate solidatur.
chunks.english: From Book two of the Homilies on the Gospels, homily twenty-seven, paragraph one: Every commandment is about love alone, and all commandments are one precept, because whatever is commanded is solidified in charity alone.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Praecepta dominica et multa sunt et unum: multa per diversitatem operis, unum in radice dilectionis.
chunks.english: The Lord's precepts are both many and one: many through diversity of work, one in the root of love.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qualiter autem ista dilectio sit tenenda, ipse insinuat qui in plerisque Scripturae suae sententiis et amicos jubet diligi in se, et inimicos diligi propter se.
chunks.english: How this love is to be held, he himself suggests who in many passages of his Scripture commands that friends be loved in him, and enemies be loved because of him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ille enim veraciter charitatem habet, qui et amicum diligit in Deo, et inimicum diligit propter Deum.
chunks.english: For he truly has charity, who both loves a friend in God, and loves an enemy because of God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt nonnulli qui diligunt proximos, sed per affectum cognationis et carnis. Quibus tamen in hac dilectione sacra eloquia non contradicunt.
chunks.english: There are some who love neighbors, but through affection of kinship and flesh. To these, however, in this love sacred speeches do not contradict.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed aliud est quod sponte impenditur naturae, aliud quod praeceptis dominicis ex charitate debetur obedientiae.
chunks.english: But one thing is what is willingly expended to nature, another what is owed to obedience from charity according to the Lord's precepts.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui proximos suos carnaliter diligunt, illa sublimia dilectionis praemia non assequuntur, quia amorem suum non spiritualiter, sed carnaliter, impendunt.
chunks.english: Those who love their neighbors carnally do not attain those sublime rewards of love, because they expend their love not spiritually, but carnally.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Proinde cum Dominus diceret: Hoc est mandatum meum, ut diligatis invicem (Joan. XV, 12), protinus addidit: Sicut dilexi vos. Ac si aperte dicat: Ad hoc amate ad quod amavi vos.
chunks.english: Therefore when the Lord said in the Gospel of John, chapter fifteen, verse twelve: This is my commandment, that you love one another, he immediately added: As I have loved you. As if to say openly: Love to that end for which I have loved you.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Una et summa est probatio charitatis, si et ipse diligitur qui adversatur.
chunks.english: One and supreme is the proof of charity, if even he who opposes is loved.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc est quod ipsa Veritas et crucis patibulum sustinet, et tamen ipsis suis persecutoribus affectum dilectionis impendit dicens: Pater, ignosce illis, quia nesciunt quid faciunt (Luc. XXIII, 34).
chunks.english: Hence it is that Truth himself both endures the suffering of the cross, and yet expends the affection of love to his own persecutors, saying in the Gospel of Luke, chapter twenty-three, verse thirty-four: Father, forgive them, for they know not what they do.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid ergo mirum si inimicos diligant discipuli dum vivunt, quando et tunc inimicos diligit cum occiditur Magister?
chunks.english: What then is wonderful if disciples love enemies while they live, when even then the Master loves enemies when he is killed?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Virtus charitatis ut invicta sit in perturbatione, nutriatur per misericordiam in tranquillitate; quatenus omnipotenti Deo primum discat sua impendere, postmodum se.
chunks.english: The virtue of charity, that it may be unconquered in disturbance, should be nourished through mercy in tranquility, so that it may first learn to expend its own things to almighty God, afterwards itself.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In Evangelio Veritas ait: Vos autem dixi amicos, quia omnia quaecunque audivi a Patre meo, nota feci vobis (Joan. XV, 15).
chunks.english: In the Gospel, Truth says in the Gospel of John, chapter fifteen, verse fifteen: But I have called you friends, because all things whatsoever I have heard from my Father, I have made known to you.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae sunt omnia quae audivit a Patre suo, quae nota fieri voluit servis suis, ut eos efficeret amicos suos, nisi gaudia internae charitatis, nisi illa festa supernae patriae, quae nostris quotidie mentibus per aspirationem sui amoris imprimit?
chunks.english: What are all the things which he heard from his Father, which he wished to make known to his servants, so that he might make them his friends, if not the joys of interior charity, if not those feasts of the heavenly homeland, which he impresses daily on our minds through the breathing of his love?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dum enim audita supercoelestia amamus, amata jam novimus, quia amor ipse notitia est. Nemo cum quempiam diligit, habere se protinus charitatem putet, nisi prius ipsam vim suae dilectionis examinet.
chunks.english: For when we love things heard from above the heavens, we already know things loved, because love itself is knowledge. Let no one, when he loves someone, immediately think he has charity, unless first he examines the very force of his love.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ev., hom. 38, n. 11.) Nam si quis quemlibet amat, sed propter Deum non amat, charitatem non habet, sed habere se putat.
chunks.english: From Book two of the Homilies on the Gospels, homily thirty-eight, paragraph eleven: For if anyone loves anyone, but does not love because of God, he does not have charity, but thinks he has it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Charitas vera est cum et in Deo diligitur amicus, et propter Deum diligitur inimicus. Ille enim propter Deum diligit eos quos diligit, qui jam et eos diligere a quibus non diligitur scit.
chunks.english: True charity is when both a friend is loved in God, and an enemy is loved because of God. For he loves because of God those whom he loves, who now also knows how to love those by whom he is not loved.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ev., hom. 9, n. 6.) Quisquis charitatem habet, etiam dona alia percipit; quisquis charitatem non habet, etiam dona quae percepisse videbatur, amittit.
chunks.english: From Book two of the Homilies on the Gospels, homily nine, paragraph six: Whoever has charity also receives other gifts. Whoever does not have charity, even loses the gifts which he seemed to have received.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Necesse nobis est ut per omne quod agimus in charitatis custodia vigilemus. Charitas vera est amicum diligere in Deo, et inimicum diligere propter Deum. Quam quisquis non habet, omne bonum amittit quod habet.
chunks.english: It is necessary for us that through everything we do we watch in the custody of charity. True charity is to love a friend in God, and to love an enemy because of God. Whoever does not have it loses every good which he has.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ezech., homil. 8, n. 6.) Nos cum contra malignos spiritus spiritalis certaminis aciem ponimus, summopere necesse est ut per charitatem semper uniti atque constricti, et nunquam interrupti per discordiam inveniamur.
chunks.english: From Book one of the Homilies on Ezekiel, homily eight, paragraph six: When we set the battle line of spiritual combat against evil spirits, it is supremely necessary that we always be found united and bound together through charity, and never interrupted through discord.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quaelibet bona in nobis opera fuerint, si charitas desit, per malum discordiae locus aperitur in acie, unde ad feriendos nos valeat hostis intrare.
chunks.english: Whatever good works there may be in us, if charity is lacking, a place is opened in the battle line through the evil of discord, from which the enemy may be able to enter to strike us.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ev., hom. 17, n. 1.) Duo sunt praecepta charitatis, Dei videlicet amor et proximi; et minus quam inter duos charitas haberi non potest.
chunks.english: From Book one of the Homilies on the Gospels, homily seventeen, paragraph one: There are two precepts of charity, namely the love of God and of neighbor, and charity cannot be had with less than between two.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nemo enim proprie ad semetipsum habere charitatem dicitur, sed dilectio in alterum tendit ut esse charitas possit.
chunks.english: For no one is properly said to have charity toward himself, but love tends toward another so that it may be charity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Redemptor noster binos ad praedicandum discipulos mittit, quatenus hoc nobis tacitus insinuet quia qui charitatem erga alterum non habet, praedicationis officium suscipere nullatenus debet.
chunks.english: Our Redeemer sends disciples in pairs to preach, so that he may silently suggest to us that he who does not have charity toward another should by no means undertake the office of preaching.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 1, n. 5.) In aedificio lapis lapidem portat, quia lapis super lapidem ponitur; et qui portat alterum, portatur ab altero.
chunks.english: From Book two of the Homilies on Ezekiel, homily one, paragraph five: In a building, stone carries stone, because stone is placed upon stone, and he who carries another is carried by another.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sic itaque sic in sancta Ecclesia, unusquisque et portat alterum, et portatur ab altero. Nam vicissim se proximi tolerant, ut per eos aedificium charitatis surgat.
chunks.english: Thus therefore in the holy Church, each one both carries another, and is carried by another. For neighbors mutually support one another, so that through them the building of charity may rise.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc enim Paulus admonet, dicens: Invicem onera vestra portate, et sic adimplebitis legem Christi (Gal. VI, 2).
chunks.english: For hence Paul admonishes, saying in his letter to the Galatians, chapter six, verse two: Bear one another's burdens, and so you will fulfill the law of Christ.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Grace That Precedes and Follows Us
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXX. De gratia praeveniente et subsequente nos.
chunks.english: Chapter Thirty: On Grace That Precedes and Follows Us.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Ezech., homil. 9, n. 2.) Ex omnipotentis Dei gratia ad bona opera conari quidem possumus, sed haec implere non possumus, si ipse non adjuvet qui jubet.
chunks.english: From Book one of the Homilies on Ezekiel, homily nine, paragraph two: From the grace of almighty God we can indeed strive toward good works, but we cannot fulfill them if he who commands does not help.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Paulus apostolus discipulos admonet, dicens: Cum metu et tremore vestram ipsorum salutem operamini (Philip. II, 12). Illico quis in eis haec ipsa bona operaretur adjunxit, dicens: Deus enim est qui operatur in vobis et velle et perficere pro bona voluntate (Ibid. 13).
chunks.english: Paul the apostle admonishes disciples, saying in his letter to the Philippians, chapter two, verse twelve: Work out your own salvation with fear and trembling. Immediately he added who would work these very good things in them, saying in verse thirteen: For it is God who works in you both to will and to accomplish according to good will.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc est quod ipsa Veritas discipulis dicit: Sine me nihil potestis facere (Joan. XV, 5).
chunks.english: Hence it is that Truth himself says to disciples in the Gospel of John, chapter fifteen, verse five: Without me you can do nothing.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Considerandum nobis est, quia si bona nostra sic omnipotentis Dei dona sunt ut in eis aliquid nostrum non sit, cur nos quasi pro meritis aeternam retributionem quaerimus? Si autem ita nostra sunt ut dona Dei omnipotentis non sint, cur ex eis omnipotenti Deo gratias agimus?
chunks.english: It must be considered by us, because if our good things are so gifts of almighty God that nothing of ours is in them, why do we seek eternal reward as if for merits? But if they are so ours that they are not gifts of almighty God, why do we give thanks to almighty God from them?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sciendum quia mala nostra solummodo nostra sunt, bona autem nostra et omnipotentis Dei sunt et nostra; quia ipse aspirando nos praevenit ut velimus, qui adjuvando subsequitur ne inaniter velimus, sed possimus implere quod volumus.
chunks.english: It should be known that our evils are ours alone, but our goods are both of almighty God and ours, because he himself precedes us by inspiring so that we may will, who follows by helping lest we will in vain, but may be able to fulfill what we will.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Praeveniente gratia et bona voluntate subsequente, hoc quod omnipotentis Dei donum est, fit meritum nostrum.
chunks.english: With grace preceding and good will following, that which is the gift of almighty God becomes our merit.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod bene Paulus brevi sententia explicat dicens: Plus illis omnibus laboravi (I Cor. XV, 10): Qui ne videretur suae virtuti tribuisse quod fecerat, adjunxit: Non autem ego, sed gratia Dei mecum.
chunks.english: This Paul well explains in a brief sentence, saying in his first letter to the Corinthians, chapter fifteen, verse ten: I labored more than all of them. Lest he seem to have attributed what he did to his own virtue, he added: Yet not I, but the grace of God with me.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia coelesti dono Paulus praeventus est, quasi alienum se a bono suo opere agnovit, dicens: Non autem ego. Sed quia praeveniens gratia liberum in eo arbitrium fecerat in bonum, quo libero arbitrio eamdem gratiam subsecutus est in opere, adjunxit: Sed gratia Dei mecum: ac si diceret: In bono opere laboravi non ego, sed et ego.
chunks.english: Because Paul was preceded by heavenly gift, he recognized himself as if foreign to his good work, saying: Yet not I. But because preceding grace had made free will in him toward good, by which free will he followed the same grace in work, he added: But the grace of God with meas if to say: In good work I labored not I, but also I.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In eo enim quod solo Domini dono praeventus sum, non ego. In eo autem quod donum voluntate subsecutus, et ego.
chunks.english: For in that by which I was preceded by the Lord's gift alone, not I. But in that by which I followed the gift by will, also I.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XIX, c. 4, n. 7.) Respicere Dei est ea quae amissa ac perdita fuerant ad suam gratiam reformare. Respiciendo namque levitatis nostrae mala coercuit et magna merita maturitatis dedit.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book nineteen, chapter four, paragraph seven: To look upon is of God, to restore to his grace those things which had been lost and destroyed. For by looking upon he restrained the evils of our fickleness and gave great merits of maturity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. XVII, c. 16, n. 22.) Beatus Job ait: Luna non splendet, et stellae non sunt mundae in conspectu ejus (Job. XXV, 5).
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book seventeen, chapter sixteen, paragraph twenty-two: Blessed Job says in Job, chapter twenty-five, verse five: The moon does not shine, and the stars are not clean in his sight.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia nec sancta Ecclesia virtute propria tot miraculis emicat, nisi hanc praevenientis gratiae dona perfundant. Nec singulorum bene viventium mentes a peccatorum maculis mundae sunt, si remota pietate judicentur.
chunks.english: Because neither does the holy Church shine with so many miracles by its own virtue, unless the gifts of preceding grace overflow it. Nor are the minds of individual well-living people clean from the stains of sins, if they are judged with mercy removed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Apud districti judicis oculos sua unumquemque corruptibilitas inquinat, nisi hanc quotidie gratia parcentis tergat.
chunks.english: Before the eyes of the strict judge, one's own corruptibility stains each person, unless the grace of the sparing one daily wipes it clean.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Four Orders of Leaders in the Church
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXXI. De quatuor regentium ordinibus.
chunks.english: Chapter Thirty-One: On the Four Orders of Leaders.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II in Ezech., homil. 9, n. 6.) Sancta Ecclesia ad eruditionem fidelium populorum quatuor regentium ordines accepit, quos Paulus apostolus ex dono omnipotentis Domini enumerat dicens: Ipse dedit quosdam quidem apostolos, quosdam autem prophetas, alios vero evangelistas, alios autem pastores et doctores (Ephes. IV, 11).
chunks.english: From Book two of the Homilies on Ezekiel, homily nine, paragraph six: The holy Church has received four orders of leaders for the instruction of the faithful peoples, which Paul the apostle enumerates from the gift of the almighty Lord, saying in his letter to the Ephesians, chapter four, verse eleven: He himself gave some indeed as apostles, some as prophets, others as evangelists, others as pastors and teachers.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Pastores namque et doctores unum regentium ordinem nominat, quia gregem Dei ipse veraciter pascit qui docet.
chunks.english: For he names pastors and teachers as one order of leaders, because he himself truly feeds the flock of God who teaches.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Habuit in exordiis suis sancta Ecclesia apostolos et prophetas. Prophetas autem dicimus, non eos qui in veteri populo fuerunt, sed eos qui in sancta Ecclesia post apostolos sunt exorti.
chunks.english: The holy Church had in its beginnings apostles and prophets. But we call prophets not those who were among the old people, but those who arose in the holy Church after the apostles.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Posteriori tempore, quod nunc est, habet evangelistas atque doctores. Quia vero Evangelium bonum nuntium dicitur, evangelistas utique appellamus qui rudibus populis bona patriae coelestis annuntiant.
chunks.english: In the later time, which is now, it has evangelists and teachers. Because the Gospel is called good news, we indeed call evangelists those who announce the good things of the heavenly homeland to untaught peoples.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Evangelistae atque doctores et priori quidem tempore fuerunt, sed nunc usque Domino largiente permanent, quia adhuc quotidie et infideles populos ad finem trahi, et fideles quosque in bonos mores per doctores erudiri cognoscimus.
chunks.english: Evangelists and teachers were indeed in the earlier time, but by the Lord's granting they remain until now, because we still know daily both that unbelieving peoples are drawn to faith, and that any faithful are instructed in good morals through teachers.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Qualities Required for Church Pastors
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXXII. De pastoribus animarum, quales in Ecclesia eligi debeant.
chunks.english: Chapter Thirty-Two: On Pastors of Souls, What Kind Should Be Chosen in the Church.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Praefat. I part. Reg. Pastor.) Cum rerum necessitas exposcit, pensandum valde est ad culmen quisque regiminis qualiter veniat, atque ad hoc rite perveniens qualiter vivat, et bene vivens qualiter doceat, et recte docens infirmitatem suam quotidie quanta consideratione cognoscat; ne aut humilitas accessum fugiat, aut perventioni vita contradicat, aut vitam doctrina destituat, aut doctrinam praesumptio extollat.
chunks.english: From the Preface to the first part of the Pastoral Rule: When the necessity of things demands, it must be greatly considered how each one comes to the summit of rule, and having rightly arrived at it how he lives, and living well how he teaches, and teaching rightly with what great consideration he daily recognizes his weakness, lest either humility flee access, or life contradict arrival, or teaching desert life, or presumption exalt teaching.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Prius ergo appetitum timor temperet, post autem magisterium, quod a non quaerente suscipitur, vita commendet. Ac deinde necesse est ut pastoris bonum quod vivendo ostenditur, etiam loquendo propagetur.
chunks.english: First therefore let fear temper appetite, afterwards let life commend the teaching office which is undertaken by one not seeking it. And then it is necessary that the good of the pastor which is shown by living should also be spread by speaking.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Reg. Past., part. II, c. 4.) Ad extremum vero superest ut perfecta quaeque opera consideratio propriae infirmitatis deprimat; ne haec ante occulti arbitris oculos tumor elationis exstinguat.
chunks.english: From the Pastoral Rule, part two, chapter four: In the end, however, it remains that consideration of one's own weakness should depress any perfect works, lest swelling of pride extinguish them before the eyes of the hidden judge.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Isaias propheta ait: Clama, ne cesses, sicut tuba exalta vocem tuam (Isa. LVIII, 1). Praeconis quippe officium sumit quisquis ad sacerdotium accedit, ut ante adventum judicis, qui terribiliter sequitur, ipse scilicet clamando gradiatur.
chunks.english: Isaiah the prophet says in chapter fifty-eight, verse one: Cry out, cease not, lift up your voice like a trumpet. For whoever approaches the priesthood takes up the office of a herald, so that before the coming of the judge, who follows terribly, he himself should proceed crying out.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sacerdos ergo si praedicationis est nescius, quam clamoris vocem daturus est praeco mutus?
chunks.english: Therefore if a priest is ignorant of preaching, what voice of crying is a mute herald going to give?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Reg. Past., part. II, c. 11.) Fortes perseverantesque doctores velut imputribilia ligna quaerendi sunt, qui instructioni sacrorum voluminum semper inhaerentes sanctae Ecclesiae unitatem denuntiant, et quasi intromissi circulis arcam Domini portent.
chunks.english: From the Pastoral Rule, part two, chapter eleven: Strong and persevering teachers are to be sought like incorruptible wood, who, always adhering to the instruction of sacred volumes, proclaim the unity of the holy Church, and as if inserted into rings carry the ark of the Lord.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Vectibus arcam Testamenti portare est bonis doctoribus sanctam Ecclesiam ad rudes infidelium mentes praedicando deduci.
chunks.english: To carry the ark of the Testament with poles is for good teachers to lead the holy Church by preaching to the untaught minds of unbelievers.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui auro quoque jubentur operiri, ut cum sermone aliis insonant, ipsi etiam vitae splendore fulgescant.
chunks.english: They are also commanded to be covered with gold, so that when they sound to others with speech, they themselves also shine with the splendor of life.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Necesse est igitur ut qui ad officium praedicationis excubant, a sacrae lectionis studio non recedant.
chunks.english: It is therefore necessary that those who watch for the office of preaching should not depart from the study of sacred reading.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ad hoc namque vectes esse in circulis arcae semper jubentur, ut cum portari arcam opportunitas exigit, de intromittendis vectibus portandi tarditas nulla generetur; quia videlicet cum spirituale aliquid a subditis pastor inquiritur, ignominiosum valde est, si tunc quaerat discere cum quaestionem debet enodare.
chunks.english: For to this end the poles are commanded always to be in the rings of the ark, so that when opportunity requires the ark to be carried, no slowness of carrying is generated from inserting the poles, because indeed when something spiritual is inquired by subjects from the pastor, it is very shameful if he then seeks to learn when he should explain the question.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Circulis arcae foederis vectes inhaereant, ut doctores semper in suis cordibus eloquia sacra meditantes, Testamenti arcam sine mora elevent, si quidquid necesse est protinus docent.
chunks.english: Let the poles adhere to the rings of the ark of the covenant, so that teachers, always meditating on sacred words in their hearts, may lift the ark of the Testament without delay, if they immediately teach whatever is necessary.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde bene primus pastor Ecclesiae pastores caeteros admonet, dicens: Parati semper ad satisfactionem de ea, quae in nobis est, spe (I Petr. III, 15).
chunks.english: Hence the first pastor of the Church well admonishes the other pastors, saying in Peter's first letter, chapter three, verse fifteen: Always prepared for satisfaction concerning that hope which is in us.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ac si aperte dicat: Ut ad portandam arcam nulla mora praepediat, vectes a circulis nunquam recedant.
chunks.english: As if to say openly: So that no delay may hinder carrying the ark, let the poles never depart from the rings.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Reg. Past., part. II, c. 6, et Mor., lib. XXI, c. 15, n. 22 et 25.) Sancti viri, dum praesunt, non in se potestatem ordinis, sed aequalitatem conditionis attendant. Nec praeesse gaudeant hominibus, sed prodesse.
chunks.english: From the Pastoral Rule, part two, chapter six, and Morals on Job, book twenty-one, chapter fifteen, paragraphs twenty-two and twenty-five: Holy men, when they preside, should not attend to the power of order in themselves, but the equality of condition. Nor should they rejoice to preside over men, but to profit them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sciendum quod antiqui Patres nostri, non tam reges hominum quam pastores pecorum fuisse memorantur.
chunks.english: It should be known that our ancient Fathers are remembered not so much as kings of men as shepherds of flocks.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum Noe Dominus filiisque ejus post diluvium diceret: Crescite et multiplicamini, et implete terram, subdidit: Et terror vester ac tremor sit super cuncta animalia terrae (Gen. IX, 1, 2).
chunks.english: When the Lord said to Noah and his sons after the flood in Genesis, chapter nine, verses one and two: Increase and multiply, and fill the earth, he added: And let the terror and trembling of you be upon all the animals of the earth.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Homo quippe animalibus irrationabilibus, non autem caeteris hominibus, natura praelatus est. Idcirco ei dicitur ut ab animalibus et non ab homine timeatur, quia contra naturam superbire est ab aequali velle timeri.
chunks.english: Man is indeed placed by nature over irrational animals, but not over other men. Therefore it is said to him that he should be feared by animals and not by man, because to be proud against nature is to wish to be feared by an equal.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cuncti qui praesunt non in se potestatem debent ordinis, sed aequalitatem pensare conditionis, nam, sicut praefati sumus, antiqui Patres nostri pastores pecorum, et non reges hominum fuisse memorantur.
chunks.english: All who preside should not think in themselves of the power of order, but weigh the equality of condition, for, as we have said before, our ancient Fathers are remembered as shepherds of flocks, and not kings of men.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Necesse est ut rectores a subditis timeantur, quando ab eisdem Deum minime deprehendunt timeri, ut humana saltem formidine peccare metuant qui divina judicia non formidant.
chunks.english: It is necessary that rulers be feared by subjects, when they perceive that God is scarcely feared by them, so that they may fear to sin at least by human dread, who do not dread divine judgments.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nequaquam praepositi ex subjectorum timore superbiant, in quo, non suam gloriam, sed subditorum justitiam quaerunt.
chunks.english: By no means should those in charge be proud from the fear of subjects, in which they seek not their own glory, but the justice of subjects.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In eo autem quod metum sibi a perverse viventibus exigunt, quasi non hominibus, sed animalibus dominantur, quia videlicet ex qua parte bestiales sunt subditi, ex ea etiam debent formidine jacere substrati.
chunks.english: But in that they demand fear for themselves from those living perversely, they dominate as if not men, but animals, because indeed from which part subjects are beastly, from that they should also lie prostrate in fear.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral., lib. XIII, c. 20, n. 23.) Facies sanctae Ecclesiae sunt hi qui in locis regiminum positi apparent primi, ut ex eorum specie sit honor fidelis populi, etiam si quid in corpore latet deforme.
chunks.english: From Morals on Job, book thirteen, chapter twenty, paragraph twenty-three: The faces of the holy Church are those who, placed in positions of rule, appear first, so that from their appearance may be the honor of the faithful people, even if something deformed lies hidden in the body.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui nimirum praelati plebibus plangunt culpas infirmantium, seque sic de alienis lapsibus ac si de propriis affligunt.
chunks.english: These prelates over the people certainly lament the faults of the weak, and thus afflict themselves about others' falls as if about their own.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Saepe rectores boni, dum quosdam vident ad veniam post culpas redire, quosdam vero in iniquitate persistere, occulta omnipotentis Dei judicia mirantur, sed penetrare nequeunt. Obstupescunt enim quae non intelligunt.
chunks.english: Often good rulers, when they see some return to pardon after faults, but some persist in iniquity, wonder at the hidden judgments of almighty God, but cannot penetrate them. For they are amazed at what they do not understand.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Reg. Past., part. I, c. 10.) Ille modis omnibus debet ad exemplum vivendi pertrahi qui cunctis carnis passionibus moriens jam spiritaliter vivit, qui prospera mundi postposuit, qui nulla adversa pertimescit, qui sola interna desiderat.
chunks.english: From the Pastoral Rule, part one, chapter ten: He should by all means be drawn to the example of living who, dying to all passions of the flesh, now lives spiritually, who has put prosperity of the world behind, who fears no adversity, who desires only internal things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cujus intentioni bene congruens, nec omnino per imbecillitatem, nec valde per contumeliam corpus repugnat.
chunks.english: To whose intention, well agreeing, the body resists neither entirely through weakness, nor greatly through insult.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ipse nihilominus ad dignitatem pastoralis officii debet provehi qui ad aliena cupienda non ducitur, sed propria largitur; qui per pietatis viscera citius ad ignoscendum flectitur, sed nusquam plusquam deceat ignoscens, ab arce rectitudinis inclinatur: qui nulla illicita perpetrat, sed perpetrata ab aliis ut propria deplorat; qui ex affectu cordis alienae infirmitati compatitur, sicque in bonis proximi, sicut in suis profectibus laetatur.
chunks.english: He nonetheless should be advanced to the dignity of pastoral office who is not led to desire others' things, but gives his own; who is bent more quickly to forgive through the bowels of piety, but by forgiving nowhere more than is fitting, is inclined from the citadel of righteousness; who perpetrates no illicit things, but deplores things perpetrated by others as his own; who from affection of heart sympathizes with another's weakness, and thus rejoices in the goods of a neighbor as in his own progress.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ad dignitatem pontificalis excellentiae rite pervenit qui ita se imitabilem caeteris in cunctis quae agit insinuat, ut inter eos non habeat quod saltem de transactis erubescat; qui sic studet vivere, ut proximorum quoque corda arentia doctrinae valeat fluentibus irrigare; qui orationis usu et experimento jam didicit quod obtinere a Domino quae poposcerit possit; cui per effectus vocem jam quasi specialiter dicitur: Adhuc loquente te dicam: Ecce adsum (Isa. LVIII, 9).
chunks.english: He rightly reaches the dignity of pontifical excellence who thus shows himself imitable to others in all things he does, so that among them he may not have what at least from past things he blushes at; who so strives to live that he may be able to water also the parched hearts of neighbors with the flowing streams of teaching; who by the use and experience of prayer has already learned that he can obtain from the Lord what he has requested; to whom through the effect a voice now as if especially says in Isaiah, chapter fifty-eight, verse nine: While you are yet speaking I will say: Behold I am here.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si fortasse quisquam veniat ut pro se ad intercedendum nos apud potentem quempiam virum, qui sibi iratus, nobis vero est incognitus, ducat, protinus respondemus: Ad intercedendum venire non possumus, quia familiaritatis ejus notitiam non habemus.
chunks.english: If perhaps someone comes to lead us to intercede for him before some powerful man, who is angry with him, but unknown to us, we immediately respond: We cannot come to intercede, because we do not have knowledge of his familiarity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si ergo homo apud hominem, de quo minime praesumit, fieri intercessor erubescit, qua mente apud Deum intercessionis locum pro populo arripit qui familiarem se ejus gratiae esse per vitae meritum nescit?
chunks.english: Therefore if man blushes to become an intercessor before man, of whom he presumes least, with what mind does he seize the place of intercession before God for the people, who does not know himself to be familiar with his grace through merit of life?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aut ab eo quomodo aliis veniam postulabit, qui utrum sibi sit placatus ignorat?
chunks.english: Or how will he ask pardon for others from him, who is ignorant whether he is pleased with him?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qua in re est adhuc aliud sollicitius formidandum, ne qui placare posse iram creditur, hanc ipse ex proprio reatu mereatur. Cuncti liquido novimus quia cum is qui displicet ad intercedendum mittitur, irati animus ad deteriora provocatur.
chunks.english: In which matter there is still something else more carefully to be feared, lest he who is believed able to appease wrath, himself merit it from his own guilt. We all clearly know that when he who displeases is sent to intercede, the mind of the angry one is provoked to worse things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui adhuc desideriis terrenis astringitur, caveat ne districti iram judicis gravius accendens, dum loco delectatur gloriae, fiat subditis auctor ruinae.
chunks.english: He who is still bound by earthly desires, let him beware lest, kindling more gravely the anger of the strict judge, while he delights in the place of glory, he become to subjects the author of ruin.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Reg. Past., part. I, c. 11.) Solerter se quisque metiatur, ne locum regiminis assumere audeat, si adhuc in se vitium damnabiliter regnat, ne is quem crimen depravat proprium intercessor fieri appetat pro culpis aliorum.
chunks.english: From the Pastoral Rule, part one, chapter eleven: Let each one measure himself carefully, lest he dare assume a place of rule, if vice still damnably reigns in him, lest he whom his own crime depraves desire to become an intercessor for the faults of others.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: How Church Leaders Should Live
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXXIII. De Rectoribus, qualiter vitae conversationem habeant.
chunks.english: Chapter Thirty-Three: On Rulers, How They Should Conduct Their Life.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Reg. Past., part. II, c. 2.) Rector semper cogitatione sit mundus, quatenus nulla hunc immunditia polluat qui hoc suscepit officium ut in alienis quoque cordibus pollutionis maculas tergat.
chunks.english: From the Pastoral Rule, part two, chapter two: Let the ruler always be pure in thought, so that no impurity may defile him who has undertaken this office to wipe away the stains of pollution also in the hearts of others.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Necesse est ut esse munda studeat manus quae diluere sordes aliorum curat, ne tacta quaeque deterius inquinet, si sordida insequens lutum tenet.
chunks.english: It is necessary that the hand strive to be clean which cares to wash away the filth of others, lest it stain more badly whatever things it touches, if dirty it holds following mud.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc namque per prophetam dicitur: Mundamini qui fertis vasa Domini (Isa. LII, 11).
chunks.english: For hence it is said through the prophet in Isaiah, chapter fifty-two, verse eleven: Be clean, you who carry the vessels of the Lord.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Domini etenim vasa ferunt qui proximorum animas ad aeterna sacraria perducendas in suae conversationis fide suscipiunt.
chunks.english: For they carry the vessels of the Lord who receive the souls of neighbors to be led to eternal sanctuaries in the faith of their own conversation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Apud semetipsos quantum debeant mundari conspiciant qui ad aeternitatis templum vasa viventia in sinu propriae sponsionis portant.
chunks.english: Let them see within themselves how much they should be cleansed who carry living vessels in the bosom of their own promise to the temple of eternity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc divina voce praecipitur ut in Aaron pectore rationale judicii vittis ligantibus imprimatur (Exod. XXVIII, 15 seq.), quatenus sacerdotale cor nequaquam cogitationes fluxae possideant, sed ratio sola constringat.
chunks.english: Hence it is commanded by divine voice that in Aaron's breast the rational of judgment be impressed by binding ribbons, as in Exodus, chapter twenty-eight, verse fifteen and following, so that the priestly heart may by no means be possessed by fluid thoughts, but reason alone may constrain it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nec indiscretum quid vel inutile cogitet qui ad exemplum aliis constitutus ex gravitate vitae semper debet ostendere quantam in pectore rationem portet.
chunks.english: Nor should he think anything indiscrete or useless who, established as an example to others, should always show from the gravity of life how much reason he carries in his breast.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In judicii rationale, quod in Aaron pectore ponitur, praecipitur ut duodecim patriarcharum nomina describantur. Ascriptos etenim Patres semper in pectore ferre, est antiquorum vitam sine intermissione cogitare.
chunks.english: In the rational of judgment, which is placed on Aaron's breast, it is commanded that the names of the twelve patriarchs be inscribed. For to carry the inscribed Fathers always in the breast is to think without interruption on the life of the ancients.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tunc sacerdos irreprehensibiliter graditur, cum exempla Patrum praecedentium indesinenter intuetur; cum sanctorum vestigia sine cessatione considerat, et cogitationes illicitas deprimit, ne extra ordinis limitem operis pedem tendat.
chunks.english: Then the priest walks irreproachably when he unceasingly observes the examples of preceding Fathers; when he considers without ceasing the footsteps of the saints, and depresses illicit thoughts, lest he extend the foot of work beyond the boundary of order.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Debet rector subtili semper examine bona malaque discernere, et quae vel quibus, quando vel qualiter congruant studiose cogitare; nihilque proprium quaerere, sed sua commoda propinquorum deputare.
chunks.english: The ruler should always discern good and evil with subtle examination, and carefully consider what things, or to whom, when or how they are suitable; and seek nothing of his own, but consider his advantages as those of neighbors.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Reg. Past., part. II, c. 3.) Sit rector operatione praecipuus, ut vitae viam subditis bene vivendo denuntiet, et grex, qui pastoris vocem moresque sequitur, per exempla melius quam per verba gradiatur.
chunks.english: From the Pastoral Rule, part two, chapter three: Let the ruler be distinguished in action, so that he may proclaim the way of life to subjects by living well, and the flock, which follows the voice and character of the pastor, may walk better through examples than through words.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Per divinam legem praecipitur ut sacerdos in sacrificium armum dextrum accipiat et separatum, ut non solum sit ejus operatio utilis, sed etiam singularis: nec inter malos tantummodo quae recta sunt faciat, sed bene quoque operantes subditos, sicut honore ordinis superat, ita etiam morum virtute transcendat.
chunks.english: It is commanded by divine law that the priest receive in sacrifice the right shoulder and separated, so that not only may his operation be useful, but also singular; and that he may not do right things only among the wicked, but may also transcend well-working subjects, as he surpasses by honor of order, so also by virtue of character.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sacerdoti in esu pectusculum cum armo tribuitur, ut quod de sacrificio praecipitur sumere, hoc de semetipso auctori discat immolare; et non solum pectore quae recta sunt cogitet, sed spectatores suos ad sublimia armo operis invitet.
chunks.english: To the priest in eating is given the breast with the shoulder, so that what is commanded to be taken from the sacrifice, this he may learn to immolate from himself to the author; and not only may he think right things in his breast, but may invite his observers to sublime things by the shoulder of work.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nulla praesentis vitae rector appetat, nulla pertimescat, blandimenta mundi respecto intimo timore despiciat; terrores autem considerato internae dulcedinis blandimento contemnat.
chunks.english: Let the ruler desire nothing of present life, fear nothing; let him despise the blandishments of the world in respect of intimate fear; but let him contemn terrors by consideration of the blandishment of internal sweetness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Reg. Past., part. II, c. 5.) Sit rector singulis compassione proximus, prae cunctis contemplatione suspensus, ut et per pietatis viscera in se infirmitatem caeterorum transferat, et per speculationis altitudinem semetipsum quoque invisibilia appetendo transcendat: ne aut alta petens proximorum infima despiciat, aut infimis proximorum congruens, appetere alta relinquat.
chunks.english: From the Pastoral Rule, part two, chapter five: Let the ruler be near to individuals by compassion, suspended above all by contemplation, so that both through the bowels of piety he may transfer into himself the weakness of others, and through the height of speculation he may also transcend himself by desiring invisible things; lest either seeking high things he despise the lowest things of neighbors, or being suited to the lowest things of neighbors, he abandon seeking high things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Pastores, non solum sursum sanctum Caput Ecclesiae, videlicet Dominum, contemplando appetunt, sed deorsum quoque ad membra illius miserando descendunt.
chunks.english: Pastors not only desire upward the holy Head of the Church, namely the Lord, by contemplating, but also descend downward to his members by showing mercy.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc Moyses crebro tabernaculum intrat et exit; et qui intus in contemplationem rapitur, foris infirmantium negotiis urgetur. Intus Dei arcana considerat, foris onera carnalium portat.
chunks.english: Hence Moses frequently enters and exits the tabernacle; and he who is seized within into contemplation is pressed outside by the business of the weak. Within he considers God's secrets, outside he bears the burdens of the carnal.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Moyses sanctus de rebus dubiis semper ad tabernaculum recurrit, et coram Testamenti arca Deum consulit: exemplum proculdubio rectoribus praebens, ut cum foris ambigunt quod disponant, ad mentem semper quasi ad tabernaculum redeant; et velut coram Testamenti arca Dominum consulant, si de his in quibus dubitant apud semetipsos intus sacri eloquii paginas requirant.
chunks.english: Holy Moses always returns to the tabernacle concerning doubtful matters, and consults God before the ark of the Testament, providing an example without doubt to rulers, that when they doubt outside what to arrange, they should always return to the mind as if to the tabernacle; and as if before the ark of the Testament they should consult the Lord, if concerning those things about which they doubt they seek within themselves the pages of sacred speech.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ipsa scilicet Veritas, per susceptionem nobis nostrae humanitatis ostensa, in monte orationi inhaeret, miracula in urbibus exercet (Luc. VI, 12), imitationis videlicet viam bonis rectoribus sternens; ut si etiam summa contemplando appetunt, necessitatibus tamen infirmantium compatiendo misceantur.
chunks.english: Truth itself, shown to us through the assumption of our humanity, adheres to prayer on the mountain, exercises miracles in the cities, as the Gospel of Luke, chapter six, verse twelve shows, evidently spreading the way of imitation to good rulers; so that even if they desire sublime things by contemplating, nevertheless they should be mixed by sympathizing with the necessities of the weak.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tunc ad alta charitas mirabiliter surgit, cum ad ima proximorum se misericorditer attrahit; et quo benigne descendit ad infima, valenter recurrat ad summa.
chunks.english: Then charity rises wonderfully to high things when it draws itself mercifully to the lowest things of neighbors; and to where it benignly descends to the lowest, it strongly returns to the highest.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui regimine pastorali sunt aliis praelati, tales se exhibeant, quibus subjecti occulta sua prodere non erubescant; ut cum tentationum fluctus parvuli tolerant, ad pastoris mentem, quasi ad matris sinum, recurrant. Et hoc quod se inquinari pulsantis culpae sordibus praevident, exhortationis ejus solatio ac lacrymis orationis lavent.
chunks.english: Those who are set over others by pastoral rule, let them show themselves such that subjects may not blush to reveal their secrets; so that when little ones tolerate the waves of temptations, they may run back to the pastor's mind as if to a mother's bosom. And what they foresee themselves being polluted by the filth of striking guilt, they may wash by the comfort of his exhortation and by tears of prayer.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Reg. Past. part. II, c. 7.) Sit rector internorum curam in exteriorum occupatione non minuens, exteriorum providentiam in internorum sollicitudine non relinquens; ne aut exterioribus deditus ab intimis corruat, aut solis interioribus occupatus, quae foris debet proximis non impendat.
chunks.english: From the Pastoral Rule, part two, chapter seven: Let the ruler not diminish care of internal things in occupation with external things, not abandoning providence of external things in solicitude for internal things; lest either devoted to external things he fall from intimate things, or occupied with internal things alone, he not expend to neighbors outside what he owes.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: A subjectis inferiora gerenda sunt, a rectoribus summa cogitanda, ut scilicet oculum qui providendis gressibus praeeminet cura pulveris non obturbet.
chunks.english: Lower things are to be carried out by subjects, higher things to be thought about by rulers, so that indeed care of dust may not block the eye which stands out for providing steps.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Caput subjectorum sunt cuncti qui praesunt; et ut recta pedes valeant itinera carpere, haec proculdubio
chunks.english: All who preside are the head of subjects; and that the feet may be able to take right paths, these without doubt
chunks.notes: Sentence appears incomplete in source

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: caput debet ex alto providere, ne a provectus sui itinere pedes torpeant, cum curvata rectitudine corporis caput sese ad terram declinat. Cuncti qui praesunt habere quidem sollicitudines exteriores debent, nec tamen eis vehementer incumbere.
chunks.english: The head must provide guidance from above, lest the feet grow sluggish in their journey forward, when the head bends downward toward the ground with curved posture. All who are in charge should indeed have external concerns, yet they must not press too heavily upon them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sacerdotes recte et caput prohibentur radere, et comam non nutrire, ut cogitationes carnis de vita subditorum et non funditus amputent, nec rursus ad crescendum nimis relaxent.
chunks.english: Priests are rightly forbidden both to shave the head completely and to let the hair grow long, so that they neither utterly cut off fleshly thoughts from the life of their subjects, nor allow them to grow excessively.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sacerdotibus per legem praecipitur, ut tondentes tondeant capita sua (Ezech. XLIV, 20), ut videlicet curae temporalis sollicitudines, et quantum necesse est, provideant, et tamen recidantur citius, ne immoderatius excrescant.
chunks.english: The law commands priests that they should keep their heads trimmed, as stated in the book of Ezekiel, chapter forty-four, verse twenty, so that they both provide for the concerns of temporal care as much as necessary, and yet cut them back quickly, lest they grow immoderately.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dum igitur et per administratam exteriorem providentiam corporum vita protegitur, et rursus per moderatam cordis intentionem non impeditur, capilli in capite sacerdotis et servantur, ut cutem cooperiant, et resecantur, ne oculos claudant.
chunks.english: When therefore bodily life is protected through external care administered, and yet not hindered through moderate intention of heart, the hair on the priest's head is both preserved to cover the skin, and trimmed so it does not close the eyes.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Necesse est ut rector solerter invigilet, ne hunc cupido placendi hominibus pulset; ne cum studiose interiora penetrat, cum provide exteriora subministrat, se magis a subditis diligi quam veritatem quaerat; ne cum bonis actibus fultus a mundo videtur alienus, hunc auctoris reddat extraneum amor suus.
chunks.english: The leader must vigilantly watch that the desire to please people does not strike him; that when he carefully penetrates interior matters and providently administers external ones, he does not seek to be loved by his subjects more than the truth itself; that when supported by good actions he appears estranged from the world, his own self-love does not make him a stranger to the Creator.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hostis Redemptoris est qui per recta opera quae facit, ejus vice ab Ecclesia amari concupiscit; quia adulterinae cogitationis reus est, si placere puer sponsae oculis appetit per quem sponsus dona transmisit.
chunks.english: He is an enemy of the Redeemer who desires to be loved by the Church in his place through the right works he performs; for he is guilty of adulterous thought if the servant seeks to please the eyes of the bride through whom the Bridegroom sent his gifts.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Rectores boni, dum privato se diligere amore nesciunt, liberae puritatis verbum a subditis obsequium humilitatis credunt.
chunks.english: Good leaders, when they do not know how to love themselves with private affection, consider the freely given word of pure devotion from their subjects as an act of humble obedience.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Necessarium valde rectoribus est ut cura regiminis tanta moderaminis arte temperetur, quatenus subditorum mens, cum quaedam recta sentire potuerit, sic in vocis libertatem prodeat, ut tamen libertas in superbiam non erumpat; ne dum fortasse immoderatius linguae eis libertas conceditur, vitae ab his humilitas amittatur.
chunks.english: It is very necessary for leaders that the care of governance be tempered with such art of moderation, that when the mind of subjects is able to perceive certain right things, they may advance into freedom of speech in such a way that freedom does not erupt into pride; lest perhaps when freedom of tongue is granted to them too immoderately, humility of life be lost by them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Oportet igitur ut rectores boni sic placere hominibus appetant, ut suae aestimationis dulcedine proximos in affectum veritatis trahant, non ut se amari desiderent, sed ut dilectionem suam quasi quamdam viam faciant per quam corda audientium ad amorem Conditoris introducant.
chunks.english: Good leaders ought therefore to seek to please people in such a way that by the sweetness of their reputation they draw neighbors into affection for the truth, not that they desire to be loved themselves, but that they make their love like a certain path through which they lead the hearts of hearers to love of the Creator.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Difficile quippe est ut, quamlibet recta denuntians, praedicator qui non diligitur libenter audiatur.
chunks.english: For it is difficult that a preacher who is not loved should be gladly heard, no matter how rightly he announces things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Debet ergo qui praeest et studere se amari, et tamen amorem suum pro semetipso non quaerere, ne inveniatur ei cui servire per officium cernitur occulta cogitationis tyrannide resultare: quod bene Paulus apostolus insinuat, cum sui nobis studii occulta manifestat, dicens: Sicut et ego per omnia omnibus placeo (I Cor. X, 33).
chunks.english: Therefore the one who presides should both strive to be loved, and yet not seek love for himself, lest he be found to resist with hidden tyranny of thought the one whom he is seen to serve through duty. Paul the apostle clearly expresses this when he reveals to us the hidden purpose of his effort, saying, as in Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, chapter ten, verse thirty-three: Just as I also please everyone in all things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui tamen rursus dicit: Si adhuc hominibus placerem, Christi servus non essem (Gal. I, 10): Placet ergo Paulus et non placet, quia in eo quod placere appetit, non se, sed per se, hominibus placere veritatem quaerit.
chunks.english: Yet he says again, as in Paul's letter to the Galatians, chapter one, verse ten: If I were still pleasing people, I would not be a servant of Christ. Therefore Paul both pleases and does not please, because in that which he desires to please, he seeks not himself but through himself that truth should please people.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Necesse est ut rector animarum virtutes ac vitia vigilanti cura discernat, ne aut cor tenacia occupet, et parcum se videri in dispensationibus exsultet; aut cum effuse quid perditur, largum se quasi miserando glorietur; aut remittendo quod ferire debuit, ad aeterna supplicia subditos pertrahat; aut immaniter feriendo quod delinquitur, ipse gravius delinquat: aut hoc quod agi recte ac graviter potuit, immature praeveniens leviget; aut bonae actionis meritum differendo ad deteriora permutet.
chunks.english: A shepherd of souls must discern virtues and vices with watchful care, lest either tenacity occupy the heart and he rejoice at appearing sparing in his distributions; or when something is squandered extravagantly, he glory in appearing generous as though showing mercy; or by pardoning what should have been struck, he drag subjects to eternal punishments; or by striking savagely what has been transgressed, he himself transgress more gravely; or by prematurely anticipating what could have been done rightly and seriously, he trivializes it; or by deferring, he exchanges the merit of good action for worse outcomes.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Omne hoc quod praemisimus rite a rectore agitur, si supernae formidinis et dilectionis spiritu afflatus studiose quotidie sacri eloquii praecepta meditetur; ut in eo vim sollicitudinis et erga coelestem vitam providae circumspectionis, quam humanae conversationis usus indesinenter destruit, divinae admonitionis verba restaurent; et qui ad vetustatem per societatem saecularium ducitur, ad amorem semper spiritalis patriae compunctionis aspiratione renovetur.
chunks.english: All that we have mentioned is rightly done by a leader, if inspired by the spirit of heavenly fear and love, he daily meditates studiously on the precepts of sacred Scripture; so that in him the force of care and provident watchfulness toward heavenly life, which the practice of human interaction incessantly destroys, may be restored by the words of divine admonition; and he who is led to oldness through association with worldly people may always be renewed by the aspiration of compunction toward love of the spiritual homeland.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Humility Required of Leaders
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXXIV. De humilitate praepositorum.
chunks.english: Chapter thirty-four: On the humility of leaders.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sit rector discretus in silentio, utilis in verbo, ne aut tacenda proferat, aut proferenda reticescat. Nam sicut incauta locutio in errorem pertrahit, ita indiscretum silentium hos qui erudiri poterant in errore derelinquit.
chunks.english: Let the leader be discreet in silence, useful in speech, lest he either speak what should be kept silent, or keep silent what should be spoken. For just as careless speech drags into error, so indiscreet silence abandons those who could be instructed in their error.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sit rector bene agentibus per humilitatem socius, contra delinquentium vitia per zelum justitiae erectus: ut et bonis in nullo se praeponat, et cum pravorum culpa exigit, potestatem protinus sui prioratus agnoscat; quatenus et honore suppresso, aequalem se subditis bene viventibus deputet, et erga perversos jura rectitudinis exercere non formidet.
chunks.english: Let the leader be a companion through humility to those acting well, raised up against the vices of offenders through zeal for justice: so that among the good he places himself above no one, and when the fault of the wicked demands it, he immediately recognizes the authority of his office; that with honor suppressed, he considers himself equal to subjects living well, and toward the perverse he does not fear to exercise the rights of righteousness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Omnes homines natura aequales genuit, sed variante meritorum ordine alios aliis culpa postponit. Ipsa autem diversitas, quae accessit ex vitio, divino judicio dispensatur; ut quia omnis homo aeque stare non valet, alter regatur ab altero.
chunks.english: Nature has brought forth all people equal, but by varying order of merits, guilt places some behind others. This very diversity, which arose from vice, is dispensed by divine judgment; so that since not every person can stand equally, one is governed by another.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cuncti qui praesunt non in se potestatem debent ordinis, sed aequalitatem pensare conditionis: nec praeesse hominibus gaudeant, sed prodesse.
chunks.english: All who are in charge should consider in themselves not the power of their rank, but the equality of their human condition: they should not rejoice to be set over people, but to be of service to them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quam videlicet potentiam bene regit qui et tenere illam noverit et impugnare. Bene hanc regit, qui scit per illam super culpas erigi, scit cum illa caeteris aequalitate componi.
chunks.english: He governs power well who knows both how to hold it and how to fight against it. He governs it well who knows how to be raised up through it above faults, and knows how to compose himself with others in equality along with it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quam tamen potestatem recte dispensat qui sollicite noverit et sumere ex illa quod juvat, et expugnare quod tentat, et aequalem se cum illa caeteris cernere, et tamen se peccantibus zelo ultionis anteferre.
chunks.english: Yet he rightly dispenses power who carefully knows both to take from it what helps, and to fight what tempts, and to see himself as equal with it to others, and yet to place himself before sinners with zeal for vengeance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Praedicator quisque studeat ut minas potentium ratiocinatione mitiget, ut oppressorum angustias, quanto praevalet, ope levet; ut foris resistentibus opponat patientiam, et intus superbientibus exhibeat cum patientia disciplinam: ut erga errata subditorum sic mansuetudo zelum temperet, quatenus a justitiae studio non enervet; sic ad ultionem zelus ferveat, ne tamen pietatis limitem fervendo transcendat.
chunks.english: Every preacher should strive to soften the threats of the powerful through reasoning, to lighten the distresses of the oppressed with whatever help he can provide; to oppose patience to those resisting from without, and to show discipline with patience to those growing proud within: so that toward the errors of subjects, gentleness so tempers zeal that it does not weaken the pursuit of justice; so zeal burns toward vengeance, yet in burning does not transgress the boundary of mercy.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Rectoris officium esse debet ut ingratos beneficiis ad amorem provocet, ut gratos quosque ministeriis in amore servet: ut proximorum mala cum corrigere non valet, taceat; et quaecunque corrigi loquendo possunt, silentium consensum esse pertimescat.
chunks.english: The duty of a leader should be to provoke the ungrateful to love through benefits, to preserve each grateful person in love through services: to remain silent about neighbors' evils when he cannot correct them; and to fear that silence regarding whatever can be corrected by speaking means consent.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: How Leaders Should Teach Subjects While Maintaining Self-Awareness
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXXV. Qualiter praelati subjectos doceant ac semetipsos discreta circumspectione praevideant.
chunks.english: Chapter thirty-five: How prelates should teach subjects and provide for themselves with discreet circumspection.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia igitur qualis esse debeat pastor superius ostendimus, nunc qualiter doceat demonstremus. Non una eademque cunctis exhortatio congruit, quia nec cunctos par morum qualitas astringit.
chunks.english: Since we have shown above what kind of person a shepherd should be, let us now demonstrate how he should teach. Not one and the same exhortation suits everyone, because not all are bound by an equal quality of character.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Saepe namque aliis officiunt quae aliis prosunt, quia et plerumque herbae quae haec animalia nutriunt, alia occidunt, et lenis sibilus equos mitigat, catulos instigat; et medicamentum quod hunc morbum imminuit, alteri vires jungit: et panis, qui vitam fortium roborat, parvulorum necat.
chunks.english: For often what benefits some harms others, since generally herbs that nourish these animals kill others, and a gentle whistle calms horses but excites puppies; and medicine that lessens this disease strengthens another: and bread, which strengthens the life of the strong, kills little ones.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Pro qualitate igitur audientium formari debet sermo doctorum, ut et ad sua singulis congruat, et tamen a communis aedificationis arte nunquam recedat.
chunks.english: According to the quality of hearers, therefore, the speech of teachers must be formed, so that it suits each person individually, and yet never departs from the art of common edification.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid enim sunt intentae mentes auditorum, nisi, ut ita dixerim, quaedam in cithara tensiones stratae chordarum, quas tangendi artifex, ut non sibimetipsi dissimile canticum faciat, dissimiliter pulsat?
chunks.english: For what are the attentive minds of hearers but, so to speak, certain taut strings stretched on a lyre, which the skilled player strikes differently, so as not to produce a discordant song?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et idcirco chordae consonam modulationem reddunt, quia uno quidem plectro, sed non uno quidem impulsu feriuntur. Doctor quisque, ut una cunctos virtute charitatis aedificet, ex una doctrina, non una eademque exhortatione tangere corda audientium debet.
chunks.english: And therefore the strings render harmonious melody, because they are struck with one plectrum indeed, but not with one uniform impulse.
