Every teacher, in order to build up all with the single virtue of charity, from one teaching but not with one and the same exhortation, must touch the hearts of hearers.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Doctor etenim qui loci sui necessitate exigitur summa dicere, hac eadem necessitate compellitur summa monstrare. Illa namque vox libentius auditorum cor penetrat quam dicentis vita commendat, quia quod loquendo imperat, ostendendo adjuvat ut fiat.
chunks.english: For the teacher who is required by the necessity of his position to speak the highest things, is compelled by this same necessity to demonstrate the highest things. For that word more readily penetrates the heart of hearers which the life of the speaker commends, because what he commands by speaking, he helps to come about by showing.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Per prophetam Dominus dicit: Super montem excelsum ascende tu, qui evangelizas Sion (Isa. XL, 9). Ut videlicet qui coelesti praedicatione utitur, ima jam terrenorum operum deserens, in rerum culmine stare videatur, tantoque facilius subditos ad meliora pertrahat, quanto per vitae meritum de supernis clamat.
chunks.english: Through the prophet the Lord says, as in the book of Isaiah, chapter forty, verse nine: Ascend a high mountain, you who bring good news to Zion. So that he who engages in heavenly preaching, already abandoning the depths of earthly works, may be seen to stand at the summit of things, and may draw subjects to better things all the more easily, as he cries out about heavenly things through the merit of his life.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Recte etiam sacerdos superhumerale ex auro, hyacintho, purpura, bis tincto cocco, et torta fieri bysso habere praecipitur; ut quanta virtutum diversitate clarescere debeat, demonstretur.
chunks.english: Rightly also the priest is commanded to have the ephod made from gold, blue, purple, twice-dyed scarlet, and twisted fine linen; so that it may be shown with how great a diversity of virtues he ought to shine.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In sacerdotis quippe habitu ante omnia aurum fulget, ut in eo intellectus sapientiae principaliter emicet. Cui hyacinthus, qui aereo colore resplendet, adjungitur; ut per omne quod intelligendo penetrat, non ad favores infimos, sed ad amorem coelestium surgat; ne dum suis incautus laudibus capitur, ipso etiam veritatis intellectu vacuetur.
chunks.english: In the priest's attire, gold shines before all things, so that in him the understanding of wisdom may principally gleam. To this is joined blue, which shines with sky-like color; so that through all that he penetrates by understanding, he may rise not to base favors but to love of heavenly things; lest while carelessly captured by his own praises, he be emptied even of the very understanding of truth.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Auro videlicet, hyacintho ac purpurae bis tinctus coccus adjungitur, ut ante interni Judicis oculos omnia virtutum bona ex charitate decorentur, et cuncta quae coram hominibus rutilant, haec in conspectu occulti arbitris flamma intimi amoris incendat.
chunks.english: To gold and blue, twice-dyed scarlet is joined to purple, so that before the eyes of the inner Judge all the goods of virtues may be adorned from charity, and all things that shine brilliantly before people, these may burn in the sight of the hidden arbiter with the flame of intimate love.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae vero scilicet charitas, quia Deum simul ac proximum diligit, quasi ex duplici tinctura fulgescit. Qui sic ad auctoris speciem anhelat ut proximorum curam negligat, vel sic proximorum curam exsequitur ut a divino amore torpescat, quia unum horum quodlibet negligit, in superhumeralis ornamento habere coccum bis tinctum nescit.
chunks.english: This charity, because it loves both God and neighbor together, shines as if from double dyeing. He who so pants after the vision of the Creator that he neglects care of neighbors, or so pursues care of neighbors that he grows torpid from divine love, because he neglects either one of these, does not know how to have twice-dyed scarlet in the ornament of the ephod.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum rector se ad loquendum praeparat, sub quanto cautelae studio loquatur attendat; ne si inordinate ad loquendum rapitur, erroris vulnere audientium corda feriantur, et cum fortasse sapiens videri desiderat, unitatis compagem insipienter abscidat.
chunks.english: When a leader prepares himself to speak, let him attend to how much caution he uses in speaking; lest if he is rashly swept away to speaking, the hearts of hearers be struck with the wound of error, and when perhaps he desires to seem wise, he foolishly cuts apart the structure of unity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In Evangelio Veritas ait: Habete sal in vobis, et pacem habete inter vos (Marc. IX, 49). Per sal quippe verbi sapientia designatur. Qui igitur loqui sapienter nititur, magnopere metuat ne ejus eloquio audientium unitas confundatur.
chunks.english: In the Gospel, Truth says, as in the Gospel of Mark, chapter nine, verse forty-nine: Have salt in yourselves, and have peace among yourselves. By salt indeed the wisdom of the word is designated. Therefore whoever strives to speak wisely, let him greatly fear lest by his eloquence the unity of hearers be confounded.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc Paulus ait: Non plus sapere quam oportet sapere, sed sapere ad sobrietatem (Marc. XII, 3). Ne igitur rector incautus ad loquendum proruat, hoc quod jam praemisimus, per semetipsam discipulis Veritas clamat: Habete sal in vobis, et pacem habete inter vos (Marc. IX, 49).
chunks.english: Hence Paul says, as in Paul's letter to the Romans, chapter twelve, verse three: Not to be wise beyond what it is proper to be wise, but to be wise unto sobriety. Lest therefore a leader rush carelessly to speaking, Truth itself cries out to disciples what we have already mentioned: Have salt in yourselves, and have peace among yourselves, from the Gospel of Mark, chapter nine, verse forty-nine.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ac si figurate per habitum sacerdotis dicat: Mala punica tintinnabulis jungite; ut per omne quod dicitis unitatem fidei cauta observatione teneatis.
chunks.english: As if figuratively through the priest's attire he says: Join pomegranates to bells; so that through all that you say you may hold the unity of faith with cautious observance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sacerdos vero semper vocem praedicationis habeat, ne superni inspectoris judicium ex silentio offendat. Sacerdos in tabernaculum ingrediens vel egrediens moritur si de eo sonitus non auditur, quia iram contra se occulti Judicis exigit, si sine praedicationis sonitu incedit.
chunks.english: The priest should always have the voice of preaching, lest he offend the judgment of the heavenly Inspector through silence. The priest entering or leaving the tabernacle dies if sound is not heard from him, because he provokes the anger of the hidden Judge against himself, if he proceeds without the sound of preaching.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Apte tintinnabula vestimentis pontificis describuntur inserta. Vestimenta etenim sacerdotis quid aliud quam recta opera debemus accipere, Propheta attestante, qui ait: Sacerdotes tui induantur justitia (Ps. CXXXI, 9)?
chunks.english: Appropriately bells are described as attached to the garments of the high priest. For what else should we understand by the garments of the priest than right works, with the Prophet testifying, who says in Psalm one hundred thirty-one, verse nine: Let your priests be clothed with justice.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Vestimentis itaque illius tintinnabula inhaerent, ut vitae viam cum linguae sonitu ipsa quoque opera sacerdotis clament.
chunks.english: Therefore bells adhere to his garments, so that the very works of the priest may cry out the way of life with the sound of the tongue.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nos quia infirmi homines sumus, cum de Deo hominibus loquimur, debemus primum meminisse quid sumus, ut ex propria infirmitate pensemus quo docendi ordine infirmis fratribus consulamus.
chunks.english: We, because we are weak human beings, when we speak to people about God, must first remember what we are, so that from our own weakness we may consider in what order of teaching we should minister to weak brothers.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Consideremus igitur quia aut tales sumus quales nonnullos corrigimus, aut tales aliquando fuimus, etsi jam divina gratia operante non sumus, ut tanto eos temperantius corde humili corrigamus, quanto nosmetipsos verius in his quos emendamus agnoscimus.
chunks.english: Let us consider therefore that we are either such as we correct some to be, or we were at some time such, even if by divine grace working we are no longer, so that we may correct them all the more temperately with humble heart, as we more truly recognize ourselves in those whom we amend.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si nos sacerdotes tales nec fuimus nec sumus quales adhuc illi sunt quos emendare curamus, ne cor nostrum forte superbiat, et de ipsa innocentia pejus ruat, quorum mala corrigimus, alia eorum bona nobis ante oculos revocemus: quae si omnino nulla sunt, ad occulta Dei judicia recurramus.
chunks.english: If we priests neither were nor are such as those still are whom we take care to amend, lest perhaps our heart grow proud and fall worse from innocence itself, let us call to mind before our eyes other goods of those whose evils we correct: which if there are none at all, let us have recourse to God's hidden judgments.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia sicut nos nullis meritis hoc ipsum bonum quod habemus accepimus, ita illos quoque potest gratia supernae virtutis infundere, ut excitati posterius, etiam ipsa possint bona quae nos ante accepimus praevenire.
chunks.english: Because just as we received by no merits this very good that we have, so also the grace of supernal power can pour into them, so that aroused afterward, they can even surpass the very goods that we received before.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quis enim crederet quod per apostolatus meritum Saulus lapidatum Stephanum praecessurus erat, qui in morte ejus lapidantium vestimenta servabat (Act. VII, 57)? His ergo primum cogitationibus humiliari cor debet, et tunc demum delinquentium iniquitas increpari.
chunks.english: For who would have believed that Saul would surpass Stephen the stoned through the merit of apostleship, he who at his death kept the garments of those stoning him, as in the Acts of the Apostles, chapter seven, verse fifty-seven? By these thoughts therefore the heart must first be humbled, and then finally the iniquity of offenders rebuked.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Zeal Required of Pastors for Their Subjects
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXXVI De zelo pastoralis officii erga subditos.
chunks.english: Chapter thirty-six: On the zeal of pastoral office toward subjects.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Omnis spiritalis zelus doctoris animam frigit, quia valde cruciatur dum infirmos quosque aeterna deserere, et rebus temporalibus delectari conspicit.
chunks.english: All spiritual zeal roasts the soul of the teacher, because he is greatly tormented when he sees any of the weak abandoning eternal things and delighting in temporal things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nullum quippe omnipotenti Deo tale est sacrificium, quale est zelus animarum, sicut Psalmista ait: Zelus domus tuae comedit me (Ps. LXVIII, 10).
chunks.english: For there is no sacrifice to almighty God such as the zeal of souls, as the Psalmist says in Psalm sixty-eight, verse ten: Zeal for your house has consumed me.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Paulus apostolus zelo animarum cruciatus, dicebat: Quis infirmatur, et ego non infirmor? Quis scandalizatur, et ego non uror (II Cor. XI, 29)?
chunks.english: Paul the apostle, tormented by zeal for souls, said, as in Paul's second letter to the Corinthians, chapter eleven, verse twenty-nine: Who is weak, and I am not weak? Who is made to stumble, and I am not inflamed?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ipsum suum cor, quod animarum zelo succenderat, quid aliud quam sartaginem fecerat, in quo amore virtutum contra vitia ardebat? Quod enim urebatur, sartago erat.
chunks.english: His own heart, which he had set ablaze with zeal for souls, what else had he made but a frying pan, in which he burned with love of virtues against vices? For what was being burned was a frying pan.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Inardescebat enim et coquebat, quia incendebatur amaritudine; sed virtutum alimenta praeparabat ex sua afflicta cogitatione.
chunks.english: For he was burning and cooking, because he was inflamed with bitterness; but he was preparing the food of virtues from his afflicted thought.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid est quod Ezechiel propheta sartaginem inter se et civitatem murum ferreum ponit (Ezech. IV, 3), nisi quod idem zelus fortis, qui nunc in mente doctoris agitur, in die extremi judicii inter eum et animam quam a vitiis zelatur testis est?
chunks.english: What does it mean that the prophet Ezekiel places the frying pan as an iron wall between himself and the city, as in the book of Ezekiel, chapter four, verse three, except that this same strong zeal, which now is at work in the mind of the teacher, on the day of final judgment is a witness between him and the soul for which he has zeal against vices?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ut etsi audire is qui docetur noluerit, doctor tamen pro zelo quem exhibet de auditoris negligentia reus non sit.
chunks.english: So that even if he who is taught is unwilling to hear, the teacher nevertheless is not guilty of the hearer's negligence because of the zeal he has shown.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Murum ferreum propheta inter se et civitatem ponit, quia in ultionis tempore inde doctor a damnationis periculo munitur, unde nunc per zelum custodiae cordis frixuram patitur.
chunks.english: The prophet places an iron wall between himself and the city, because in the time of vengeance the teacher is fortified from the danger of damnation by that from which now through zeal of guarding the heart he suffers roasting.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quantum frixura cordis, quae per spiritalem zelum agitur, omnipotentem Deum placat, aperte ostenditur, cum offerri per legem simila in sacrificium jubetur.
chunks.english: How much the roasting of the heart, which is brought about through spiritual zeal, pleases almighty God, is clearly shown when fine flour is commanded to be offered in sacrifice through the law.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scriptum quippe est: In sartagine oleo conspersa frigetur, offeretque eam calidam in odorem suavissimum Domino sacerdos, qui patri jure successerit, et tota cremabitur in altari (Lev. VI, 21, 22).
chunks.english: For it is written in the book of Leviticus, chapter six, verses twenty-one and twenty-two: In a frying pan sprinkled with oil let it be fried, and let the priest who has succeeded his father by right offer it hot as a most pleasing aroma to the Lord, and it shall be wholly burned on the altar.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tunc simila in sartagine frigitur, cum munda mens justi zeli sancti ardore crematur. Quae conspergi oleo praecipitur, id est charitas misericordiae misceri, quae in conspectu omnipotentis Dei ardet et lucet.
chunks.english: Then fine flour is fried in a frying pan, when the pure mind of the just is consumed by the ardor of holy zeal. It is commanded to be sprinkled with oil, that is, charity of mercy to be mixed in, which burns and shines in the sight of almighty God.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Conspergatur ergo oleo mens quae in sartagine frigitur, quia sancti zeli districtio necesse est ut ex misericordiae virtute et ardeat et clarescat.
chunks.english: Therefore let the mind which is fried in the frying pan be sprinkled with oil, because the strictness of holy zeal must both burn and shine from the virtue of mercy.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Amat enim eumdem ipsum quem insequi videtur. Unde et calida in odorem suavissimum Domino offerri praecipitur, quia si amorem zelus non habet, ea quae de sartagine offertur calorem simila amisit.
chunks.english: For it loves the very one whom it seems to pursue. Therefore it is commanded to be offered hot as a most pleasing aroma to the Lord, because if zeal does not have love, the fine flour which is offered from the frying pan has lost its heat.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Notandum valde est quis similam offerre praecipitur, videlicet sacerdos, qui patri jure successerit. Ille enim sacerdos patri jure succedit, qui esse se omnipotentis Domini filium moribus demonstrat, atque a nobilitate intima operum suorum ignobilitate non discrepat.
chunks.english: It must be greatly noted who is commanded to offer the fine flour, namely the priest who has succeeded his father by right. For that priest succeeds his father by right who demonstrates by his conduct that he is a son of the almighty Lord, and does not differ by baseness from the inner nobility of his works.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quae in altari tota cremari praecipitur, ut videlicet holocaustum fiat. Simila itaque in sartagine est munda mens justi in zeli spiritualis afflictione, quae per sollicitudinem animarum frigitur; et non solum sacrificium, sed etiam holocaustum Domino esse deputatur.
chunks.english: It is commanded to be wholly burned on the altar, so that it may become a holocaust. Therefore the fine flour in the frying pan is the pure mind of the just in the affliction of spiritual zeal, which is fried through care for souls; and it is reckoned to be not only a sacrifice but also a holocaust to the Lord.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sumamus ergo sartaginem ferream, et ponamus eam murum ferreum inter nos et civitatem, id est, assumamus zelum fortem, ut inter nos et auditoris nostri animam inveniamus hanc postmodum fortem munitionem.
chunks.english: Let us therefore take an iron frying pan, and place it as an iron wall between us and the city, that is, let us assume strong zeal, so that between us and the soul of our hearer we may afterward find this strong fortification.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tunc enim hunc murum ferreum inventuri sumus, si nunc eum fortiter tenemus, videlicet docendo, custodiendo, suadendo, increpando, mulcendo, terrendo, aliquando leniter, aliquando vero etiam severius agendo.
chunks.english: For then we shall find this iron wall, if now we hold it firmly, namely by teaching, guarding, persuading, rebuking, soothing, frightening, sometimes acting gently, sometimes indeed even more severely.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: De qua severitate per Ezechielem recte subditur: Et obfirmabis faciem tuam ad eam (Ezech. IV, 3), et erit in obsidionem.
chunks.english: Concerning which severity it is rightly added through Ezekiel, from the book of Ezekiel, chapter four, verse three: And you shall make your face firm toward it, and it shall be under siege.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid est obfirmare faciem ad Jerusalem in latere descriptam, nisi ut ei animae cui coelestis pacis visionem doctor denuntiat, si adhuc eam infirmari in suis actibus cernit, remissiorem et clementiorem se minime ostendat?
chunks.english: What is it to make the face firm toward Jerusalem depicted on the side, except that to that soul to which the teacher announces the vision of heavenly peace, if he still sees it weakened in its actions, he shows himself by no means more lenient and merciful?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scriptum est: Filiae tibi sunt? Serva corpus illarum, et non ostendas hilarem faciem tuam ad illas (Eccli. VII, 26).
chunks.english: It is written in the book of Sirach, chapter seven, verse twenty-six: Do you have daughters? Guard their bodies, and do not show a cheerful face to them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Infirmae quippe animae, atque ad appetitum mundi deditae, aliquando melius ex severitate servantur: ut obfirmata facies, id est, per severitatis custodiam ab omni spe frivolae remissionis obducta, inconstantem animam terreat, atque a delectatione vitiorum districtionis vigore constringat.
chunks.english: For weak souls, devoted to the appetite of the world, are sometimes better preserved through severity: so that a face made firm, that is, hardened through the guardianship of severity from all hope of frivolous leniency, may terrify the inconstant soul, and restrain it from the delight of vices by the force of strictness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod cum a doctore agitur, semper necesse est ut dulcedo et humilitas in corde teneatur; quatenus et multum amet, et nunquam contra eum per elationem superbiat, cui tamen amorem suum et humilitatem pro utilitate ejus prodere recusat.
chunks.english: When this is done by a teacher, it is always necessary that sweetness and humility be held in the heart; so that he may love much, and never grow proud against him through exaltation, to whom nevertheless he refuses to reveal his love and humility for his benefit.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Circumdat doctor auditoris animam, cum in omne quod in hac vita agitur tentationum laqueos apponi posse denuntiat; ut dum ubique fit mens pavida, ubique circumspecta, quanto timidior, tanto vigilantior vivat.
chunks.english: The teacher surrounds the soul of the hearer when he announces that snares of temptations can be placed in everything that is done in this life; so that while the mind becomes fearful everywhere, watchful everywhere, the more timid it is, the more vigilantly it may live.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ipse namque zelus rectitudinis, dum inquietudine mentem agitat, ejus mox aciem obscurat, ut altiora in commotione non videat quae bene prius tranquilla cernebat.
chunks.english: For zeal of righteousness itself, while it agitates the mind with disturbance, soon obscures its vision, so that in commotion it does not see the higher things which it previously saw well when tranquil.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed inde subtilius ad alta reducitur, unde ad tempus ne videat reverberatur. Nam ipsa recti aemulatio aeterna post paululum in tranquillitate largius aperit, quae haec interim per commotionem claudit; et unde mens turbatur ne videat, inde proficit ut ad videndum verius clarescat: sicut infirmanti oculo cum collyrium mittitur, lux penitus negatur; sed inde eam post paululum veraciter recipit, unde hanc ad tempus salubriter amittit.
chunks.english: But from there it is more subtly led back to the heights, from where for a time it is beaten back from seeing. For emulation of the right itself after a little while more abundantly opens eternal things in tranquility, which it meanwhile closes through commotion; and from where the mind is disturbed so as not to see, from there it profits to shine more truly for seeing: just as when salve is applied to an ailing eye, light is entirely denied; but from there after a little while it truly receives it, from where it healthfully loses it for a time.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nunquam commotioni contemplatio jungitur, nec praevalet mens perturbata conspicere ad quod vix tranquilla valet inhiare; quia nec solis radius cernitur; cum commotae nubes coeli faciem obducunt; nec turbatus fons respicientis imaginem reddit, quam tranquillus propriam ostendit, quia quo ejus unda palpitat, eo in se speciem similitudinis obscurat.
chunks.english: Contemplation is never joined to commotion, nor can a disturbed mind prevail to see that which a tranquil one can scarcely gaze upon; for neither is the ray of the sun perceived when stirred clouds cover the face of heaven; nor does a troubled spring return the image of one looking into it, which a tranquil one shows clearly, because the more its water ripples, the more it obscures in itself the appearance of the likeness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum per zelum animus movetur, curandum summopere est ne haec eadem, quae instrumento virtutis adsumitur, menti ira dominetur; ne quasi domina praeeat, sed velut ancilla ad obsequium parata a rationis tergo nunquam recedat.
chunks.english: When the spirit is moved by zeal, care must be taken supremely that anger not dominate the mind in this same thing which is assumed as an instrument of virtue; lest it go before as mistress, but like a maid prepared for service, let it never withdraw from the back of reason.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tunc enim robustius contra vitia erigitur, cum subdita rationi famulatur. Quantumlibet ira ex zelo rectitudinis surgat, immoderatam mentem dilacerat. Rationi protinus servire contemnit, et tanto se impudentius dilatat, quanto impatientiae vitium virtutem putat.
chunks.english: For then it is more robustly raised up against vices, when it serves subject to reason. However much anger arises from zeal for righteousness, it tears apart an immoderate mind. It immediately scorns to serve reason, and dilates itself all the more shamelessly, as it considers the vice of impatience to be virtue.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Necesse est ut hoc ante omnia qui zelo rectitudinis movetur attendat, ne ira extra mentis dominium transeat, sed in ultione peccati tempus modumque considerans, surgentem animi perturbationem subtilius retractando restringat, animositatem reprimat, et motus fervidos sub aequitate disponat, ut eo fiat justior ultor alienus, quo prius exstititit victor suus.
chunks.english: It is necessary that before all things, he who is moved by zeal for righteousness attend to this, lest anger pass beyond the dominion of the mind, but considering the time and manner in the vengeance of sin, by more subtly reconsidering, let him restrain the rising disturbance of spirit, suppress impetuosity, and arrange fervent movements under equity, so that he may become a more just avenger of another's wrong, as he previously stood as conqueror of his own.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui zelo rectitudinis movetur, sic culpas delinquentium corrigat, ut ante ipse qui corrigit per patientiam crescat, et fervorem suum transcendendo dijudicet, ne intemperanter excitatus ipso zelo rectitudinis, longe a rectitudine aberret.
chunks.english: He who is moved by zeal for righteousness should correct the faults of offenders in such a way that he who corrects first grows through patience, and judges his fervor by transcending it, lest intemperately aroused by the very zeal of righteousness, he wander far from righteousness.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Why the Unworthy Must Not Presume Pastoral Office
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXXVII. Ut indigni atque imperiti ad pastorale magisterium accedere non praesumant.
chunks.english: Chapter thirty-seven: That the unworthy and unskilled must not presume to approach pastoral teaching.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt plerique pastorum qui dum metiri se nesciunt quae non didicerunt docere concupiscunt, qui pondus magisterii tanto levius aestimant, quanto vim magnitudinis illius ignorant; ut quia indocti ac praecipites doctrinae arcem tenere appetunt, a praecipitationis suae ausibus in ipsa locutionis janua repellantur.
chunks.english: There are many shepherds who, while not knowing how to measure themselves, desire to teach what they have not learned, who esteem the weight of teaching all the lighter as they are ignorant of the force of its greatness; so that because untaught and rash they desire to hold the citadel of doctrine, they are repelled from the very door of speech by the audacity of their rashness.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nulla ars doceri praesumitur, nisi intenta prius meditatione discatur. Ab imperitis ergo pastorale magisterium qua temeritate suscipitur, quando ars est artium regimen animarum?
chunks.english: No art is presumed to be taught, unless it is first learned by intent meditation. With what temerity therefore is pastoral teaching undertaken by the unskilled, when the governance of souls is the art of arts?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quis cogitationum vulnera occultiora esse nesciat vulneribus viscerum? Et tamen saepe qui nequaquam spiritalia praecepta cognoverunt, cordis se medicos profiteri non metuunt, dum qui pigmentorum vim nesciunt, videri medici carnis erubescunt.
chunks.english: Who does not know that the wounds of thoughts are more hidden than wounds of the internal organs? And yet often those who have by no means learned spiritual precepts do not fear to profess themselves physicians of the heart, while those who do not know the power of medicines are ashamed to appear as physicians of the flesh.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt nonnulli qui intra sanctam Ecclesiam per speciem regiminis gloriam affectant honoris: videri doctores appetunt, transcendere caeteros concupiscunt, atque, attestante Veritate, primos in coenis recubitus, primas in conventibus cathedras quaerunt (Matth. XXIII, 6, 7): qui susceptum curae pastoralis officium ministrare digne tanto magis nequeunt, quanto ad humilitatis magisterium ex sola elatione pervenerunt.
chunks.english: There are some who within the holy Church through the appearance of governance desire the glory of honor: they desire to be seen as teachers, they covet to surpass others, and as Truth testifies in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-three, verses six and seven, they seek the first places at dinners, the first seats in assemblies: who are all the more unable to worthily minister the office of pastoral care they have undertaken, as they have arrived at the teaching of humility from pride alone.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ipsa quippe in magisterio lingua confunditur, quando aliud discitur, et aliud docetur. Contra indignos pastores Dominus per prophetam queritur, dicens: Ipsi regnaverunt, et non ex me: principes exstiterunt, et non cognovi (Ose. VIII, 4).
chunks.english: For the tongue itself is confounded in teaching, when one thing is learned and another is taught. Against unworthy shepherds the Lord complains through the prophet, saying in the book of Hosea, chapter eight, verse four: They have reigned, but not from me: they have been princes, and I knew them not.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ex se namque et non ex arbitrio summi rectoris regnant, qui nullis fulti virtutibus nequaquam divinitus vocati, sed sua cupidine accensi, culmen regiminis rapiunt potius quam assequuntur.
chunks.english: For they reign from themselves and not from the will of the supreme ruler, who supported by no virtues, by no means divinely called, but inflamed by their own desire, seize rather than attain the summit of governance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Inutiles sacerdotes internus judex et provehit et non cognoscit; quia quos permittendo tolerat, profecto per judicium reprobationis ignorat. Unde ad se quibusdam et post miracula venientibus dicit: Recedite a me, operarii iniquitatis, nescio qui estis (Luc. XIII, 27).
chunks.english: The inner Judge both advances and does not know useless priests; because those whom he tolerates by permitting, he certainly ignores through the judgment of reprobation. Therefore to some coming to him even after miracles he says, as in the Gospel of Luke, chapter thirteen, verse twenty-seven: Depart from me, workers of iniquity, I do not know who you are.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Pastorum imperitia voce Veritatis increpatur, cum per prophetam dicitur: Ipsi pastores ignoraverunt intelligentiam (Isai. LVI, 11). Quos rursum Dominus detestatur, dicens: Et tenentes legem nescierunt me (Jer., II, 8).
chunks.english: The ignorance of shepherds is rebuked by the voice of Truth, when it is said through the prophet in the book of Isaiah, chapter fifty-six, verse eleven: The shepherds themselves have not known understanding. Whom again the Lord detests, saying in the book of Jeremiah, chapter two, verse eight: And those holding the law did not know me.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et nesciri ergo se ab eis Veritas queritur, et nescire se principatum nescientium protestatur; quia profecto hi qui ea quae sunt Domini nesciunt, a Domino nesciuntur, Paulo attestante, qui ait: Si quis autem ignorat, ignorabitur (I Cor. XIV, 38).
chunks.english: And therefore Truth complains that it is not known by them, and protests that it does not know the rule of those who do not know; because certainly those who do not know the things that are the Lord's are not known by the Lord, with Paul testifying, who says in Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, chapter fourteen, verse thirty-eight: But if anyone is ignorant, he shall be ignored.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerumque pastorum imperitia meritis congruit subjectorum, quia quamvis lumen scientiae sua culpa exigente non habeant, districto tamen judicio agitur, ut per eorum ignorantiam hi etiam qui sequuntur offendant.
chunks.english: Often the ignorance of shepherds corresponds to the merits of subjects, because although they do not have the light of knowledge through their own demanding fault, yet by strict judgment it is arranged that through their ignorance even those who follow may stumble.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc namque in Evangelio per semetipsam Veritas dicit: Si caecus caeco ducatum praebeat, ambo in foveam cadunt (Matth. XV, 14).
chunks.english: Hence indeed in the Gospel, Truth itself says in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter fifteen, verse fourteen: If a blind man leads a blind man, both fall into a pit.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc Psalmista, non optantis animo, sed prophetantis mysterio denuntiat, dicens: Obscurentur oculi eorum, ne videant, et dorsum illorum semper incurva (Ps. LXVIII, 24).
chunks.english: Hence the Psalmist, not with the spirit of one wishing but with the mystery of one prophesying, announces, saying in Psalm sixty-eight, verse twenty-four: Let their eyes be darkened, that they may not see, and always bow down their back.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Oculi quippe sunt qui in ipsa honoris summi facie positi providendi itineris officium susceperunt; quibus hi nimirum qui subsequenter inhaerent dorsa nominantur. Obscuratis ergo oculis dorsum flectitur, quia cum lumen scientiae perdunt qui praeeunt, profecto ad portanda peccatorum curvantur onera qui sequuntur.
chunks.english: The eyes indeed are those who, placed in the very face of highest honor, have undertaken the duty of providing the way; to whom certainly those who follow behind are called backs. Therefore when the eyes are darkened the back is bent, because when those who lead lose the light of knowledge, certainly those who follow are bent to bearing the burdens of sins.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Indigni quique tanti reatus pondere fugerent, si Veritatis sententiam sollicita cordis aure pensarent, quae ait: Qui scandalizaverit unum de pusillis istis qui in me credunt, expedit ei ut suspendatur mola asinaria collo ejus, et demergatur in profundum maris (Matth. XVIII, 6).
chunks.english: Each unworthy person would flee from the weight of so great a guilt, if they would weigh with careful ear of heart the sentence of Truth, which says in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter eighteen, verse six: Whoever causes one of these little ones who believe in me to stumble, it would be better for him that a millstone be hung around his neck, and he be drowned in the depth of the sea.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ne temerare sacra regimina quisquis his impar est audeat, et per concupiscentiam culminis ducatum suscipiat perditionis.
chunks.english: Lest anyone unequal to these things dare to violate sacred governances, and through desire for the summit undertake leadership of perdition.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc enim pie Jacobus prohibet, dicens: Nolite plures magistri fieri, fratres mei (Jacob. III, 1). Hinc ipse Dei hominumque Mediator regnum percipere vitavit in terris, qui supernorum spirituum quoque scientiam sensumque transcendens ante saecula regnat in coelis.
chunks.english: Hence piously James forbids, saying in the letter of James, chapter three, verse one: Do not become many teachers, my brothers. Hence the very Mediator of God and humanity avoided receiving a kingdom on earth, who transcending even the knowledge and understanding of heavenly spirits reigns in heaven before the ages.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerumque adversitatis magisterio sub disciplina cor premitur; quod si ad regiminis culmen erupit, in elationem protinus usu gloriae permutatur.
chunks.english: Often by the teaching of adversity the heart is pressed under discipline; which if it breaks out to the summit of governance, is immediately changed into exaltation by the use of glory.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sic Saul, qui indignum se prius considerans fugerat, mox ut regni gubernacula percepit, intumuit: honorari namque coram populo cupiens, dum reprehendi publice noluit, ipsum qui in regno se unxerat scidit (I Reg. X, 22; XV, 17, 30; Act. XIII, 22; II Reg. XI, 3).
chunks.english: Thus Saul, who previously considering himself unworthy had fled, as soon as he received the reins of the kingdom, swelled up: for desiring to be honored before the people, while unwilling to be reproved publicly, he tore apart the very one who had anointed him in the kingdom, as recounted in the first book of Samuel, chapter ten, verse twenty-two; chapter fifteen, verses seventeen and thirty; in the Acts of the Apostles, chapter thirteen, verse twenty-two; and in the second book of Samuel, chapter eleven, verse three.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sic David propheta auctoris judicio pene in cunctis actibus placens, mox ut pressurae pondere caruit, in tumorem vulneris erupit, factusque est in morte viri crudeliter rigidus, qui in appetitu feminae fuit enerviter fluxus: et qui malis ante noverat pie parcere, in bonorum quoque necem post didicit sine obstaculo retractationis anhelare (II Reg. XI, 15).
chunks.english: Thus David the prophet, pleasing to the Creator's judgment in almost all his actions, as soon as he lacked the weight of pressure, broke out into the swelling of a wound, and became cruelly rigid in the death of a man, who had been weakly dissolute in the desire for a woman: and he who before had known how to mercifully spare the wicked, afterward learned to pant without obstacle of reconsideration even for the death of the good, as in the second book of Samuel, chapter eleven, verse fifteen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Prius quippe ferire deprehensum persecutorem noluit, et post cum damno desudantis exercitus etiam devotum militem exstinxit. Quem profecto ab electorum numero culpa longius raperet, nisi hunc ad veniam flagella revocassent.
chunks.english: For previously he was unwilling to strike the persecutor he had caught, and afterward with the loss of his toiling army he even killed a devoted soldier. Whom indeed guilt would have carried farther from the number of the elect, had not scourges recalled him to pardon.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerumque qui subire magisterium pastorale cupiunt, nonnulla quoque bona opera animo proponunt. Et quamvis hoc elationis intentione appetant, operaturos tamen se magna pertractant: fitque ut aliud in imis intentio supprimat, aliud tractantis animo superficies cogitationis ostendat.
chunks.english: Often those who desire to undertake pastoral teaching also propose certain good works in their mind. And although they seek this with the intention of exaltation, yet they contemplate doing great things: and it happens that one thing the intention suppresses in the depths, another the surface of thought shows to the deliberating mind.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam sibi ipsa de se mens saepe mentitur, et fingit se de bono opere amare quod non amat, de mundi autem gloria non amare quod amat; saepe mens principare appetens fit ad hoc pavida cum quaerit, audax cum pervenit.
chunks.english: For the mind often lies to itself about itself, and pretends to love about good work what it does not love, and not to love about worldly glory what it does love; often the mind desiring to rule becomes fearful about this when it seeks, bold when it arrives.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tendens enim, ne non perveniat trepidat; sed repente perveniens, jure sibi hoc debitum ad quod pervenerit putat. Cumque percepti principatus officio perfrui saeculariter coeperit, libenter obliviscitur quidquid religiose cogitavit.
chunks.english: For striving, it trembles lest it not arrive; but suddenly arriving, it thinks this to which it has arrived due to it by right. And when it has begun to enjoy the office of received principality in a worldly manner, it gladly forgets whatever it thought religiously.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Necesse est ut cum cogitatio extra usum ducitur, protinus mentis oculus ad opera transacta revocetur: ac penset quisquis quid subjectus egerit, et repente cognoscit si praelatus bona agere quae proposuerit possit.
chunks.english: It is necessary that when thought is led outside of use, immediately the eye of the mind be recalled to deeds done: and let each one weigh what he did as a subject, and suddenly he knows if as a prelate he can do the good things he proposed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nequaquam valet in culmine humilitatem discere, qui in imis positus non desiit superbire. Nescit laudem, cum suppetit fugere, qui ad hanc didicit cum deesset, anhelare.
chunks.english: He who placed at the bottom has not ceased to be proud by no means can learn humility at the summit. He does not know how to flee praise when it is abundant, who has learned to pant after it when it is lacking.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nequaquam vincere avaritiam potest, quando ad multorum sustentationem tenditur is cui sufficere propria nec soli potuerunt. Ex ante acta ergo vita se quisque inveniat, ne in appetitu se culminis imago cogitationis illudat.
chunks.english: He by no means can conquer avarice, when he who could not be satisfied with his own things even alone is stretched to the sustenance of many. Therefore from his previously lived life let each one discover himself, lest in the desire for the summit the image of thought deceive him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerumque in occupatione regiminis ipse quoque boni operis usus perditur qui in tranquillitate tenebatur, quia quieto mari recte navem et imperitus dirigit, turbatus autem tempestatis fluctibus etiam peritus se nauta confundit.
chunks.english: Often in the occupation of governance even the practice of good work itself is lost which was held in tranquility, because on a calm sea even the inexperienced rightly steers a ship, but when disturbed by the waves of tempest even the skilled sailor confounds himself.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid est potestas culminis nisi tempestas mentis? In qua cogitationum semper procellis cordis navis quatitur, huc illucque incessanter impellitur, ut per repentinos excessus oris et operis, quasi per obviantia saxa, frangatur.
chunks.english: What is the power of the summit but a tempest of the mind? In which the ship of the heart is always shaken by storms of thoughts, incessantly driven here and there, so that through sudden excesses of mouth and work, as through opposing rocks, it may be broken.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Inter haec quae protulimus, quid sequendum est, quid tenendum, nisi ut virtutibus pollens coactus ad regimen veniat, virtutibus vacuus nec coactus accedat?
chunks.english: Among these things which we have brought forth, what is to be followed, what to be held, except that he who is strong in virtues should come to governance when compelled, and he who is empty of virtues should not approach even when compelled?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ille si omnino renititur, caveat ne acceptam pecuniam in sudarium ligans, de ejus occultatione judicetur (Matth. XXV, 18). Pecuniam quippe in sudario ligare est percepta dona sub otio lenti torporis abscondere.
chunks.english: If he utterly resists, let him beware lest binding the received money in a cloth, he be judged for its concealment, as in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-five, verse eighteen. For to bind money in a cloth is to hide received gifts under the leisure of sluggish torpor.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Indignus quisque, cum regimen appetit, attendat ne per exemplum pravi operis pharisaeorum more ad ingressum regni tendentibus obstaculum fiat (Matth., XXIII, 13), qui, juxta Magistri vocem, nec ipsi intrant, nec alios intrare permittunt.
chunks.english: Let each unworthy person, when he desires governance, take heed lest through the example of wicked work in the manner of the Pharisees he become an obstacle to those tending toward entrance to the kingdom, as in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twenty-three, verse thirteen, who, according to the Master's voice, neither enter themselves, nor permit others to enter.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Considerandum quoque est quia cum causam populi electus praesul suscipit, quasi ad aegrum medicus accedit. Si ergo adhuc ejus in opere passiones vivunt, qua praesumptione percussum mederi properat qui in facie vulnus portat?
chunks.english: It must also be considered that when an elected bishop takes up the cause of the people, he approaches like a physician to the sick. If therefore passions still live in his work, with what presumption does he hasten to heal the wounded who bears a wound in his face?

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Power Given to Bishops to Bind and Loose
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXXVIII. De collata episcopis potestate ligandi atque solvendi.
chunks.english: Chapter thirty-eight: On the power conferred to bishops of binding and loosing.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Praedicatores sancti qui districtum Dei judicium metuunt animarum judices fiunt, et alios damnant vel liberant, qui semetipsos damnari metuebant.
chunks.english: Holy preachers who fear the strict judgment of God become judges of souls, and condemn or free others, who feared to be condemned themselves.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Horum profecto nunc in Ecclesia episcopi locum tenent. Solvendi atque ligandi auctoritatem suscipiunt, qui gradum regiminis sortiuntur.
chunks.english: Of these indeed now in the Church bishops hold the place. They receive the authority of loosing and binding, who obtain the rank of governance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Grandis honor pontificalis, sed grave pondus est istius honoris. Durum quippe est ut qui nescit tenere moderamina vitae suae, judex vitae fiat alienae.
chunks.english: Great is the honor of a bishop, but heavy is the weight of this honor. For it is hard that he who does not know how to hold the reins of his own life should become judge of another's life.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerumque contingit ut ipse judicii locum teneat, cui ad locum vita minime concordat. Et saepe agitur ut vel damnet immeritos, vel alios ipse ligatus solvat.
chunks.english: It often happens that he himself holds the place of judgment, for whom life by no means agrees with the place. And it is often done that he either condemns the undeserving, or himself bound looses others.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Saepe in solvendis ac ligandis subditis suae voluntatis motus, non autem causarum merita sequitur. Unde fit ut ipsa hac ligandi et solvendi potestate se privet, qui hanc pro suis voluntatibus et non pro subjectorum meritis exercet.
chunks.english: Often in loosing and binding subjects he follows the movements of his own will, not however the merits of the cases. Whence it happens that he deprives himself of this very power of binding and loosing, who exercises it according to his own wills and not according to the merits of subjects.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Saepe fit ut erga quemlibet proximum odio vel gratia moveatur pastor. Judicare autem digne de subditis nequeunt qui in subditorum causis sua vel odia vel gratiam sequuntur.
chunks.english: It often happens that a shepherd is moved by hatred or favor toward any neighbor. But those who in the cases of subjects follow their own hatreds or favors cannot judge worthily about subjects.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde recte per prophetam dicitur: Mortificabant animas quae non moriuntur, et vivificabant animas quae non vivunt (Ezech., XIII, 19). Non morientem quippe mortificat qui justum damnat, et non victurum vivificare nititur qui reum a supplicio absolvere conatur.
chunks.english: Whence it is rightly said through the prophet in the book of Ezekiel, chapter thirteen, verse nineteen: They were killing souls that should not die, and giving life to souls that should not live. For he kills one who will not die who condemns the just, and strives to give life to one who will not live who attempts to absolve the guilty from punishment.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Deus omnipotens, ut nos a praecipitatae sententiae prolatione compesceret, cum omnia nuda et aperta sint oculis ejus, mala tamen Sodomae noluit audita judicare, qui ait: Descendam et videbo, utrum clamorem qui venit ad me opere compleverint, an non est ita, ut sciam (Gen. XVIII, 20).
chunks.english: Almighty God, in order to restrain us from pronouncing hasty sentence, when all things are naked and open to his eyes, nevertheless was unwilling to judge the evils of Sodom by hearsay, who said in the book of Genesis, chapter eighteen, verse twenty: I will go down and see, whether they have done altogether according to the cry that has come to me, or whether it is not so, that I may know.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Omnipotens itaque Dominus et omnia sciens, cur ante probationem quasi dubitat, nisi ut gravitatis exemplum nobis proponat, ne mala hominum ante praesumamus credere quam probare?
chunks.english: The almighty Lord therefore, knowing all things, why does he as it were doubt before proof, except to propose to us an example of gravity, lest we presume to believe the evils of people before proving them?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid hoc exemplo nisi nos admonemur, ne ad proferendam sententiam unquam praecipites esse debeamus, ne temere indiscussa judicemus, ne quaelibet mala audita nos moveant, ne passim dicta sine probatione credamus?
chunks.english: What by this example except we are admonished, that we should never be hasty in pronouncing sentence, that we should not rashly judge things not examined, that any evils heard should not move us, that we should not everywhere believe things said without proof?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Causae videlicet pensandae sunt, et tunc ligandi atque solvendi potestas exercenda.
chunks.english: Causes certainly must be weighed, and then the power of binding and loosing is to be exercised.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Videndum quae culpa, aut quae sit poenitentia secuta post culpam, ut quos omnipotens Deus per compunctionis gratiam visitat, illos pastoris sententia absolvat. Tunc vera est absolutio praesidentis, cum interni arbitrium sequitur judicis.
chunks.english: It must be seen what the fault is, or what penance has followed after the fault, so that those whom almighty God visits through the grace of compunction, the sentence of the shepherd may absolve. Then the absolution of the one presiding is true, when it follows the judgment of the inner Judge.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod bene quatriduani mortui resuscitatio illa significat, quae videlicet demonstrat quia prius mortuum Dominus vocavit et vivificavit dicens: Lazare, veni foras (Joan. XI, 43); et postmodum is qui vivens egressus fuerat a discipulis est solutus, sicut scriptum est: Cumque egressus esset, qui fuerat ligatus institis, tunc dixit Jesus discipulis suis: Solvite eum et sinite abire (Ibid., 45).
chunks.english: Which the resurrection of the four-day dead man well signifies, which indeed demonstrates that first the Lord called the dead man and gave him life saying, as in the Gospel of John, chapter eleven, verse forty-three: Lazarus, come forth; and afterward he who had come forth alive was loosed by the disciples, as it is written: And when he who had been bound with strips had come forth, then Jesus said to his disciples: Loose him and let him go, from the same chapter, verse forty-five.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Scilicet ut pastores Ecclesiae ei poenam debeant amovere quam meruit qui non erubuit confiteri quod fecit.
chunks.english: Namely so that shepherds of the Church ought to remove the punishment from him who was not ashamed to confess what he did.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sub magno moderamine pastores Ecclesiae vel solvere studeant vel ligare. Sed utrum juste an injuste obliget pastor, pastoris tamen sententia gregi timenda est: ne is qui subest, et cum injuste forsitan ligatur, obligationis suae sententiam ex alia culpa mereatur.
chunks.english: Under great moderation let shepherds of the Church strive either to loose or to bind. But whether the shepherd binds justly or unjustly, nevertheless the sentence of the shepherd is to be feared by the flock: lest he who is subject, even when perhaps bound unjustly, deserves the sentence of his binding from another fault.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Pastor quisque vel absolvere indiscrete timeat, vel ligare. Is autem qui sub manu pastoris est, ligari timeat juste vel injuste. Nec pastoris sui judicium temere reprehendat, ne et si injuste ligatus est, ex ipsa tumidae reprehensionis superbia, culpa quae non erat, fiat.
chunks.english: Let each shepherd fear either to absolve or to bind indiscretely. But he who is under the hand of the shepherd, let him fear to be bound justly or unjustly. Nor let him rashly reproach the judgment of his shepherd, lest even if he was bound unjustly, from the very pride of swollen reproach, a fault which was not, may come to be.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Corruption of Shepherds Walking in Error
chunks.latin: CAPUT XXXIX. De pastoribus non recte gradientibus.
chunks.english: Chapter thirty-nine: On shepherds not walking rightly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt nonnulli qui solerti cura spiritualia praecepta perscrutantur, sed quae intelligendo penetrant vivendo conculcant. Repente docent quae non opere, sed meditatione didicerunt, et quod verbis praedicant moribus impugnant.
chunks.english: There are some who with careful attention scrutinize spiritual precepts, but what they penetrate by understanding they trample by living. Suddenly they teach what they have learned not by work but by meditation, and what they preach in words they attack by conduct.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde fit ut cum pastor per abrupta graditur, ad praecipitium grex sequatur. Per prophetam Dominus contra contemptibilem pastorum scientiam queritur, dicens: Cum ipsi limpidissimam aquam biberetis, reliquam pedibus vestris turbabatis, et oves meae, quae conculcata pedibus vestris fuerant, pascebantur, et quae pedes vestri turbaverant, haec bibebant (Ezech. XXXIV, 18, 19).
chunks.english: Whence it happens that when the shepherd walks through precipices, the flock follows to the precipice. Through the prophet the Lord complains against the contemptible knowledge of shepherds, saying in the book of Ezekiel, chapter thirty-four, verses eighteen and nineteen: When you yourselves drank the clearest water, you troubled the rest with your feet, and my sheep fed on what had been trampled by your feet, and they drank what your feet had troubled.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aquam quippe limpidissimam pastores bibunt, cum fluenta veritatis recte intelligentes hauriunt, sed eamdem aquam pedibus turbare est sanctae meditationis studia male vivendo corrumpere.
chunks.english: For shepherds drink the clearest water when, rightly understanding the streams of truth, they draw them in, but to trouble this same water with their feet is to corrupt the studies of holy meditation by living badly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aquam scilicet pastorum turbatam pedibus oves bibunt, cum subjecti quique non sectantur verba quae audiunt, sed sola quae conspiciunt exempla pravitatis imitantur.
chunks.english: The sheep certainly drink water troubled by the feet of shepherds, when each of the subjects does not follow the words they hear, but imitates only the examples of depravity which they see.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui cum dicta sitiunt, quia per opera pervertuntur, quasi corruptis fontibus in potibus lutum sumunt. Nemo amplius in Ecclesia nocet quam qui perverse agens nomen vel ordinem sanctitatis habet.
chunks.english: Who when they thirst for the words, because they are perverted through works, as if from corrupted fountains they take mud in their drinks. No one harms more in the Church than he who acting perversely has the name or order of sanctity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Delinquentem namque hunc redarguere nullus praesumit, et in exemplum culpa vehementer extenditur, quando pro reverentia ordinis peccator honoratur.
chunks.english: For no one presumes to rebuke this one who is offending, and the fault is vehemently extended into example, when the sinner is honored out of reverence for his order.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui ad sanctitatis speciem deductus vel verbo caeteros destruit vel exemplo, melius profecto fuerat ut hunc ad mortem sub exteriori habitu terrena acta constringerent, quam sacra officia in culpa caeteris imitabilem demonstrarent: quia nimirum si solus caderet, utcunque hunc tolerabilior inferni poena cruciaret.
chunks.english: He who, led to the appearance of sanctity, destroys others either by word or by example, it would certainly have been better that earthly actions had constrained him to death under external garb, than that sacred offices demonstrated him imitable to others in guilt: because doubtless if he fell alone, a more tolerable punishment of hell would somehow torment him.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Saepe suscepta cura regiminis cor per diversa diverberat, et impar quisque invenitur ad singula, dum confusa mente dividitur ad multa.
chunks.english: Often the care of governance undertaken tears the heart through various things, and each one is found unequal to individual matters, while divided to many things with confused mind.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde quidam sapiens provide prohibet dicens: Fili, ne in multis sint actus tui (Eccli. XI, 10); quia videlicet nequaquam plene in uniuscujusque operis ratione colligitur, dum mens per diversa partitur.
chunks.english: Whence a certain wise man providently forbids saying in the book of Sirach, chapter eleven, verse ten: Son, let not your undertakings be many; because certainly one is by no means fully gathered in the reason of each work, while the mind is divided through diverse things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cumque foras per insolentem curam trahitur, a timoris intimi soliditate vacuatur. Dum mens in exteriorum fit dispositione sollicita, sui est solummodo ignara, et scit multa cogitare se nesciens.
chunks.english: And when it is drawn outward through inordinate care, it is emptied of the solidity of intimate fear. While the mind becomes anxious in the disposition of external things, it is ignorant only of itself, and knows many things while not knowing itself.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam cum plus quam necesse est se exterioribus implicat, quasi occupata in itinere obliviscitur quo tendebat. Ita ut ab studio suae inquisitionis aliena, ne ipsa quidem quae patitur damna consideret, et per quanta delinquat ignoret.
chunks.english: For when it entangles itself more than necessary in external things, as if occupied on a journey it forgets where it was heading. So that estranged from the study of its own inquiry, it does not even consider the very losses it suffers, and is ignorant through how many things it transgresses.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ezechias Rex peccare se minime credidit, cum venientibus ad se alienigenis cellas aromatum ostendit (IV Reg. X, 13): sed in damnatione secuturae prolis ex eo iram Judicis pertulit (Isai. XXXIX, 4), quod se facere licenter aestimavit.
chunks.english: King Hezekiah by no means believed himself to sin, when he showed the storerooms of spices to foreigners coming to him, as in the fourth book of Kings, chapter ten, verse thirteen: but he bore the anger of the Judge in the damnation of his offspring to come from this, as in the book of Isaiah, chapter thirty-nine, verse four, because he judged himself to do it lawfully.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Saepe dum multa suppetunt, dumque agi possunt quae subjecti, quia acta sunt, admirentur, in cogitatione se animus elevat, et plene in se iram Judicis provocat, quamvis per iniqua foras opera non erumpat.
chunks.english: Often while many things are abundant, and while things can be done which subjects, because they are done, admire, the spirit elevates itself in thought, and fully provokes in itself the anger of the Judge, although it does not break forth through wicked works outwardly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Intus quippe est qui judicat, intus quod judicatur. Cum ergo in corde delinquimus, latet homines quid apud nos agimus, sed tamen ipso Judice teste peccamus.
chunks.english: For within is he who judges, within is what is judged. When therefore we transgress in the heart, what we do with ourselves is hidden from people, but nevertheless with the Judge himself as witness we sin.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Haec proferentes non potestatem regiminis reprehendimus, sed ab appetitu illius cordis infirmitatem munimus, ne imperfecti quique culmen arripere regiminis audeant, et qui in planis stantes titubant, in praecipiti pedem ponant.
chunks.english: Bringing forth these things we do not reprove the power of governance, but we fortify the weakness of the heart from the appetite for it, lest each of the imperfect dare to seize the summit of governance, and those who standing on level ground totter, place their foot on a precipice.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Caecus pastor est, qui supernae lumen contemplationis ignorat (Levit. XXI, 18); qui praesentis vitae tenebris pressus, dum venturam lucem nequaquam diligendo conspicit, quo gressum operis porrigat, nescit.
chunks.english: A blind shepherd is he who is ignorant of the light of heavenly contemplation, as in the book of Leviticus, chapter twenty-one, verse eighteen; who pressed by the shadows of present life, while he by no means sees by loving the coming light, does not know where to extend the step of work.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Claudus vero rector est, qui quidem quo pergere debeat aspicit, sed per infirmitatem mentis vitae viam perfecte non valet tenere quam videt; quia ad virtutis statum dum fluxa consuetudo non erigitur, quo ex desiderio nititur, illuc gressus efficaciter non sequuntur.
chunks.english: But the lame leader is he who indeed sees where he ought to go, but through weakness of mind is not able to hold perfectly the way of life which he sees; because while weak habit is not raised up to the state of virtue, where he strives from desire, there the steps do not effectively follow.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Parvo autem naso est, qui ad tenendam mensuram discretionis idoneus non est. Naso quippe odores fetoresque discernimus. Recte ergo per nasum discretio exprimitur, per quam virtutes eligimus, delicta reprobamus.
chunks.english: But he has a small nose, who is not suitable for holding the measure of discretion. For by the nose we discern odors and stenches. Therefore rightly discretion is expressed through the nose, through which we choose virtues, we reprove offenses.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt nonnulli qui, dum aestimari hebetes nolunt, saepe se in quibusdam inquisitionibus plusquam necesse est exercentes ex nimia subtilitate falluntur. Unde recte dicitur: Vel grandi et torto naso (Ibid.).
chunks.english: There are some who, while unwilling to be judged dull, often exercising themselves in certain inquiries more than necessary are deceived from excessive subtlety. Whence it is rightly said: Or with a large and twisted nose, from the same passage.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nasus etenim grandis et tortus est discretionis subtilitas immoderata, quae dum plus quam decet excreverit, actionis suae rectitudinem ipsa confundit.
chunks.english: For a large and twisted nose is immoderate subtlety of discretion, which while it has grown more than is proper, confounds the very rectitude of its action.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Fracto pede vel manu est, qui viam Domini pergere omnino non valet, atque a bonis actibus funditus exsors vacat; quatenus haec non ut claudus saltem cum infirmitate teneat, sed ab his omnimodo alienus existat.
chunks.english: He has a broken foot or hand, who is utterly unable to walk the way of the Lord, and vacantly is completely devoid of good actions; so that he does not hold these at least as a lame man with weakness, but exists altogether estranged from these.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Gibbus vero est, quem terrenae sollicitudinis pondus deprimit, ne unquam ad superna respiciat, sed solis his quae in infimis calcantur intendat.
chunks.english: But he is hunchbacked, whom the weight of earthly solicitude depresses, so that he never looks to things above, but attends only to those things which are trampled in the lowest places.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui etsi aliquando aliquid ex bono patriae coelestis audierit, ad hoc nimirum perversae consuetudinis pondere praegravatus, cordis faciem non attollit, quia cogitationis statum erigere non valet quem terrenae usus sollicitudinis curvum tenet.
chunks.english: Who even if he has at some time heard something from the good of the heavenly homeland, to this indeed weighed down by the weight of perverse habit, does not lift up the face of his heart, because he is not able to raise up the state of thought which the use of earthly solicitude holds bent.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Lippus namque est, cujus quidem ingenium ad cognitionem veritatis emicat, sed tamen hoc carnalia opera obscurant. In lippis quippe oculis pupillae sanae sunt, sed humore defluente infirmantia palpebra grossescunt.
chunks.english: For he is blear-eyed, whose talent indeed shines forth to knowledge of truth, but nevertheless carnal works obscure this. For in blear eyes the pupils are healthy, but with humor flowing down the weakening eyelids thicken.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quorum quia infusione crebro atteritur, etiam acies pupillae vitiatur. Sunt nonnulli quorum sensum carnalis vitae operatio sauciat, qui videre recta subtiliter per ingenium poterant, sed usu pravorum actum caligant.
chunks.english: Because their infusion frequently wears away, even the sharpness of the pupil is impaired. There are some whose sense the operation of carnal life wounds, who were able to see right things subtly through talent, but by the use of depraved actions they grow dim.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Lippus itaque est, cujus sensum natura exacuit, sed conversationis pravitas confundit. Cui bene per angelum dicitur: Collyrio inunge oculos tuos, ut videas (Apoc. III, 18).
chunks.english: Therefore he is blear-eyed, whose sense nature has sharpened, but the depravity of behavior confounds. To whom well through the angel it is said in the book of Revelation, chapter three, verse eighteen: Anoint your eyes with salve, that you may see.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Collyrio quippe oculos, ut videamus, inungimus, cum ad cognoscendam veri luminis claritatem intellectus nostri aciem medicamine bonae operationis adjuvamus.
chunks.english: For we anoint our eyes with salve that we may see, when we assist the sharpness of our understanding to know the clarity of true light with the medicine of good operation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Albuginem habet sacerdos in oculo, qui veritatis lucem videre non sinitur, quia arrogantia sapientiae sive justitiae caecatur.
chunks.english: The priest has a white film in his eye, who is not permitted to see the light of truth, because he is blinded by the arrogance of wisdom or justice.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Pupilla namque oculi nigra videt, albuginem tolerans nil videt, quia videlicet sensus humanae cogitationis, si stultum se peccatoremque intelligit, cogitationem intimae claritatis apprehendit.
chunks.english: For the black pupil of the eye sees, one bearing a white film sees nothing, because certainly the sense of human thought, if it understands itself foolish and sinful, apprehends the thought of intimate clarity.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si autem candorem sibi justitiae seu sapientiae tribuit, a luce se supernae cogitationis excludit, et eo claritatem veri luminis nequaquam penetrat, quo se apud se per arrogantiam exaltat.
chunks.english: But if it attributes to itself the whiteness of justice or wisdom, it excludes itself from the light of heavenly thought, and by no means penetrates the clarity of true light, by which it exalts itself with itself through arrogance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sicut de quibusdam dicitur: Dicentes enim se esse sapientes, stulti facti sunt (Rom. I, 22).
chunks.english: As it is said of certain ones in Paul's letter to the Romans, chapter one, verse twenty-two: For professing themselves to be wise, they became fools.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Jugem habet scabiem in corpore, cui carnis petulantia sine cessatione dominatur in mente. In scabie etenim fervor viscerum ad cutem trahitur.
chunks.english: He has constant scab in the body, to whom the wantonness of the flesh dominates without cessation in the mind. For in scab the fervor of the internal organs is drawn to the skin.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Per quam recte luxuria designatur, quia si cordis tentatio usque ad operationem prosilit, nimirum fervor intimus usque ad cutis scabiem prorumpit: foras corpus scabies sauciat, quia dum in cognitione voluptas non reprimitur, etiam in actione dominatur.
chunks.english: Through which rightly luxury is designated, because if the temptation of the heart leaps forth even to operation, doubtless the intimate fervor breaks forth even to the scab of the skin: scab wounds the body outwardly, because while pleasure is not restrained in knowledge, it also dominates in action.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quasi enim cutis pruriginem Paulus curabat abstergere, cum dicebat: Tentatio vos non apprehendat, nisi humana (I Cor. X, 13); ac si aperte diceret: Humanum quidem est in corde tentationem perpeti, daemoniacum vero est in tentationis certamine et in operatione superari.
chunks.english: For Paul was taking care to wipe away as it were the itching of the skin, when he said in Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, chapter ten, verse thirteen: Let no temptation take hold of you, except what is human; as if he openly said: It is indeed human to endure temptation in the heart, but it is demonic to be overcome in the struggle of temptation and in operation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Impetiginem habet in corpore quisquis avaritia vastatur in mente, quae si in parvis non compescitur, nimirum sine mensura dilatatur.
chunks.english: He has impetigo in the body, whoever is devastated by avarice in the mind, which if not restrained in small things, doubtless dilates without measure.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Impetigo quippe sine dolore corpus occupat, et absque occupati taedio excrescens membrorum decorem foedat; quia et avaritia capti animum, dum quasi delectat, exulcerat; dum adipiscenda quaeque cogitationi objicit, ad inimicitias accendit, et dolorem in vulnere non facit, quia aestuanti animo ex culpa abundantiam promittit.
chunks.english: For impetigo occupies the body without pain, and growing without disgust of the occupied one defiles the beauty of the members; because avarice also ulcerates the captured soul, while as it were it delights; while it presents to thought each thing to be obtained, it kindles to enmities, and does not make pain in the wound, because to the burning spirit from guilt it promises abundance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Decor membrorum per impetiginem perditur, quia aliarum quoque virtutum per avaritiam pulchritudo depravatur; et quasi totum corpus exasperat, quia per universa vitia animum supplantat, Paulo attestante, qui ait: Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas (I Tim. VI, 10).
chunks.english: The beauty of members is destroyed through impetigo, because also the beauty of other virtues is depraved through avarice; and as it were it roughens the whole body, because it undermines the soul through all vices, with Paul testifying, who says in Paul's first letter to Timothy, chapter six, verse ten: The root of all evils is greed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ponderosus est qui turpitudinem non exercet opere, sed tamen ab hac cogitatione continua sine moderamine gravatur in mente: qui nequaquam quidem usque ad opus nefarium rapitur, sed ejus animus voluptate luxuriae sine ullo repugnationis stimulo delectatur.
chunks.english: He is heavy with weight who does not practice filthiness in work, but nevertheless is weighed down in mind by this continuous thought without moderation: who indeed is by no means carried away even to wicked work, but his spirit is delighted by the pleasure of luxury without any sting of resistance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Vitium quippe est ponderis, cum humor viscerum ad virilia labitur, quae profecto cum molestia dedecoris intumescunt.
chunks.english: For it is the vice of weight, when the humor of the internal organs slips to the private parts, which certainly swell with the annoyance of disgrace.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ponderosus est, qui totis cogitationibus ad lasciviam defluens pondus turpitudinis gestat in corde; et quamvis prava non exerceat opere, ab his tamen non evellitur mente.
chunks.english: He is heavy with weight, who flowing down with all thoughts to lasciviousness bears the weight of filthiness in his heart; and although he does not practice wicked things in work, nevertheless he is not torn away from these in mind.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nec ad usum boni operis in aperto valet surgere, quia grave hunc in abditis pondus turpat.
chunks.english: Nor can he rise in the open to the practice of good work, because a heavy weight defiles him in hidden things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quisquis ergo quolibet horum vitio subigitur, panes Domino offerre prohibetur, ne profecto diluere aliena delicta non valeat is quem adhuc propria devastant.
chunks.english: Whoever therefore is subdued by any of these vices, is forbidden to offer bread to the Lord, lest certainly he who is still devastated by his own offenses may not be able to wash away the offenses of others.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum sacerdos non agit bona quae loquitur, ei etiam sermo subtrahitur, ne loqui audeat quod non operatur, sicut per prophetam dicitur: Peccatori autem dixit Deus: Quare tu enarras justitias meas, et assumis testamentum meum per os tuum (Ps. XLIX, 16)?
chunks.english: When a priest does not do the good things which he speaks, even speech is withdrawn from him, lest he dare to speak what he does not perform, as it is said through the prophet in Psalm forty-nine, verse sixteen: But to the sinner God said: Why do you declare my justices, and take my covenant in your mouth?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde etiam Psalmista deprecatur dicens: Et ne auferas de ore meo verbum veritatis usquequaque (Ps. CXVIII, 43).
chunks.english: Whence also the Psalmist prays saying in Psalm one hundred eighteen, verse forty-three: And do not take away the word of truth utterly from my mouth.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Perpendit namque quod omnipotens Deus veritatis verbum facientibus tribuit, et non facientibus tollit.
chunks.english: For he weighs that almighty God grants the word of truth to those doing it, and takes it away from those not doing it.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui ergo hoc de ore suo non auferri petiit, quid aliud quam gratiam bonae operationis quaesivit? Ac si aperte diceret: A bono opere errare me non sinas, ne dum amitto ordinem bene vivendi, rectitudinem perdam loquendi.
chunks.english: He therefore who asked that this not be taken away from his mouth, what else did he seek than the grace of good operation? As if he openly said: Do not allow me to err from good work, lest while I lose the order of living well, I lose the rectitude of speaking.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerumque doctor qui docere audet quod negligit agere, cum desierit bona loqui quae operari contempsit, docere subjectos incipit prava quae agit, ut justo omnipotentis Dei judicio in bono jam nec linguam habeat qui habere bonam vitam recusat; quatenus cum mens ejus terrenarum rerum amore incenditur, de terrenis rebus semper loquatur.
chunks.english: Often the teacher who dares to teach what he neglects to do, when he has ceased to speak the good things which he scorned to perform, begins to teach subjects the wicked things which he does, so that by the just judgment of almighty God he who refuses to have good life no longer has even a tongue in good; so that when his mind is inflamed with love of earthly things, he may always speak about earthly things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde in Evangelio Veritas dicit: Ex abundantia cordis os loquitur (Matth. XII, 34). Bonus homo de bono thesauro profert bona, et malus homo de malo thesauro profert mala (Luc. VI, 45). Hinc etiam Joannes ait: Ipsi de mundo sunt, ideo de mundo loquuntur (I Joan. IV, 5).
chunks.english: Whence in the Gospel Truth says in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter twelve, verse thirty-four: Out of the abundance of the heart the mouth speaks. A good man brings forth good things from a good treasure, and an evil man brings forth evil things from an evil treasure, from the Gospel of Luke, chapter six, verse forty-five. Hence also John says in John's first letter, chapter four, verse five: They are of the world, therefore they speak of the world.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Bishops Who Accept Money for Ordinations
chunks.latin: CAPUT XL. De episcopis qui pro ordinationibus munera libenter accipiunt.
chunks.english: Chapter forty: On bishops who willingly accept gifts for ordinations.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nonnulli episcoporum donum accepti Spiritus in usum solent negotiationis inflectere, et miraculorum signa ad avaritiae obsequium declinare.
chunks.english: Some bishops are accustomed to turn the gift of the received Spirit to the use of business, and to decline the signs of miracles to the service of avarice.

chunks.speaker: narrator
