chunks.latin: Hinc est enim quod Simon per impositionem manus edita miracula concupiscens, percipere donum Spiritus sancti pecunia voluit, scilicet, ut deterius venderet quod male comparasset.
chunks.english: Hence it is that Simon, desiring miracles performed through the laying on of hands, wished to receive the gift of the Holy Spirit with money, namely that he might sell worse what he had bought badly, as in the Acts of the Apostles, chapter eight, verse eighteen.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Redemptor noster flagello de resticulis facto de templo turbas ejecit, cathedras vendentium columbas evertit (Joan. II, 15). Columbas quippe vendere est impositionem manus, qua Spiritus accipitur, non ad vitae meritum, sed ad praemium dare.
chunks.english: Our Redeemer with a whip made from cords drove the crowds out of the temple, overturned the chairs of those selling doves, as in the Gospel of John, chapter two, verse fifteen. For to sell doves is to give the laying on of hands, by which the Spirit is received, not for the merit of life, but for a reward.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt nonnulli qui nummorum quidem praemia ex ordinatione non accipiunt, et tamen sacros ordines pro humana gratia largiuntur, atque de largitate eadem laudis solummodo retributionem quaerunt.
chunks.english: There are some who indeed do not accept rewards of money from ordination, and yet bestow sacred orders for human favor, and from this same generosity seek only the repayment of praise.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hi nimirum, quod gratis acceptum est gratis non tribuunt; quia de impenso officio sanctitatis nummum favoris expetunt.
chunks.english: These doubtless do not give freely what was freely received; because from the bestowed office of sanctity they seek the coin of favor.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum justum virum describeret Isaias propheta ait: Qui excutit manus suas ab omni munere (Isa. III, 15). Neque enim dicit: Qui excutit manus suas a munere, sed adjunxit ab omni: quia aliud est munus ab obsequio, aliud munus a manu, aliud munus a lingua.
chunks.english: When the prophet Isaiah described the just man, he said in the book of Isaiah, chapter three, verse fifteen: Who shakes his hands from every gift. For he does not say: Who shakes his hands from a gift, but he added from every: because one thing is a gift from service, another a gift from the hand, another a gift from the tongue.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Munus ab obsequio est subjectio indebite impensa; munus a manu, pecunia; munus a lingua, favor.
chunks.english: A gift from service is subjection unduly bestowed; a gift from the hand is money; a gift from the tongue is favor.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui ergo sacros ordines tribuit, tunc ab omni munere manus excutit, quando in divinis rebus non solum ullam pecuniam, sed etiam humanam gratiam non requirit.
chunks.english: Therefore he who bestows sacred orders then shakes his hands from every gift, when in divine matters he seeks not only no money whatsoever, but also not human favor.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerumque fit ut quisquis aurum, vel bona corporalia ab hominibus accipere contemnat, sed quia haec non accipit, majores ab eis recipere laudes quaerat.
chunks.english: It often happens that whoever scorns to accept gold or bodily goods from people, but because he does not accept these things, seeks to receive greater praises from them.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et fortasse munus se accepisse non aestimat, quia bona corporalia accipere recusat. Sicut superius dictum est, aliquando munus a manu, aliquando vero ab ore porrigitur, nam qui nummum tribuit, munus ex manu dedit; qui autem verbum laudis impendit, munus ab ore protulit.
chunks.english: And perhaps he does not judge that he has received a gift, because he refuses to accept bodily goods. As was said above, sometimes a gift is extended from the hand, sometimes indeed from the mouth, for he who gives a coin, has given a gift from the hand; but he who bestows a word of praise, has brought forth a gift from the mouth.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerumque sacerdos etsi exteriora dona, quae terrenae forsitan necessitati congruunt, pro impositione manuum accipere recusat, plus est quod sibi retribui appetit, cum ultra meritum laudari desiderans, munus ab ore quaerit.
chunks.english: Often a priest, even if he refuses to accept external gifts, which perhaps suit earthly necessity, for the laying on of hands, it is more what he desires to be repaid to him, when desiring to be praised beyond merit, he seeks a gift from the mouth.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: Those Who Refuse Pastoral Office Through Selfish Quietude
chunks.latin: CAPUT XLI. De his qui in regimine prodesse possunt, sed idem officium per quietem propriam refugiunt.
chunks.english: Chapter forty-one: On those who can be of service in governance, but flee this same office through their own quietude.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt nonnulli qui eximia virtutum dona percipiunt, et pro exercitatione caeterorum magnis muneribus exaltantur; qui studio castitatis mundi, abstinentiae robore validi, doctrinae dapibus referti, patientiae longanimitate humiles, auctoritatis fortitudine erecti, pietatis gratia benigni, justitiae severitate districti sunt.
chunks.english: There are some who receive extraordinary gifts of virtues, and are exalted by great gifts for the exercise of others; who are pure in the study of chastity, strong in the vigor of abstinence, filled with the feasts of doctrine, humble in the long-suffering of patience, raised up in the fortitude of authority, kind in the grace of piety, strict in the severity of justice.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qui nimirum culmen regiminum si vocati suscipere renuunt, ipsa sibi plerumque dona adimunt, quae non pro se tantummodo, sed etiam pro aliis acceperunt.
chunks.english: Who doubtless if when called they refuse to undertake the summit of governances, often take away from themselves the very gifts, which they received not only for themselves, but also for others.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cumque sua et non aliorum lucra cogitant, ipsis se, quae privata habere appetunt, bonis privant.
chunks.english: And when they think of their own and not others' gains, they deprive themselves of the very goods, which they desire to have privately.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Discipulis in Evangelio Veritas dicit: Non potest civitas abscondi super montem posita, neque accendunt lucernam, et ponunt eam sub modio, sed super candelabrum, ut luceat omnibus qui in domo sunt (Matth. V, 15).
chunks.english: To the disciples in the Gospel, Truth says in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter five, verse fifteen: A city set on a mountain cannot be hidden, nor do they light a lamp and put it under a bushel, but on a lampstand, that it may give light to all who are in the house.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc Petro ait: Simon Joannis, amas me (Joan. XV, 16, 17)? Qui cum se amare protinus respondisset, audivit: Si diligis me, pasce oves meas.
chunks.english: Hence he says to Peter in the Gospel of John, chapter fifteen, verses sixteen and seventeen: Simon son of John, do you love me? Who when he had immediately responded that he loved, heard: If you love me, feed my sheep.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si ergo dilectionis testimonium est cura pastionis, quisquis virtutibus pollens gregem Dei renuit pascere, pastorem summum convincitur non amare.
chunks.english: If therefore the testimony of love is the care of feeding, whoever strong in virtues refuses to feed the flock of God, is proved not to love the supreme shepherd.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si nostram sicut proximi curam gerimus, quasi utrumque pedem per calceamentum munimus. Qui vero suam cogitans utilitatem, proximorum negligit, quasi unius pedis calceamentum cum dedecore amittit.
chunks.english: If we take care of our own as well as our neighbor's concerns, we fortify as it were both feet through footwear. But he who thinking of his own usefulness neglects neighbors, as it were loses the footwear of one foot with disgrace.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt nonnulli qui magnis muneribus ditati, dum solius contemplationis studiis inardescunt, parere utilitati proximorum in praedicatione refugiunt, secretum quietis diligunt, secessum speculationis appetunt.
chunks.english: There are some who enriched with great gifts, while they burn with the studies of contemplation alone, refuse to serve the usefulness of neighbors in preaching, love the secret of quietude, desire the withdrawal of speculation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: De quo si districte judicentur, ex tantis procul dubio rei sunt quantis venientes ad publicum prodesse potuerunt.
chunks.english: Concerning which if they are strictly judged, they are without doubt guilty of as many things as they could have been of use coming to public life.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Qua mente is qui proximis profuturus enitesceret, utilitati caeterorum secretum praeponit suum, quando ipse summi Patris Unigenitus, ut multis prodesset de sinu Patris egressus est ad publicum nostrum?
chunks.english: With what mind does he who would shine forth to be of use to neighbors place his own secret before the usefulness of others, when the very Only-Begotten of the supreme Father, in order to be of use to many, came forth from the bosom of the Father to our public life?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sunt nonnulli qui ex sola humilitate refugiunt, ne eis quibus se impares aestimant praeferantur. Quorum profecto humilitas, si caeteris quoque virtutibus cingitur, tunc ante oculos Dei vera est, cum ad respuendum hoc quod utiliter subire praecipitur pertinax non est.
chunks.english: There are some who flee from humility alone, lest they be preferred to those to whom they judge themselves unequal. Whose humility indeed, if it is girded with other virtues too, is then true before the eyes of God, when it is not obstinate in refusing this which is commanded to be undertaken usefully.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Neque enim vere est humilis qui superni nutus arbitrium ut debeat praeesse intelligit, et tamen praeesse contemnit. Divinis dispositionibus subditus, atque a vitio obstinationis alienus, cum sibi regiminis culmen imperatur, si jam donis praeventus est, quibus et aliis prosit, et ex corde debet fugere, et invitus obedire.
chunks.english: For he is not truly humble who understands the will of the heavenly nod that he ought to preside, and yet scorns to preside. Subject to divine dispositions, and alien from the vice of obstinacy, when the summit of governance is commanded to him, if he has already been anticipated by gifts, by which he may also be of use to others, both from the heart he ought to flee, and unwillingly to obey.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: The Conduct Expected of Good Subjects Under Authority
chunks.latin: CAPUT XLII. De subjectis bonis sub pastorali regimine constitutis.
chunks.english: Chapter forty-two: On good subjects established under pastoral governance.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Admonendi sunt subditi ne praepositorum suorum vitam temere judicent, si quid eos fortasse agere reprehensibiliter vident, ne unde recte mala redarguunt, inde per elationis impulsum in profundiora mergantur.
chunks.english: Subjects must be admonished not to rashly judge the life of their superiors, if perhaps they see them doing something reprehensibly, lest from where they rightly rebuke evils, from there through the impulse of exaltation they be plunged into deeper things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Admonendi sunt subditi ne cum culpas praepositorum considerant, contra eos audaciores fiant, sed sic, si qua valde sunt eorum prava, apud semetipsos dijudicent, ut tamen divino timore constricti, ferre sub eis jugum reverentiae non recusent.
chunks.english: Subjects must be admonished that when they consider the faults of superiors, they should not become bolder against them, but thus, if certain things are very wicked of them, let them judge among themselves, so that nevertheless constrained by divine fear, they do not refuse to bear under them the yoke of reverence.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod melius ostendimus, si David factum ad medium deducamus. Saul quippe persecutor, cum ad purgandum ventrem speluncam fuisset ingressus, illic cum viris suis David inerat, qui jam tam longo tempore persecutionis ejus mala tolerabat.
chunks.english: Which we better show, if we bring forth the deed of David into the middle. For Saul the persecutor, when he had entered a cave to relieve himself, David was there with his men, who had already for so long a time endured the evils of his persecution.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cumque eum viri sui ad feriendum Saul accenderent, fregit eos responsionibus, quia manum mittere in christum Domini non deberet. Qui tamen occulte surrexit, et oram chlamydis ejus abscidit (I Reg. XXIV, 4).
chunks.english: And when his men were urging him to strike Saul, he broke them with responses, because he ought not to lay a hand on the anointed of the Lord. Yet he secretly arose, and cut off the edge of his cloak, as in the first book of Samuel, chapter twenty-four, verse four.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid per Saul nisi mali rectores, quid per David nisi boni subditi designantur? Saul igitur ventrem purgare est pravos praepositos conceptam in corde malitiam usque ad opera miseri odoris extendere, et cogitata apud se noxia factis exterioribus exsequendo monstrare.
chunks.english: What is designated by Saul except evil leaders, what by David except good subjects? Therefore for Saul to purge his belly is for wicked superiors to extend malice conceived in the heart even to works of miserable odor, and to show by executing things thought harmful in themselves through external deeds.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: David namque Saul ferire metuit, quia piae subditorum mentes ab omni se peste obtrectationis abstinentes, praepositorum vitam nullo linguae gladio percutiunt, etiam cum de imperfectione reprehendunt.
chunks.english: For David fears to strike Saul, because the pious minds of subjects abstaining from all plague of detraction, strike the life of superiors with no sword of the tongue, even when they reprove imperfection.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Boni subditi, quando pro infirmitate abstinere sese vix possunt, ut extrema quaedam atque exteriora praepositorum mala, sed tamen humiliter, loquantur, quasi oram chalmydis silenter incidunt.
chunks.english: Good subjects, when through weakness they can scarcely abstain, so that they speak certain extreme and external evils of superiors, but nevertheless humbly, as it were silently cut the edge of the cloak.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia videlicet dum praelatae dignitati saltem innoxie et latenter derogant, quasi Regis superpositi vestem foedant; sed tamen ad semetipsos redeunt, seque vehementissime, vel de tenuissima verbi laceratione reprehendunt.
chunks.english: Because indeed while they at least innocently and secretly derogate the dignity placed over them, they as it were defile the garment of the King placed above; but nevertheless they return to themselves, and most vehemently reprove themselves even for the slightest tearing of a word.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Unde bene et illic scriptum est: Post haec David percussit cor suum, eo quod abscidisset oram chlamydis Saul (Ibid., 6).
chunks.english: Whence well also it is written there in the same chapter, verse six: After this David struck his heart, because he had cut off the edge of Saul's cloak.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Facta praepositorum oris gladio ferienda non sunt, etiam cum recte reprehendenda judicantur. Si quando vero contra eos vel in minimis lingua labitur, necesse est ut per afflictionem poenitentiae cor prematur; quatenus ad semetipsum redeat, et cum praepositae potestati deliquerit, ejus contra se judicium, a quo sibi praelatus est, perhorrescat.
chunks.english: The deeds of superiors are not to be struck with the sword of the mouth, even when they are judged to be rightly reprehended. But if at any time the tongue slips against them even in the smallest things, it is necessary that through the affliction of penance the heart be pressed; so that it may return to itself, and when it has offended against the power placed over it, may dread against itself the judgment of him from whom the one placed over it comes.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam cum praepositis delinquimus, ejus ordinationi, qui eos nobis praetulit, obviamus. Unde Moyses quoque, cum contra se et Aaron conqueri populum cognovisset, ait: Nos enim quid sumus? Nec contra nos est murmur vestrum, sed contra Dominum (Exod. XVI, 8).
chunks.english: For when we offend against superiors, we oppose the ordinance of him who placed them over us. Whence Moses also, when he had recognized the people complaining against himself and Aaron, said in the book of Exodus, chapter sixteen, verse eight: For what are we? Neither is your murmuring against us, but against the Lord.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Admonendi sunt benevoli subditi, ut sic alienis bonis congaudeant, quatenus habere et propria concupiscant. Sic proximorum facta diligendo laudent, ut etiam imitando multiplicent, ne si in hoc praesentis vitae stadio ad certamen alienum devoti fautores, sed pigri exspectatores assistant, eo post certamen sine bravio remaneant, quo nunc in certamine non laborant; et tunc eorum palmas afflicti respiciant in quorum nunc laboribus otiosi perdurant.
chunks.english: Benevolent subjects must be admonished, that they so rejoice with the goods of others, that they may also desire to have their own. That they so praise the deeds of neighbors with love, that they may also multiply them by imitating, lest if in this stadium of present life they stand as devoted supporters but lazy spectators to another's contest, there after the contest they remain without reward, where now in the contest they do not labor; and then afflicted they may look upon their palms in whose labors now they persist idle.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Valde peccamus, si aliena bene gesta non diligimus. Sed nil mercedis agimus, si ea quae diligimus, in quantum possumus, non imitamur.
chunks.english: We sin greatly, if we do not love the good deeds done by others. But we do nothing of reward, if those things which we love, as much as we can, we do not imitate.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dicendum est benevolis subditis, quia si imitari bona minime festinant quae laudantes approbant, sic eis virtutum sanctitas, sicut stultis exspectatoribus ludicrarum artium vanitas placet.
chunks.english: It must be said to benevolent subjects, that if they by no means hasten to imitate the good things which praising they approve, thus the holiness of virtues pleases them, as the vanity of theatrical arts pleases foolish spectators.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Illi namque aurigarum ac histrionum gesta favoribus efferunt, nec tamen tales esse desiderant quales illos conspiciunt esse quos laudant. Mirantur eos placita egisse, sed tamen similiter devitant placere.
chunks.english: For they extol the deeds of charioteers and actors with favors, and yet they do not desire to be such as they see those to be whom they praise. They admire that they have done pleasing things, but nevertheless they avoid pleasing similarly.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dicendum est benevolis subditis, ut cum proximorum facta conspiciunt, ad suum cor redeant, et de alienis actibus non praesumant, ne bona laudent, et agere recusent, gravius quippe extrema ultione feriendi sunt quibus placuit quod imitari noluerunt.
chunks.english: It must be said to benevolent subjects, that when they behold the deeds of neighbors, let them return to their own heart, and not presume about the actions of others, lest they praise good things and refuse to do them, for more severely must those be struck with final vengeance to whom that which they were unwilling to imitate has pleased.

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: On Envious or Defiant Subordinates
chunks.latin: CAPUT XLIII. De invidis vel protervis subditis.
chunks.english: Chapter 43: On Envious or Defiant Subordinates

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Reg. Past., part. III, c. 8.) Plerumque subditi sub pastorali regimine constituti, dum valde de se elati praesumunt, exprobrando caeteros dedignantur, et singulariter summa aestimant cuncta quae agunt. Subtiliter itaque ab arguente discutienda sunt opera protervorum, ut in quo sibi placent ostendantur quia Deo displicent.
chunks.english: Subordinates under pastoral authority, when they become greatly puffed up about themselves, disdain to reproach others, and esteem everything they do as uniquely superior. Therefore, the works of the defiant must be carefully examined by their corrector, so that they may be shown that in the very things that please them, they displease God.
chunks.notes: Opening address on pride and arrogance among subordinates

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Tunc protervos melius corrigimus, cum ea quae bene egisse credunt male acta monstramus; et unde adepta gloria creditur, inde utilis confusio subsequatur. Nonnunquam subditi, cum se vitium proterviae minime perpetrare cognoscunt, compendiosius ad correctionem veniunt, si alterius culpae manifestioris, et ex latere requisitae in proprio confunduntur; ut ex eo quod defendere nequeunt, cognoscant se tenere improbe quod defendunt.
chunks.english: We better correct the defiant when we show them that what they believed they did well was done badly, and that from what they thought brought glory, useful shame follows instead. Sometimes subordinates, when they do not recognize that they are committing the vice of defiance, come more quickly to correction if they are confronted with another more obvious fault sought from the side, so that from what they cannot defend, they may recognize that they are wrongly holding to what they do defend.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum proterve Paulus Corinthios adversum se invicem videret inflatos, ut alius Apollo, alius Pauli, alius Cephae, alius Christi esse se diceret (I Cor. I, 12; III, 4), incestus culpam in medium deduxit, quae apud eos et perpetrata fuerat, et incorrecta remanebat, dicens: Auditur inter vos fornicatio, et talis fornicatio, qualis nec inter gentes, ita ut uxorem patris quis habeat. Et vos inflati estis, et non magis luctum habuistis, ut tolleretur de medio vestrum qui opus fecit (I Cor. V, 1, 2).
chunks.english: When Paul saw the Corinthians defiantly puffed up against one another, so that one would say he belonged to Apollo, another to Paul, another to Cephas, and another to Christ, he brought into their midst the charge of incest, which had been committed among them and remained uncorrected, saying, as we read in Paul's first letter to the Corinthians, chapter five, verses one and two: It is heard that there is fornication among you, and such fornication as is not even among the gentiles, such that someone should have his father's wife. And you are puffed up, and have not rather mourned, that he who has done this deed might be taken away from among you.
chunks.notes: Paul's confrontation of the Corinthians' pride

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ac si aperte dicat: Quid vos per proterviam hujus vel illius dicitis, qui per dissolutionem negligentiae nullius vos esse monstratis? (Reg. Past., part. III, c. 10.) Admonendi sunt invidi subditi, ut perpendant quantae caecitatis sunt qui alieno profectu deficiunt, aliena exaltatione contabescunt.
chunks.english: As if he were openly saying: Why do you defiantly claim to belong to this one or that one, when through your negligent dissolution you show yourselves to belong to no one? Envious subordinates must be warned to consider how great is the blindness of those who fail at another's progress and waste away at another's exaltation.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quantae infelicitatis sunt, qui melioratione proximi deteriores fiunt; dumque augmenta alienae prosperitatis aspiciunt, apud semetipsos anxie afflicti, cordis sui peste moriuntur. Quid invidis infelicius, quos dum conspecta felicitas afficit, poena nequiores reddit?
chunks.english: How great is the unhappiness of those who become worse through their neighbor's improvement, and while they look upon the increases of another's prosperity, they die anxiously afflicted within themselves by the plague of their own heart. What is more unhappy than the envious, whom, while observed happiness affects them, punishment renders more wicked?

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Aliorum vero bona, quae habere non possunt, si diligerent, sua fecissent. Nostra nimirum sunt bona aliorum, quae, etsi imitari non possumus, amamus in aliis; et amantium fiunt quaeque amantur in nobis. Hinc ergo pensent invidi, quantae virtutis est charitas, quae alieni laboris opera nostra sine labore facit.
chunks.english: But if they loved the good things of others which they cannot have, they would have made them their own. Certainly the good things of others are ours when, even if we cannot imitate them, we love them in others; and whatever is loved in us becomes the possession of those who love. From this, therefore, let the envious consider how great a virtue charity is, which makes the works of another's labor our own without labor.
chunks.notes: The transformative power of loving others' virtues

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Dum se invidi a livore minime custodiunt, in antiquam versuti hostis nequitiam demerguntur. De illo namque scriptum est: Invidia diaboli mors intravit in orbem terrarum (Sap. II, 24). Quia enim ipse coelum perdidit, condito hoc homini invidit, et damnationem suam perditus adhuc alios perdendo cumulavit.
chunks.english: While the envious do not guard themselves at all from malice, they are plunged into the ancient wickedness of the cunning enemy. For it is written of him in the book of Wisdom, chapter two, verse twenty-four: Through the envy of the devil, death entered into the world. Because he himself lost heaven, he envied this created man, and being lost, he still multiplied his own damnation by destroying others.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cognoscant invidi quantis lapsibus subcrescentis ruinae subjaceant, quia dum livorem a corde non projiciunt, ad apertas operum nequitias devolvuntur. Nisi enim Cain invidisset acceptam fratris hostiam, minime pervenisset ad exstinguendam vitam. Unde scriptum est: Et respexit Dominus ad Abel, et ad munera ejus; ad Cain vero et ad munera illius non respexit. Iratusque est Cain vehementer, et concidit vultus ejus (Gen. IV, 4).
chunks.english: Let the envious recognize to how many falls of growing ruin they are subject, because while they do not cast malice from their heart, they roll down to open wickedness in their deeds. For unless Cain had envied his brother's accepted sacrifice, he would never have arrived at extinguishing his life. Whence it is written in Genesis, chapter four, verse four: And the Lord looked upon Abel and his gifts, but upon Cain and his offerings he did not look. And Cain was exceedingly angry, and his countenance fell.
chunks.notes: The story of Cain and Abel as illustration of envy leading to murder

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Itaque livor sacrificii fratricidii seminarium fuit. Nam quem meliorem se esse doluit, ne utcumque esset, amputavit. Dicendum est invidis quia dum se ista intrinsecus peste consumunt, etiam quidquid in se aliud boni habere videntur, interimunt. Unde scriptum est: Vita carnium sanitas cordis; putredo ossium invidia (Prov. XIV, 30).
chunks.english: Thus malice over the sacrifice became the seed of fratricide. For he cut off the one whom he grieved to be better than himself, so that he would not exist at all. It must be said to the envious that while they consume themselves with this inner plague, they also destroy whatever other good they seem to have in themselves. Whence it is written in the book of Proverbs, chapter fourteen, verse thirty: The life of the flesh is the health of the heart; envy is the rottenness of the bones.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Per livoris vitium ante Dei oculos pereunt etiam quae humanis oculis fortia videntur. Ossa quippe per invidiam putrescere est, quaedam etiam robusta deperire (Moral. XXVI, c. 1, n. 1). Ille est vere humilis subjectus in bonis, qui non est defensor in malis.
chunks.english: Through the vice of malice, even those things that seem strong to human eyes perish before the eyes of God. For bones to rot through envy is for even certain strong things to perish. He is truly a humble subordinate in good things who is not a defender in evil things.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nam dum de malis suis subjectus arguitur, et contra verba arguentis accenditur, quando de bonis suis quasi humiliter titubat, per humilitatis vocem ornari appetit, non doceri.
chunks.english: For when a subordinate is confronted about his evils and becomes inflamed against the words of the one confronting him, when he hesitates quasi-humbly about his good things, he desires to be adorned through the voice of humility, not to be taught.
chunks.notes: False humility as resistance to correction

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: On Clerics and Their Required Character
chunks.latin: CAPUT XLIV. De clericis, quales eos oporteat esse.
chunks.english: Chapter 44: On Clerics and Their Required Character

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. II, in Evang., homil. 17, n. 18.) Clericus admonendus est quatenus sic vivat, ut bonum exemplum vitae suae saecularibus praebeat. In clerico si quid juste reprehenditur, ex ejus vitio ipsa religionis nostrae aestimatio gravatur.
chunks.english: A cleric must be admonished to live in such a way that he provides a good example of his life to secular people. If anything in a cleric is justly blamed, the very estimation of our religion is burdened by his fault.
chunks.notes: The high standard for clerical conduct

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Reg. Past., p. III, c. 4.) Clerici discant ut quae a senioribus suis jubentur impleant, ut humiliter eorum imperiis subjaceant; ut nec subjectio eos conterat, nec locus superior extollat. Clerici discant quomodo ante occulti arbitris oculos per humilitatem et obedientiam sua interiora componant, quatenus non reprobi puniantur, sed cum electis aeterna praemia sortiantur.
chunks.english: Let clerics learn to fulfill what is commanded by their elders, to submit humbly to their commands, so that neither subjection crushes them nor a higher position lifts them up. Let clerics learn how to order their interior selves through humility and obedience before the eyes of the hidden judge, so that they may not be punished as reprobates, but may receive eternal rewards with the elect.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Admonendi sunt clerici, ut tanto circa se sollicitius vivant, quanto eos aliena cura non implicat. Dicendum est clericis, ne praepositorum suorum vitam temere judicent, si quid eos fortasse agere reprehensibiliter vident; ne unde recte mala redarguunt, inde per elationis impulsum in profundiora demergantur.
chunks.english: Clerics must be warned to live so much more carefully around themselves as the care of others does not entangle them. It must be said to clerics that they should not rashly judge the life of their superiors, if perhaps they see them doing something blameworthy, lest from where they rightly condemn evils, they should be plunged into deeper things through the impulse of pride.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Admonendi sunt clerici, ne cum culpas suorum praepositorum considerant, sic eorum prava apud semetipsos dijudicent, ut tamen divino timore constricti, ferre sub eis jugum reverentiae non recusent; quia facta praepositorum oris gladio ferienda non sunt, etiam cum recte reprehendenda judicantur.
chunks.english: Clerics must be warned that when they consider the faults of their superiors, they should so judge their wrongs within themselves that nevertheless, bound by divine fear, they do not refuse to bear the yoke of reverence under them; because the deeds of superiors must not be struck with the sword of the mouth, even when they are judged rightly to be blamed.
chunks.notes: Respecting authority despite recognizing faults

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Ibid. 6, 7.) Plerosque clericos ab impudentiae vitio non nisi increpatio dura compescit, quia dum se delinquere nesciunt, necesse est ut a pluribus increpentur. Verecundos clericos plerumque ad melius exhortatio modesta componit, quia ad conversionem sufficit quod doctor eis mala sua saltem leniter ad memoriam reducit.
chunks.english: For many clerics, nothing but harsh rebuke restrains them from the vice of shamelessness, because while they do not know themselves to be at fault, it is necessary that they be rebuked by many. For modest clerics, moderate exhortation usually leads them to better things, because for their conversion it is sufficient that a teacher brings their evils gently to their memory.
chunks.notes: Different approaches for different temperaments

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Major profectus modestis clericis adducitur, si hoc quod in eis reprehenditur quasi manu linguae blandientis ex latere tangatur. (Ibid. c. 8.) Pusillanimes clericos aptius ad iter bene agendi reducimus, si quaedam illorum bona ex latere requiramus, ut dum in eis alia reprehendendo corripimus, alia amplectendo laudemus, quatenus eorum teneritudinem laus audita nutriat, quam culpa increpata castigat.
chunks.english: Greater progress is brought to modest clerics if what is blamed in them is touched from the side, as if with the hand of a soothing tongue. We more suitably bring back faint-hearted clerics to the path of right action if we seek out from the side certain of their good things, so that while we correct them by reproving some things, we praise them by embracing others, so that heard praise may nourish their tenderness, which rebuked fault chastises.
chunks.notes: Pastoral wisdom in correction

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerumque utilius apud clericos proficimus, si et eorum bene gesta memoramus. (Reg. Past. p. III, c. 11.) Et si qua ab eis inordinate gesta sunt, non jam tanquam perpetrata corripimus, sed quasi adhuc ne perpetrari debeant prohibemus.
chunks.english: We often make more useful progress with clerics if we also recall their good deeds. And if any things have been done by them in a disorderly way, we do not rebuke them as already committed, but we forbid them as if they still should not be committed.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerique clericorum dum in culpa sua deprehendi metuunt, semper improbas defensiones quaerunt, semper pavidis suspicionibus agitantur. Nihil quippe est ad defendendum puritate tutius, nihil ad dicendum veritate facilius. Nam dum fallaciam suam tueri cogitur, labore duro cor fatigatur.
chunks.english: Many clerics, while they fear to be caught in their fault, always seek wicked defenses and are always agitated by fearful suspicions. For nothing is safer for defense than purity, nothing easier for speaking than truth. For while one is compelled to protect his deceit, the heart is wearied with hard labor.
chunks.notes: The burden of living a lie

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerumque in culpa clerici deprehensi, dum quales sint cognosci refugiunt, sese sub fallaciae velamen abscondunt, et hoc quod peccant, quodque jam aperte cernitur, excusare moliuntur. Plerumque contingit ut is qui pravorum clericorum culpas corripere studet, aspersae falsitatis nebulis seductus, pene amisisse se videat quod de eis jam certum tenebat.
chunks.english: Often clerics caught in fault, while they refuse to be known for what they are, hide themselves under the veil of deceit, and strive to excuse what they have sinned, and what is now openly seen. It often happens that one who strives to correct the faults of wicked clerics, seduced by the mists of sprinkled falsehood, sees that he has almost lost what he already held as certain about them.
chunks.notes: The difficulty of correcting deceptive clerics

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Per prophetam dicitur: Ibi habuit foveam ericius (Isa. XXXIV, 15). Ericii quippe nomine impurae mentis seseque callide defendentis duplicitas designatur. Ericius namque cum apprehenditur, ejus et caput cernitur, et pedes videntur, et corpus omne conspicitur; sed mox ut apprehensus fuerit, semetipsum in sphaeram colligit, pedes introrsus subtrahit, caput abscondit, et intra tenentis manus totum simul amittitur quod totum simul ante videbatur.
chunks.english: Through the prophet it is said in the book of Isaiah, chapter thirty-four, verse fifteen: There the hedgehog had its den. By the name of hedgehog is designated the duplicity of an impure mind defending itself craftily. For when a hedgehog is seized, its head is seen, its feet are visible, and its whole body is observed; but as soon as it has been seized, it gathers itself into a sphere, withdraws its feet inward, hides its head, and within the holder's hands all that was seen as a whole before is lost all at once.
chunks.notes: Extended metaphor of the hedgehog as deceptive cleric

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Cum impurae mentes in suis excessibus comprehenduntur, quasi caput ericii cernitur, quia quo initio ad culpam peccator accesserit, videtur. Pedes ericii conspiciuntur: quia quibus vestigiis nequitia sit perpetrata cognoscitur, et tamen adductis repente excusationibus, impura mens introrsus pedes colligit, quia cuncta iniquitatis suae vestigia abscondit.
chunks.english: When impure minds are caught in their excesses, it is as if the head of the hedgehog is seen, because it is visible by what beginning the sinner approached his fault. The feet of the hedgehog are observed, because it is known by what tracks the wickedness was perpetrated, and yet when excuses are suddenly brought forth, the impure mind draws its feet inward, because it hides all the traces of its iniquity.
chunks.notes: Continuation of hedgehog metaphor

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Caput subtrahit: quia miris defensionibus nec inchoasse malum aliquod ostendit. Quasi sphaera in manu tenentis ericius remanet: quia is qui corripit, cuncta quae jam cognoverat subito amittit, involutumque intra conscientiam tenet peccatorem; et qui totum jam deprehendendo viderat, tergiversatione pravae defensionis illusus, totum pariter ignorat.
chunks.english: It withdraws its head, because through wondrous defenses it does not even show that it began any evil. The hedgehog remains like a sphere in the hand of the holder, because the one who corrects suddenly loses all that he had already known, and holds the sinner wrapped within his conscience; and he who had already seen the whole by apprehending it, deceived by the evasion of wicked defense, is equally ignorant of the whole.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Foveam ericius habet in reprobis; quia malitiosae mentis duplicitas sese intra se colligens abscondit in tenebris defensionis. Per Habacuc prophetam dicitur: Ecce dies Domini venit magnus, et horribilis super omnes civitates munitas, et super omnes angulos excelsos.
chunks.english: The hedgehog has its den among the reprobate, because the duplicity of the malicious mind, gathering itself within itself, hides in the darkness of defense. Through the prophet Habakkuk it is said: Behold, the great and terrible day of the Lord comes upon all fortified cities and upon all high corners.
chunks.notes: Transition to judgment theme

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid enim per civitates munitas exprimitur, nisi suspectae mentes, et fallaci semper defensione circumdatae, quae quoties earum culpa corripitur, veritatis ad se jacula non admittunt? Quid per excelsos angulos (duplex quippe semper est in angulis paries) nisi impura corda signantur? quae dum veritatis simplicitatem fugiunt, ad semetipsa quodammodo duplicitatis perversitate replicantur.
chunks.english: For what is expressed by fortified cities except suspicious minds, always surrounded by deceitful defense, which whenever their fault is corrected, do not admit the javelins of truth to themselves? What is signified by high cornersfor there is always a double wall in cornersexcept impure hearts, which while they flee the simplicity of truth, are in some way folded back upon themselves by the perversity of duplicity?
chunks.notes: Interpretation of prophetic imagery

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Ira quippe extremi judicii humana corda et defensionibus contra veritatem clausa destruit, et duplicitatibus involuta dissolvit. Tunc munitae civitates cadunt, quia mentes Deo impenetratae damnabuntur. Tunc excelsi anguli corruunt, quia corda quae se per impuritatis prudentiam erigunt per justitiae sententiam prosternuntur.
chunks.english: For the wrath of the final judgment destroys human hearts both closed by defenses against truth and dissolves those wrapped in duplicities. Then fortified cities fall, because minds impenetrable to God will be condemned. Then high corners collapse, because hearts that raise themselves through the prudence of impurity are cast down by the sentence of justice.
chunks.notes: Eschatological conclusion to discussion of deception

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: On the Life and Conduct of Monks
chunks.latin: CAPUT XLV. De vita, vel conversatione monachorum.
chunks.english: Chapter 45: On the Life and Conduct of Monks

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral., lib. V, c. 3, n. 3.) Omnes monachi saeculum relinquentes punire flendo non desinunt quae deliquerunt. Gravi se moerore afficiunt, quia longe huc a facie Conditoris projecti, adhuc in aeternae patriae gaudiis non sunt. De quorum corde bene per Salomonem dicitur: Cor, quod novit amaritudinem animae suae, in gaudio illius non miscebitur extraneus (Prov. XIV, 10).
chunks.english: All monks, leaving the world, do not cease to punish by weeping the things they have sinned. They affect themselves with grave sorrow, because having been cast far from the face of the Creator, they are not yet in the joys of the eternal homeland. Of whose heart it is well said through Solomon in the book of Proverbs, chapter fourteen, verse ten: The heart that knows the bitterness of its soul, no stranger will be mixed in its joy.
chunks.notes: The monastic life characterized by penitence

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Corda bonorum monachorum amaritudinem suam noverunt, quia aerumnam exsilii, qua projecti lacerantur, intelligunt; et quam sint tranquilla quae perdiderunt, quam confusa in quibus ceciderunt, sentiunt. (Num. 4.) Monachi, qui in amaritudine animae sunt, mori mundo funditus concupiscunt; ut sicut in saeculo ipsi nihil appetunt, ita jam a saeculo nulla obligatione teneantur.
chunks.english: The hearts of good monks know their bitterness, because they understand the hardship of exile by which they are torn while cast down; and they sense how tranquil are the things they have lost, how confused are those things into which they have fallen. Monks who are in bitterness of soul thoroughly desire to die to the world, so that just as they themselves seek nothing in the world, so now they may be held by no obligation from the world.
chunks.notes: The desire for complete detachment

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerumque contingit ut jam monachus mundum mente non teneat, sed tamen monachum quibusdam occupationibus astringat, et ipse quidem mundo jam mortuus est, sed ipsi mundus adhuc vivit. Adhuc namque mundus eum concupiscit, dum alio intentum in suis actionibus rapere contendit.
chunks.english: It often happens that a monk no longer holds the world in his mind, but nevertheless the world binds the monk with certain occupations, and he himself is indeed already dead to the world, but the world still lives for him. For the world still desires him while it strives to seize him, intent on other things, in its actions.
chunks.notes: The challenge of worldly entanglements

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Paulus apostolus, cum saeculum perfecte despiceret, et talem se factum videret, quem jam hoc saeculum concupiscere omnino non posset, ruptis hujus vitae vinculis, liber dicit: Mihi mundus crucifixus est, et ego mundo (Gal. VI, 14). Mundus quippe ei crucifixus fuerat, quia hunc, cordi suo jam mortuum, non amabat. Sed et seipsum mundo crucifixerat, quia talem se ei exhibere studuit, ut ab eo quasi mortuus concupisci non posset.
chunks.english: The apostle Paul, when he perfectly despised the world and saw himself made such that this world could no longer desire him at all, with the bonds of this life broken, says freely in Paul's letter to the Galatians, chapter six, verse fourteen: The world is crucified to me, and I to the world. For the world had been crucified to him, because he did not love it, already dead to his heart. But he had also crucified himself to the world, because he strove to show himself to it such that he could not be desired by it as if he were dead.
chunks.notes: Paul as exemplar of complete detachment

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si uno in loco sint mortuus et vivens, etsi mortuus vivum non videt, vivus tamen mortuum videt; si vero utrique sunt mortui, alter alterum nequaquam videt. Ita qui jam mundum non amat, sed tamen ab illo vel non volens amatur, etsi ipse velut mortuus mundum non videt, hunc tamen mundus adhuc non mortuus videt.
chunks.english: If a dead person and a living person are in one place, even if the dead does not see the living, the living nevertheless sees the dead; but if both are dead, neither sees the other at all. Thus one who no longer loves the world, but nevertheless is loved by it even unwillingly, even if he like a dead man does not see the world, the world, not yet dead, still sees him.
chunks.notes: Metaphor of mutual death

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si vero nec ipse in amore mundum retinet, nec rursum a mundi amore retinetur, vicissim sibi utrique exstincti sunt; quia dum alter alterum non appetit, quasi mortuum mortuus non attendit. Paulus vas electionis, quia nec mundi gloriam quaerebat, nec a mundi gloria ipse quaerebatur; et se mundo et mundum sibi crucifixum esse gloriatur.
chunks.english: But if he neither holds the world in love, nor is he again held by the world's love, they are mutually extinct to each other; because while neither seeks the other, the dead does not attend to the dead. Paul, the vessel of election, because he neither sought the world's glory, nor was he himself sought by the world's glory, glories that both he is crucified to the world and the world to him.
chunks.notes: Paul's complete mutual detachment from world

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quod quia multi monachi appetunt, sed tamen usque ad culmen exstinctionis omnimode non assurgunt, recte gementes dicunt: Quare data est misero lux, et vita his qui in amaritudine animae sunt (Job. III, 20)? Cum hujus mundi gloria tristibus gementibusque tribuitur, poena se validissimi timoris afficiunt; quia etsi ipsi mundum non tenent adhuc tamen tales se esse metuunt qui a mundo teneantur: quia nisi ei quantulumcunque viverent, hos ad usum suum procul dubio non amaret.
chunks.english: Because many monks desire this, but nevertheless do not rise in every way to the summit of extinction, they rightly say groaning, as found in the book of Job, chapter three, verse twenty: Why is light given to the miserable, and life to those who are in bitterness of soul? When the glory of this world is granted to the sad and groaning, they affect themselves with the punishment of strongest fear; because even if they themselves do not hold the world, they nevertheless fear that they are still such as to be held by the world, because unless they lived to it even a little, it would without doubt not love them for its use.
chunks.notes: The monk's fear of incomplete detachment

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Mare enim viva corpora in semetipso retinet, nam mortua extra se protinus expellit. (Ibid. c. 4, n. 6.) Nonnunquam monachi idcirco ad concepta desideria minime perveniunt, ut ipsa interveniente tarditate ad eadem desideria laxato mentis sinu dilatentur; et quae extenuari fortasse impleta poterant, magna dispositione agitur ut repulsa multiplicius crescant.
chunks.english: For the sea retains living bodies in itself, but it immediately expels dead ones outside itself. Sometimes monks therefore scarcely arrive at their conceived desires, so that with intervening delay they may be expanded to the same desires with relaxed bosom of mind; and those things which perhaps could be diminished when fulfilled, it is done by great disposition that repulsed they may grow more abundantly.
chunks.notes: Delayed gratification in spiritual growth

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerique monachorum sic in praesens saeculum mortificari appetunt ut jam perfecte, si liceat, Conditoris sui faciem contemplentur. Sed eorum desiderium differtur, ut proficiat; et tarditatis suae sinu nutritur, ut crescat. In Canticis canticorum sponsa sponsi sui faciem anhelans, clamat: In lectulo meo per noctes quaesivi quem diligit anima mea; quaesivi illum, et non inveni (Cant. III, 1).
chunks.english: Many monks so desire to be mortified to the present age that they may now contemplate perfectly, if it were permitted, the face of their Creator. But their desire is deferred so that it may profit; and it is nourished in the bosom of its delay so that it may grow. In the Song of Songs, the bride, gasping for the face of her bridegroom, cries out in chapter three, verse one: In my bed by night I sought him whom my soul loves; I sought him and did not find him.
chunks.notes: The Song of Songs applied to monastic longing

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Abscondit se sponsus, cum quaeritur, ut non inventus ardentius quaeratur; et differtur quaerens sponsa ne inveniat, ut tarditate sua capacior reddita, multiplicius quandoque inveniat quod quaerebat. (Num. 7.) Cum spiritales monachi plene mortificationem suam appetunt, quanto fiunt viciniores ad finem, tanto se exhibent ardentiores in opere.
chunks.english: The bridegroom hides himself when he is sought, so that not being found he may be sought more ardently; and the seeking bride is delayed from finding, so that made more capacious by her delay, she may at some time find more abundantly what she sought. When spiritual monks fully desire their mortification, the closer they become to the end, the more ardent they show themselves in work.
chunks.notes: Spiritual intensification near the end

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Laborando ergo non deficiunt, sed magis ad usum laboris crescunt; qui quo jam praemia propinquiora considerant, eo in opere delectabilius exsudant. Paulus apostolus quasi quibusdam monachis absconditum aeternae patriae thesaurum quaerentibus, dicit: Non deserentes collectionem notram, sicut est consuetudinis quorumdam, sed consolantes, et tanto magis, quanto videritis appropinquantem diem (Heb. X, 25).
chunks.english: Therefore they do not fail by laboring, but rather grow in the practice of labor; for the closer they consider the rewards to be, the more delightfully they sweat in the work. The apostle Paul, as if to certain monks seeking the hidden treasure of the eternal homeland, says in the letter to the Hebrews, chapter ten, verse twenty-five: Not deserting our gathering, as is the custom of some, but consoling, and so much more as you see the day approaching.
chunks.notes: Paul's exhortation to perseverance

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Laborantem quippe consolari est pariter in labore persistere, quia sublevatio laboris est visio collaborantis. (Moral, V, 31, n. 55.) Plerique monachorum, quia ab operibus mundi non torpore, sed virtute sopiuntur, laboriosius dormiunt quam vigilare potuerunt; quia in eo quod actiones hujus saeculi deserentes superant, robusto conflictu quotidie contra semetipsos pugnant, ne mens per negligentiam torpeat, ne subacta otio, ad desideria immunda frigescat, ne in ipsis bonis desideriis plus justo inferveat, ne sub discretionis specie sibimet parcendo, a perfectione languescat.
chunks.english: For to console one who labors is to persist equally in labor, because the relief of labor is the sight of one who labors together. Many monks, because they are lulled to sleep not by torpor but by virtue from the works of the world, sleep more laboriously than they could keep watch; because in deserting and overcoming the actions of this age, they fight daily against themselves in robust conflict, lest the mind grow torpid through negligence, lest subdued by idleness it grow cold toward impure desires, lest it burn too much in the good desires themselves beyond what is just, lest under the appearance of discretion, sparing itself, it languish from perfection.
chunks.notes: The paradox of monastic rest as labor

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Bonus monachus ab hujus mundi inquieta concupiscentia se penitus subtrahit, ac terrenarum actionum strepitum deserit, et per quietis studium ejus mens virtutibus intenta, quasi vigilans dormit. Unusquisque monachus ad contemplanda interna minime perducitur, nisi ab his quae exterius implicant, studiose subtrahitur.
chunks.english: A good monk completely withdraws himself from the restless concupiscence of this world and deserts the noise of earthly actions, and through the pursuit of quiet, his mind intent on virtues sleeps as if watching. Each monk is scarcely brought to contemplate internal things unless he is carefully withdrawn from those things which entangle him externally.
chunks.notes: Necessity of withdrawal for contemplation

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc etenim per semetipsam Veritas dicit: Nemo potest duobus dominis servire (II Tim. II, 4). Hinc Paulus ait: Nemo militans Deo, implicat se negotiis saecularibus, ut ei placeat cui se probavit (Matth. VI, 24). Per Prophetam Dominus admonet, dicens: Vacate, et videte, quoniam ego sum Deus (Ps. XLV, 11). Quia videlicet nequaquam notitia interna conspicitur, nisi ab externa implicatione cessetur.
chunks.english: For through itself Truth says in the Gospel of Matthew, chapter six, verse twenty-four: No one can serve two masters. Hence Paul says in Paul's second letter to Timothy, chapter two, verse four: No one serving as a soldier for God entangles himself in secular business, so that he may please him to whom he has proved himself. Through the prophet the Lord admonishes, saying in Psalm forty-five, verse eleven: Be still and see that I am God. Because clearly internal knowledge is not discerned at all unless one ceases from external entanglement.
chunks.notes: Biblical foundations for monastic withdrawal

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: On Monastic Humility and Work
chunks.latin: CAPUT XLVI. De humilitate, vel opere eorum.
chunks.english: Chapter 46: On Monastic Humility and Work

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Admonendus est monachus ut reverentiam habitus sui in actu, in locutione, in cogitatione sua semper circumspiciat, atque ea quae mundi sunt perfecte deserat, et quod ostendit humanis oculis habitu, hoc ante Dei oculos moribus praetendat.
chunks.english: A monk must be admonished to always look carefully at the reverence of his habit in his action, in his speech, in his thought, and to perfectly abandon the things that are of the world, and what he shows to human eyes by his habit, this he should display before the eyes of God by his character.
chunks.notes: Consistency between exterior and interior life

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. V, c. 11, n. 20.) Piae monachorum mentes, cum deest exteriorum curarum administratio, in his exterioribus implicari non quaerunt. Graviter autem etiam, cum adsunt, ferunt, quia per exteriorum curam a se exire pertimescunt. Omnes monachi qui in curis exterioribus spargi refugiunt, simplices in cogitatione, atque in conscientiae suae habitatione consistunt.
chunks.english: The devout minds of monks, when the administration of external cares is absent, do not seek to be implicated in these external things. But even when they are present, they bear them heavily, because through the care of external things they fear to go out from themselves. All monks who refuse to be scattered in external cares are simple in thought and consist in the dwelling of their conscience.
chunks.notes: The ideal of interior simplicity

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc de Jacob scriptum est: Jacob autem vir simplex habitabat in tabernaculis (Gen. XXV, 27). In tabernaculis habitare, est sese intra secreta mentis restringere, et nequaquam exterius per desideria dissipare. Electi monachi, cum eis transitoria prosperitas arridet, favorem mundi quasi nescientes dissimulant, et forti gressu interius hoc, unde exterius sublevantur, calcant.
chunks.english: Hence it is written of Jacob in Genesis, chapter twenty-five, verse twenty-seven: But Jacob was a simple man dwelling in tents. To dwell in tents is to restrain oneself within the secrets of the mind, and in no way to dissipate oneself externally through desires. Elect monks, when transitory prosperity smiles upon them, dissimulate the favor of the world as if not knowing it, and with strong step inwardly trample that by which they are externally lifted up.
chunks.notes: Jacob as type of monastic interiority

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Electi monachi nullis pravae actionis clamoribus perstrepunt, nullo cupiditatum temporalium turbulento appetitu rapiuntur, sed nimirum curis praesentis vitae necessariis immoderatius occupari refugiunt. (Num. 21.) Saepe bona agentes monachi, paterna adhuc flagella sentiunt, ut tanto perfectiores ad haereditatem veniant, quanto eos pie feriens disciplina quotidie etiam de minimis purgat.
chunks.english: Elect monks resound with no clamors of wicked action, are seized by no turbulent appetite of temporal desires, but certainly they refuse to be occupied immoderately with the necessary cares of present life. Often monks doing good things still feel paternal scourges, so that they may come to their inheritance all the more perfect, as discipline striking them piously purges them daily even from the smallest things.
chunks.notes: Divine discipline as purification

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: On Lax Monastic Conduct
chunks.latin: CAPUT XLVII. De remissa conversatione ipsorum.
chunks.english: Chapter 47: On Lax Monastic Conduct

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. XII, c. 52, n. 59.) Sunt nonnulli qui post vitam perditam ad semetipsos redeunt, et accusante se conscientia, perversa itinera relinquunt, commutant opera, antiquae suae pravitati contradicunt, terrenas actiones fugiunt, desideria superna sectantur; sed priusquam in eisdem sanctis desideriis solidentur, per torporem mentis ad ea quae dijudicare coeperant redeunt, atque ad mala quae fugere disposuerant recurrunt.
chunks.english: There are some who after a lost life return to themselves, and with conscience accusing them, they abandon perverse paths, they change their works, they contradict their ancient depravity, they flee earthly actions, they pursue heavenly desires; but before they are strengthened in these same holy desires, through torpor of mind they return to those things which they had begun to judge, and they run back to the evils which they had determined to flee.
chunks.notes: The danger of unstable conversion

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Saepe contingit ut pro utilitate multorum etiam sancti viri exterioribus actibus serviant, et populorum gubernationibus occupentur; hoc infirmi aspicientes, et per vetustam adhuc superbiam quaerentes imitari, exterioribus se actionibus inserunt; sed quanto ad eas non eruditi disciplinis spiritualibus veniunt, tanto eas carnaliter exsequuntur.
chunks.english: It often happens that for the benefit of many, even holy men serve in external actions and are occupied with the governance of peoples; weak men observing this, and seeking to imitate through ancient pride still present, insert themselves into external actions; but inasmuch as they come to them not instructed in spiritual disciplines, so much do they carry them out carnally.
chunks.notes: Premature assumption of external duties

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nisi prius cor longo studio, et diutina conversatione in desideriis coelestibus convalescat, cum ad exteriora agenda refunditur, ab omni statu boni operis eradicatur. (Cap. 53, num. 60.) Sunt nonnulli qui post perversa itinera sanctas vias sectari appetunt; sed priusquam in eis, ut diximus, desideria bona roborentur, quaedam illos praesentis saeculi prosperitas accipit, quae eos rebus exterioribus implicat, et eorum mentem, dum  calore intimi amoris retrahit, quasi ex frigore exstinguit, et quidquid in eis de virtutum flore apparere videbatur, interficit.
chunks.english: Unless the heart first grows strong in heavenly desires through long study and prolonged conduct, when it is poured back to doing external things, it is uprooted from every state of good work. There are some who after perverse paths desire to pursue holy ways; but before good desires are strengthened in them, as we said, a certain prosperity of the present age receives them, which implicates them in external matters, and their mind, while it withdraws from the warmth of intimate love, is as if extinguished from cold, and whatever seemed to appear in them of the flower of virtues, it kills.
chunks.notes: External prosperity as spiritual danger

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Si quid boni fortasse infirmus ac tepidus monachus agere coeperit, priusquam in eo per longitudinem temporis convalescat, ad exteriora delabitur, et perverse deserit quae recte inchoasse videbatur. In terrenis quippe actibus valde frigescit animus, si necdum fuerit per intima dona solidatus.
chunks.english: If perhaps a weak and lukewarm monk begins to do something good, before he grows strong in it through length of time, he slips down to external things, and perversely abandons what he seemed to have rightly begun. For the spirit grows very cold in earthly actions, if it has not yet been solidified through interior gifts.
chunks.notes: The necessity of interior strengthening before action

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Valde necesse est ut loca majora, vel exteriora opera, quae humanis sunt necessitatibus profutura, illic exercenda suscipiant qui haec dijudicare atque sub semetipsis premere ex virtute intima noverunt. Cum infirmus quisque, vel ad locum regiminis, vel ad exteriora agenda retrahitur, quo quasi extra se ducitur, eradicatur; quia et arbor quae radices prius in altum non mittit, citius ventorum impetu sternitur, si se ad altam verticem extollit; eoque citius ad ima corruit, quo altius in aere sine radicibus excrevit.
chunks.english: It is very necessary that greater places or external works, which will be profitable for human necessities, be undertaken to be exercised by those who know how to judge these things and press them down under themselves from interior virtue. When any weak person is drawn back either to a place of governance or to doing external things, by which he is led as if outside himself, he is uprooted; because also a tree that does not first send roots into the deep is more quickly laid low by the force of winds if it raises itself to a high summit; and it falls more quickly to the depths, the higher it has grown in the air without roots.
chunks.notes: Metaphor of the uprooted tree

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Nonnunquam florentem vineam non frigus, sed aestus arefacit. Cumque immoderato calore tangitur, discusso flore botrus tabescit. Et plerumque contingit, ut hi qui ad bona opera recta intentione non veniunt, cum placere se hominibus vident, ad exercenda haec eadem opera vehementius accendantur, humanis placitura oculis agere anxie studeant, et quasi in sancto studio fervescant.
chunks.english: Sometimes not cold but heat dries up a flourishing vineyard. And when it is touched by immoderate heat, with the flower scattered, the grape cluster withers. And it often happens that those who do not come to good works with right intention, when they see themselves pleasing men, are more vehemently inflamed to exercise these same works, they anxiously strive to do things that will please human eyes, and they burn hot as if in holy study.
chunks.notes: The danger of human approval

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quid itaque istos, nisi in flore aestus contingit, quos humanae laudis appetitio a fructu alienos fecit? In Canticis canticorum per Salomonem dicitur: Mane surgamus ad vineas, videamus si floruit vinea, si flores fructus parturiunt (Cant. VII, 12). Florescunt quippe vineae, cum mentes fidelium bona opera proponunt. Sed fructus non pariunt, si ab eo quod proposuerint, aliquibus victi erroribus, infirmantur.
chunks.english: What therefore happens to these except heat in the flower, whom the appetite for human praise has made strangers to fruit? In the Song of Songs through Solomon it is said in chapter seven, verse twelve: Let us rise early to the vineyards, let us see if the vineyard has flourished, if the flowers bring forth fruits. For vineyards flourish when the minds of the faithful propose good works. But they do not bear fruit if, conquered by some errors, they are weakened from what they proposed.
chunks.notes: Distinction between flowering and fruit-bearing

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 61.) Non ergo intuendum est si vineae floreant, sed si flores ad partum fructuum convalescant; quia nil mirum est si quis bona inchoet, sed valde mirabile est si intentione recta in bono opere perduret. Unde fit plerumque ut si in bono opere recta intentio non teneatur, etiam ipsum hoc opus, quod bonum creditur, amittatur.
chunks.english: Therefore it is not to be considered whether vineyards flourish, but whether the flowers grow strong to the birth of fruits; because it is no wonder if someone begins good things, but it is very wonderful if he perseveres in good work with right intention. Whence it often happens that if right intention is not held in good work, even this work itself, which is believed to be good, is lost.
chunks.notes: Perseverance more important than initiation

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 60.) Oliva cum in flore est, si immoderata nebula tangitur, a plenitudine fructuum vacuatur. Et quoties inchoantes quique bona opera, laudari ab aspicientibus coeperint, atque in suis laudibus delectari, fit caligo intelligentiae in cogitatione, ut jam discernere nequeant qua intentione quid faciant, et fructum perdant operis, velut ex nebula favoris.
chunks.english: When an olive tree is in flower, if it is touched by immoderate mist, it is emptied of the fullness of fruits. And whenever those beginning good works start to be praised by onlookers and to delight in their praises, a fog of understanding occurs in thought, so that they can no longer discern with what intention they do anything, and they lose the fruit of the work, as if from a mist of favor.
chunks.notes: The fog of praise obscuring intention

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 61.) Quosdam saepe monachos vidimus terrena quae possederant reliquisse, et nil jam transitorium quaerere, nullis pro hac vita jurgiis admisceri. Cumque hoc in se quisque ostendit, quasi oliva florem protulit. Sed cum quidam ex talibus rursum coeperint mundi gloriam, quam contempserant, quaerere, et terrenis rebus, quas sprevisse videbantur, insatiabiliter inhiare, vacare jurgiis, proximorum laesiones exquirere; nimirum projecit oliva florem quem proposuit, quia rudimenta boni studii ad perfecta opera non perduxit.
chunks.english: We have often seen certain monks who had abandoned the earthly things they possessed, and who sought nothing transitory, were mixed up in no quarrels for this life. And when each one showed this in himself, he brought forth a flower like an olive tree. But when certain of such people again began to seek the glory of the world which they had despised, and to gape insatiably after earthly things which they seemed to have spurned, to devote themselves to quarrels, to seek out injuries to neighbors, certainly the olive tree cast away the flower which it had put forth, because it did not bring the rudiments of good study to perfect works.
chunks.notes: The failure to complete what was begun

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sciendum summopere est quia plerumque monachis hoc evenire consuevit qui Deum puro ac simplici studio non sequuntur, quod in libro beati Job scriptum est: Congregatio hypocritae sterilis (Job. XV, 34). Coepta enim bona non amitterent, si hypocritae non fuissent. Congregant vero et hypocritae bona opera, sed eorum sterilis est ipsa congregatio; quia per hoc quod agunt, fructum recipere in aeterna retributione non appetunt.
chunks.english: It must be known most importantly because this is accustomed to happen to monks who do not follow God with pure and simple study, what is written in the book of blessed Job, chapter fifteen, verse thirty-four: The congregation of the hypocrite is barren. For they would not lose begun good things if they had not been hypocrites. But hypocrites also gather good works, but their very gathering is sterile; because through what they do, they do not desire to receive fruit in eternal retribution.
chunks.notes: Hypocrisy as root of sterility

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Fecundi ac virides in suis operibus humanis oculis videntur, sed in conspectu occulti Judicis in fecundi et aridi apparent.
chunks.english: They seem fruitful and green in their works to human eyes, but in the sight of the hidden Judge they appear unfruitful and dry.
chunks.notes: The divine versus human perspective

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: On Monks Entangled in Worldly Affairs
chunks.latin: CAPUT XLVIII. De monachis curis saeculi se implicantibus.
chunks.english: Chapter 48: On Monks Entangling Themselves in Worldly Affairs

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. V, c. 11, n. 19.) Nequaquam mens monachi ad superna attollitur, si curarum tumultibus continue in infimis occupatur. Quid enim de Deo occupata obtineat, quae de illo apprehendere aliquid etiam vacans laborat? Bene autem per Psalmistam dicitur: Vacate, et videte quoniam ego sum Deus (Ps. XLV, 11): quia qui vacare Deo negligit, suo sibi judicio lumen ejus visionis abscondit.
chunks.english: The mind of a monk is in no way lifted up to higher things if it is continuously occupied in the lowest things by the tumults of cares. For what does an occupied mind obtain concerning God, when even while vacant it labors to apprehend something of him? But it is well said through the Psalmist in Psalm forty-five, verse eleven: Be still and see that I am God, because he who neglects to be still for God hides from himself by his own judgment the light of his vision.
chunks.notes: The necessity of stillness for divine vision

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Monachi, qui rebus temporalibus occupantur, tunc bene exteriora disponunt, cum sollicite ad interiora refugiunt; cum nequaquam foras perturbationum strepitus diligunt, sed apud semetipsos intus in tranquillitatis sinu requiescunt. (Num. 20.) Pravae monachorum mentes temporalium rerum tumultus intra semetipsas versare non cessant, etiam cum vacant.
chunks.english: Monks who are occupied with temporal things then arrange external things well when they carefully flee to interior things, when they in no way love the noise of disturbances outside, but rest within themselves in the bosom of tranquility. Depraved minds of monks do not cease to turn over the tumults of temporal things within themselves, even when they are free.
chunks.notes: Interior versus exterior focus

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In cogitatione enim servant depicta quae amant, et quamvis nihil exterius faciant, apud semetipsas tamen sub pondere inquietae quietis elaborant. Quibus si earumdem rerum administratio praebeatur, semetipsas funditus deserunt; et fugitiva haec temporalia per cogitationum passus sequuntur.
chunks.english: For they keep painted in thought what they love, and although they do nothing externally, they nevertheless labor within themselves under the weight of restless rest. If the administration of these same things is offered to them, they completely desert themselves; and they follow these fleeting temporal things through the steps of thoughts.
chunks.notes: Mental occupation with worldly concerns

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: In libro Genesis scriptum est: Factus est Esau gnarus venandi, et homo agricola (Gen. XXV, 27). Quid enim per venationem Esau, nisi eorum monachorum vita figuratur qui in exterioribus voluptatibus fusi carnalia acta sequuntur? Qui etiam agricola esse describitur, quia amatores hujus saeculi tanto magis exteriora incolunt, quanto interiora sua inculta derelinquunt.
chunks.english: It is written in the book of Genesis, chapter twenty-five, verse twenty-seven: Esau became skilled in hunting, and a farmer. For what is figured by the hunting of Esau except the life of those monks who, poured out in exterior pleasures, follow carnal actions? Who is also described as being a farmer, because lovers of this age so much more cultivate exterior things as they leave their interior things uncultivated.
chunks.notes: Esau as type of worldly monk

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Num. 21.) Dissimulanda sunt monachis quae exterius favent, reprimenda quae interius perstrepunt, declinanda quae quasi necessaria involvunt; et tamen in his omnibus adhuc districti examinis flagella metuenda. Plerumque ipsa nostra perfectio culpa non caret, nisi hanc severus Judex in subtili lance examinis misericorditer penset.
chunks.english: Things that favor externally must be dissimulated by monks, things that resound internally must be repressed, things that involve them as if necessary must be avoided; and yet in all these things the scourges of strict examination must still be feared. Often our very perfection is not without fault, unless the severe Judge mercifully weighs it in the subtle balance of examination.
chunks.notes: The incompleteness of human perfection

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Lib. I in Evan., homil. 17, n. 14.) Curis enim saecularibus intenti, tanto insensibiliores intus efficimur, quanto ad ea quae foris sunt studiosiores videmur. Usu curae terrenae a coelesti desiderio obdurescit animus; et dum ipso sua usu durus efficitur per actionem saeculi, ad ea emolliri non valet quae pertinent ad charitatem Dei.
chunks.english: For intent on secular cares, we become so much more insensible within as we seem more studious toward those things which are outside. By the use of earthly care, the spirit grows hard from heavenly desire; and while by its very use it is made hard through the action of the world, it cannot be softened toward those things which pertain to the charity of God.
chunks.notes: The hardening effect of worldly preoccupation

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sancta Ecclesia de membris suis infirmantibus dicit: Posuerunt me custodem in vineis, vineam meam non custodivi (Cant. I, 5). Vineae quippe nostrae actiones sunt, quas usu quotidiani laboris excolimus. Sed custodes in vineis positi, nostram vineam minime custodimus, quia dum extraneis cogitationibus implicamur, ministerium actionis nostrae negligimus.
chunks.english: The holy Church says of her weakening members in the Song of Songs, chapter one, verse five: They made me keeper of the vineyards, but my own vineyard I have not kept. For our vineyards are our actions, which we cultivate by the use of daily labor. But placed as keepers in the vineyards, we scarcely keep our own vineyard, because while we are implicated in foreign thoughts, we neglect the ministry of our action.
chunks.notes: Neglect of interior life through external duties

chunks.speaker: announcer
chunks.chapter_title: On Monastic Lukewarmness
chunks.latin: CAPUT XLIX. De tepiditate monachorum.
chunks.english: Chapter 49: On Monastic Lukewarmness

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Moral. lib. V, c. 31, n. 55.) Nonnulli monachorum mundi quidem actiones fugiunt, sed nullis virtutibus exercentur. Hi nimirum torpore, non studio dormiunt; et idcirco interna non conspiciunt, quia caput non in lapide, sed in terra posuerunt.
chunks.english: Some monks indeed flee the actions of the world, but are exercised in no virtues. These certainly sleep by torpor, not by study; and therefore they do not perceive interior things, because they placed their head not on a stone but on earth.
chunks.notes: Contrast with Jacob's stone pillow at Bethel

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Plerumque monachis contingit, ut quanto securius ab externis actionibus cessant, tanto latius immundae in se cogitationis strepitum per otium congerant. Unde sub Judaeae specie per prophetam torpens otio anima defletur, cum dicitur: Viderunt eam hostes, et deriserunt sabbata ejus (Thren. I, 7). Praecepto legis ab exteriori opere in sabbato cessatur. Hostes ergo sabbata videntes irrident, cum maligni spiritus ipsa vacationis otia ad cogitationes illicitas pertrahunt; ut unaquaeque anima quo remota ab externis actionibus Deo servire creditur, eo magis eorum tyrannidi illicita cogitando famuletur.
chunks.english: It often happens to monks that the more securely they cease from external actions, the more widely they heap up the noise of impure thought in themselves through idleness. Whence under the likeness of Judea, through the prophet the soul growing torpid in idleness is lamented when it is said in Lamentations, chapter one, verse seven: Her enemies saw her and mocked at her sabbaths. By the precept of the law one ceases from external work on the sabbath. Therefore enemies seeing the sabbaths mock, when malign spirits drag the very leisures of vacation to illicit thoughts, so that each soul, the more it is believed to serve God removed from external actions, so much more it serves their tyranny by thinking illicit things.
chunks.notes: The spiritual danger of undisciplined leisure

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: (Reg. Past., part. III, c. 34.) Per sapientissimum Salomonem dicitur: Qui mollis et dissolutus est in opere suo, frater est suo opera dissipantis (Prov. XVIII, 9). Inchoata bona fortis operantis manus ad perfectionem non sublevat, si ipsa operandi remissio contra hoc quod operatum est pugnat. Monachus qui coepta bona districte non exsequitur dissolutione negligentiae manum destruentis imitatur.
chunks.english: Through the most wise Solomon it is said in Proverbs, chapter eighteen, verse nine: He who is soft and dissolute in his work is brother to him who destroys his work. The hand of the strong worker does not lift up begun good things to perfection if the very slackness of working fights against what has been worked. A monk who does not strictly carry out begun good things imitates the hand of the destroyer through the dissolution of negligence.
chunks.notes: Lax completion as destruction

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sardis Ecclesiae ab angelo dicitur: Esto vigilans, et confirma caetera, quae moritura erant: non enim invenio opera tua plena coram Deo meo (Apoc. III, 2). Quia igitur plena coram Deo ejus opera inventa non fuerant, moritura reliqua etiam quae erant gesta, praedicebat. Si quod mortis in nobis est, ad vitam non accenditur, hoc etiam exstinguitur quod quasi adhuc vivum tenetur. In hoc mundo humana anima quasi more navis est contra ictum fluminis conscendentis: uno in loco stare non permittitur, quia ad ima relabitur, nisi ad summa conetur.
chunks.english: To the Church of Sardis it is said by the angel in the book of Revelation, chapter three, verse two: Be watchful and strengthen the remaining things that were about to die, for I do not find your works full before my God. Because therefore his works were not found full before God, he predicted that the remaining things also which had been done were about to die. If what is of death in us is not kindled to life, this also is extinguished which is held as if still living. In this world the human soul is like a ship ascending against the blow of a river: it is not permitted to stand in one place, because it slips back to the depths unless it strives toward the heights.
chunks.notes: The necessity of constant spiritual effort; ends with vivid nautical metaphor

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.english: This concludes the second book of Sentences.
chunks.notes: Translator's closing note
